Professor and TA were extremely accommodating and the workload was extremely light with only 6 short essays, 2 long essays, and 2 group projects throughout the entire semester.   You also don't need any astronomy background as they teach the material in a very easy way.

ASTRO 2212.comment: Prof Nicholson is very kind and helpful, however, I find the lectures to be quite dense. If you are not really interested in Astronomy then this class is probably not for you. If you like Astro and are taking a course for fun I would opt for the intro classes instead.

I would not recommend this class. The professor is really nice and definitely knows the stuff, but the class is not structured well. Class is definitely not hard but the whole thing was so confusing. I have no idea what is happening. No clear study guide for prelim and final. Things that don't appear on powerpoint could be on exams.  Professor gives two old exams (both of them are before 2010) as "sample exams" without giving the answer key. If you are thinking of continuing your astro education sequence after 2211, please look away.

BEE 2000.comment: This was a really great way to learn a little bit about a variety of topics. Some lectures were boring, but there was a different speaker and topic each week, so it was never TOO boring. The only work was to summarize the weekly presentation.
Weekly lectures vary in enjoyability.  Workload was just a summary every week. Covid affected my experience a lot though
Hardly any work and some pretty cool lectures, it just got a little boring at times (but I think that's just bound to happen with classes like this)
A wide variety of topics was discussed and it really piqued my interest in the different subjects available.

The interactive discussion structure of the class was very engaging. I felt the material itself was extremely relevant and interesting to learn about as it addressed various aspects of climate change. The workload was not overwhelming, and the readings were intriguing.

BEE 3299.comment: Incredibly easy class with easy grading. Completely online with no lectures just due dates for assignments. If you put in minimal effort and follow the rubric for each assignment, it would be hard to not get an A+. Richards is super kind and understanding and the TAs are also helpful for any questions and feedback. Suggest taking this if you need an easy science class to balance a heavy class load.

Completely online. No lectures, just short readings (that you don't actually have to read). Take it if you want an incredibly easy A+. Didn't really learn much tho. Probably 15min-2hrs of work per week

BIOAP 3160.comment: The professor is a great guy who knows his stuff but he does not seem very interested in teaching overall. The course content is similar to that in BIOMG 1350 - just much more in depth and in applied contexts. We were graded on exams and quizzes only, which he usually curved by adding points until it reached a mid-80s average grade.

BIOAP 3300.comment: A great class run by a professor who is very passionate on fish and aquaculture systems! There are 3 exams and a presentation to complete in the class, and they are all pretty easy to do.

BIOAP 4140.comment: This lecture course was okay, covers topics in drug kinetics & dynamics and drugs of various organ systems and disease conditions. Exams are all multiple choice and it is easy to lose points so read questions carefully and study all the notes. Do all the homework as it will help your grade.

BIOEE 1130.comment: This is an incredible class-- really recommend. Jillian is a great instructor and provides a great classroom environment. The watercolor and sketching exercises are fun and feel like a break from other courses. It also serves as an introduction to ornithology and the videos are really interesting. Don't worry about initial art level as long as you like illustration. The class is limited to 16 people so try to get permission to join as soon as it's available.

BIOEE 1610.professor: Alison Power, Anurag Agrawal, Justin St. Juliana
BIOEE 1610.comment: Basic introductory ecology class. Hardcore bio majors who took AP Bio in high school should consider taking BIOMG1350 or BIOG1440 instead as a lot of material was just repetition from stuff you covered by the AP. I thought Agrawal and St. Juliana were great lecturers, but Power was a little boring.
I really enjoyed this class! Probably the best biology class I've taken at Cornell!

Attendance is required. Exams are random and difficult, but they curve up the scores to make up for it. There are no practice exams provided. Definitely do not enroll if you are looking for an easy A.
Most unnecessarily difficult class ever. Material was easy but tests were extremely difficult. Professors were very unhelpful and plain rude.
Overall, workload is very light. Prelims are purposefully and unnecessarily tricky, so watch out.

BIOEE 1780.comment: Professor Drake is really big on the active learning style. You get arbitrarily put into groups of 3-5 based on your discussion section and have to complete team assignments with your team each week. Other than that, the professors really make an effort to make the class interesting and engaging but sometimes just create more work for the students. In general, the class was mostly a bunch of memorization and busy work. You're asked to memorize parts of the Tree of Life for the exam.s

BIOEE 1780.professor: Amy McCune, Brian Lazzaro, Harry Greene, Irby Lovette, Jeremy Searle
BIOEE 1780.comment: You have to show up to this class and there's a decent amount of homework, but if you put in the work you can get an A.  Evolutionary bio isn't my top interest but they did a good job at being engaging and teaching.  The median of this class was an A- when I took it and not curved, but they don't have a normal grading system and don't tell you that (ie a 94 is an A not a 93, and they don't round).

Easy if you've taken AP Bio. As an animal person I thought the tree of life unit was interesting, and as long as you stay on top of it by brain dumping the tree throughout the unit, you'll be fine. Don't love the flipped classroom setup because it was super redundant, I found the readings to be unnecessary. Abby and Robert were all right lecturers, lecture is just rather long. Leslie Babonis' lectures were the most interesting I thought.

BIOEE 1780.professor: Abby Drake, Leslie Babonis, Maren Vitousek
BIOEE 1780.comment: I didn't like the flipped lecture style of this class - made for a ton of work outside of class, although you only have to go to lecture once a week. Working with groups was nice, but I overall found the content and teaching style to be quite boring. Also, there are mandatory field trips that are really inconvenient to get to, because you have to take the bus.

This course flips the traditional class style, so you would learn the content at home and do activities in person. Although watching the lectures at home can be a bit of work, it allows you to go at your own pace and be more flexible with your schedule. The activity portion helped keep the class engaging and allowed you to work with others in your class. I would say that the exams are a lot of memorization, but it is doable if you start a few days earlier.

BIOEE 1781.comment: Somewhat chill class with weekly video  lectures and group assignments and meetings. I think it's one of the easiest ways to get your BIO-AS requirement filled if yo're busy and dont like showing up to physical lecture halls
A lot of work, but virtual format helps a lot. The professor Ash Heim is super nice but the weekly assignments can take an hour or two.

Very structured online class with a full deadline schedule to keep you on track each week. The assignments each week are not extremely hard, just sometimes tedious and time consuming. The class might be easier/harder depending on your teammates, who you have to work with on zoom every week. Sometimes the meetings would go on for 10 minutes or 2 hours depending on how many assignments need to be completed. Exams are all open notes and one gets dropped, which makes this class worth it compared to 1780 in my opinion. Overall, solid class for a biological sciences major requirement
the class was okay,  I was taking it with chem 2070 so it was kinda being neglected but as long as u keep up with the modules its a easy class, the exams were open book.
The workload varies from week to week. You have weekly team meetings that can be very annoying depending on who is in your group.

BIOEE 2740.comment: Easy A, low workload, but cool content and Willy is a legend

Great class! Super easy, all the tests were online and you can answer as many times as you like. The labs were also really cool and you can stay for however long you want.  Very easy to get an A in this class, barely any work outside of class but I still loved it, Bemis is a great lecturer and fun to talk with.

BIOEE 3690.comment: AWESOME class. So many mind boggling fun facts and cool content

BIOEE 3690.professor: Andre Kessler, Anurag Agrawal, Jennifer Thaler, Robert Raguso
BIOEE 3690.comment: This course is super engaging and has very interesting content. I highly recommend it to anyone interested in the natural sciences and ecological systems, especially if you want to go into research in the future. One of the best things about this class is how much there still is to learn so it's a great one for really starting to ask research questions.  I will say, with so many lecturers switching off, it was a little disorganized (lecturers didn't always know what was/wasn't covered before them) and the exams were often a bit vague and difficult to prepare for. The TAs are always very helpful though if you take the time to ask. Almost all of your grade is only based on two exams and one paper, so just be a little careful with that as well. Overall though a light workload but high information content class

BIOG 1440.comment: 1440 in the spring is significantly harder than it is in the fall. The lectures were often confusing and the class is curved really harshly. Overall, you need to attend lecture (since there are clicker questions) and you need to put the work in to get a good grade. The nice thing is that prelims aren't cumulative, and discussion sections generally help your overall score, but not the curve.

BIOG 1440.professor: Cole Gilbert, Darlene Campbell, John Helmann, Linda Pesciotta
BIOG 1440.comment:
The pre-lecture quizzes/videos are super important and will be referenced throughout the course. I only did well because I kept going back to the videos/my notes and reviewing a bit daily so I wasn't too stressed over the prelim. 

THEY REUSE PRELIM QUESTIONS. Do as many practice prelims as possible for this class!

BIOG 1440.professor: Cole Gilbert, John Helmann, Nicolas Buchon
BIOG 1440.comment: The reverse classroom is lot of work but the topics are very interesting

BIOG 1440.professor: Cole Gilbert, Nicolas Buchon, Not Listed
BIOG 1440.comment: The material itself is not too difficult, but it comes quickly and there is a lot of memorization. The lecturers alternate between units, so the quality of teaching fluctuates throughout the course. We were required to watch video lectures before each class (and answer quiz questions on them), which could be very time consuming. My biggest complaint is that they often waited until very soon before class to post the video lectures, so you had very little time to do them. Also, prelims were full of "gotcha" questions that made it hard to get a good score even if you understood the material and studied.

I took the class in the fall with Buchon, Helmann, and Selvaraj. The first few lectures were reviews of high school biology but the course content eventually got more interesting. My main complaint about the class is that we were required to watch online video lectures, which got tedious when I also went to in-person "lecture discussions". The workload is fairly light, and not much is required for labs. There was a generous curve for grading.

BIOG 1445.comment: WOULD NOT RECOMMEND. Labs are graded for a median/mean of around 80. Really hard to get material done in a week. The dissections were cool tho

Very challenging class if you fall behind or procrastinate. Lots of memorization. Labs are hard and graded pretty tough. TAs are pretty nice and professor is amazing. If you procrastinate often or are not very internally motivated, I'd look elsewhere, but the subjects taught are very interesting and if you put in the work you'll do well.
This class has a significant workload, and in order to do well you must be in office hours almost every single day. TAs and prof. Campbell provide alot of help but overall very difficult.

Very test heavy course. You will be expected to cover 18+ pages of objectives over the course of a week and be expected to know every subject in depth. This class would be amazing if there were more time given. The TA's that oral test will be very harsh and will be very rude when grading labs. The only plus is that the Professor cares and will check on you if you are falling behind.  Huge time commitment, and very memorization heavy. Overall don't recommend to anyone.
Great intro class for biology. It covers a broad base and is very interesting. Huge time commitment, and expect to be challenged.

BIOG 1500.comment: This class is really easy if you pay attention to the lectures because they will tell you what you need to know for the lab section. Professor Sarvary is very generous in his grading and work submission policy which grants you up to 2 weeks of submitting an assignment late with no penalty. He also grants you an emergency button to use if needed. This class is pretty simple and is great for those interested in research.

the course is fine. you don't really need to do anything outside of class for it other than one exam (thats a practical and pretty easy as long as you know how to use basic lab gear). i didn't really like how they made us go to lecture once a week because the lectures just weren't that useful. labs also don't take the full 3 hours. the whole class is kinda just meh..
Labs are just long and annoying but not hard

Don't take this class if you don't want to do research, that is really the only purpose of this class. It taught useful lab skills, but was otherwise quite boring. Very little work, almost all of it is done in class. Some TAs will let you out early, but others will make you stay the full 3 hrs.
stupid class, so much busy work but they grade so harshly for no reason even though it is easy

BIOMG 1035.comment: This is definitely one of the harder introductory biology classes, mainly because a lot of content is covered in a short period of time. While I thought the content itself was interesting, the burden of the course load made it difficult to enjoy the class fully. Organizing notes throughout the semester and regularly reviewing content will help immensely for exams. Definitely go to lectures; although the lecture slides are useful, having concepts verbally explained to you by the professor is a lot more helpful.

BIOMG 1290.comment: This class is very very easy and fulfills PBS requirement (for arts and sciences). Professor is great. Material is interesting. Take home prelims and finals only- you can get LOTS of help in office hours.

This class is SOOO interesting. I really feel like I learned a lot, however the exams are tricky sometimes and take a lot of time despite them being take-home. I took this for PBS requirement as a non science-y major and struggled in the beginning, but greatly improved on the second prelim. Beware there are graded iclickers, but they really don't count for that much of your grade. There's like almost no homework and you get to take a free DNA ancestry test.
Pretty great class and slides are very informational. I really appreciate how there is a lot of support for this class!

LOVED this class! Sometimes the lecture material can be boring, but the content of the course is super interesting for people in the medical/science field. Chip is one of the sweetest professors I've had at Cornell and truly cares about the success of his students. The only assignments for this class is a weekly discussion post that takes no more than 20 minutes. Prelims and final are both take-home and you have a week to complete the entire exam. All open ended that can become tedious but TAs offer a LOT of help. Overall SUPER easy A+ class if you put in minimal effort
The class is relatively easy, the workload consists of weekly discussion posts, three take-home prelims, and a group final project. The lectures are also recorded and slides were posted.

BIOMG 1320.comment: Fun and low committment to see some professors research! No homework or anything. Could be nice if you wanted to get into research and directly interact with the professors who lecture after class. Was interesting to learn about research, but also sometimes I had hard time understanding their research without much background in their area. Most will try to explain their research simply, but it just depends on who is lecturing with how in depth it will be.

BIOMG 1350.comment: Lecturers ok to good. Slides  pretty good. Prelims are terrible and open notes. They will catch you on a slight wording difference or switching one word out for another or bringing up something that you dont notice is a never-shown-before extrapolation type question. Hard exams ruined it for me pretty much.

Challenging, yet interesting introductory Biology course. Grading is generous, I think the median is a B+. Professor Graef teaches the first half of the course very well, although the lectures are far too fast paced to take notes on. Professor Tumbar goes similarly quickly but is a little less efficient with her teaching. Homework was very light, but plan to spend hours each week taking notes on the Lectures. Discussions were interesting and easy. Overall, there are a lot of resources if you need help and conceptually the content is not that difficult, although there is a lot to learn.

This class is overall just a grind. Graef is passionate about what he teaches but the class is just so much stuff. Sometimes you'll see something on a prelim that was literally the last slide on a lecture, but that's just the nature of the class. Commitment to the class is very minimal; its the studying outside of class which takes A LOT of time.

This class was a lot more challenging than I anticipated and gave me some trouble at first. The lectures and lecture slides are packed with information and the readings aren’t always that helpful. The subject is kind of complicated and confusing but can be manageable once ingrained into your brain. This class is memorization heavy and requires doing some extra work to make sure you understand the material. I didn’t find the topic that interesting but it was still a pretty good class.

This class will require a lot of studying. Prelims are only 25 multiple choice questions, but there are multiple chapters that they can pull the questions from. I had to study a lot for this class, as there was a lot of information presented in one class lecture. Discussion sections were easy, so they are great ways to boost your grade. There is also mandatory poll questions in class lectures. The professor just teaches what is presented on the slides, and you pretty much just need to know those, I personally never did the assigned readings. Not too bad of a class, but get ready to study.

BIOMG 2800.comment: Barbash is very clear during lectures and works through helpful examples during class.  He's also a great resource during office hours.

I took this course over the summer and really glad I did. The material is really interesting, and lots of the problems feel like puzzle games. It can be tricky, but the textbook is a great source of information that prepares you well for the prelims. Not much homework but a fair amount of reading. Professor Mac is really nice and cares about your learning.

Material is super interesting. Low amount of homework. Tests are some of the hardest I've taken at Cornell, sometimes very unfair. Little to no partial credit awarded so you better study outside of class. Will undergo change now that Dr. Fox is leaving. His excellent lecturing ability made up for what was not an enjoyable class otherwise.

Professor Barbasch is fantastic. The material is fascinating and everything is covered in lecture. It is very important to note that unlike other classes, the exam is barely based on theory and is instead based on problem-solving. You should study all the recommended problems from class.
Go to the weekly problem solving sessions with the undergrad TAs.

BIOMG 2801.comment: The class is currently undergoing some serious change, so the material will change. But the class has changed substantially and is not as difficult as once said to be. Students should have no fear taking the class. The material is much easier than the BioMG 2800 lecture. I recommend

This class is not too difficult especially if you've already taken BIOMG 2800, but regardless, it's still a lot easier than the genetics lectures. I think the concepts are both easier to grasp and more relating to lab procedures, which have explicit answers and are constantly explained within the lectures, and you can just go to OH to get your assignment answers checked over. The labs are mainly working with fruit flies and micropipetting/PCR/sequencing type procedures, and since I haven't done this too often, I found the labs not bad at all and sometimes kind of fun. Grading is slightly weird on the assignments since they are so specific in what they want from the free response answers, so even if you go to office hours, you may lose a few points here and there for the assignments. Finally, the class can be kind of repetitive, and when you start getting closer to the mid/end of the course, a lot of the concepts are just things you've already seen.

The class is very group oriented; weekly assignments and lab is worked on by groups of three. The canvas site is kinda set up weird and hard to navigate since they don't use the module tab. All information needed to complete assignments can be found within the assigned readings. Harder at weeks 4-6 and gets much easier after the midterm.

Took with Goldberg and Blake. Lectures could be very dense and long but critical information at every step. If you go to office hours every week, you'll get an A. Profs reward heavily here for that, especially doing hw and problem sets in OHs. Exam are difficult but curves are fair. Only one out-of-class lab responsibility as opposed to past years.

BIOMG 3300.comment: Very challenging and work-intensive class. But if you're taking this class, you probably love bio, and it doesn't disappoint!
Requires about 4-5 hours a week to complete the objectives, plus time it takes for the unit tests.  The prelims aren't cumulative.  If you've taken BIO 1445, it is similar but definitely easier.

An insane amount of work. I will say I learned a lot and it was a good class to build off of, but it literally took up my entire semester and I easily worked for 25 hours a week. prof (Kevin Siegenthaler) was nice but I barely interacted with him given the structure of the class.

It is challenging, and you need to dedicate a chunk of time per week to pass written and oral unit quizzes. The quiz due dates are assigned, but you will also get some "free extension pass" to delay the deadline. (but don't use them up during the beginning of the semester!!!!) For each quiz you will direct your study based on the objectives. I would recommend making a study guide by answering these objectives using visuals. You need to understand the mechanisms and explain them in your own words. Overall this is self-disciplined class and you will enjoy it if you like to take initiative on understanding material and asking questions, rather than listening to professors.

It is challenging, and you need to dedicate a certain chunk of time weekly to pass a scheduled written and oral quizzes on time. You will get assigned due dates for the quizzes, but you will also get some "free extension pass" to complete your tasks. (but don't use them all up in the beginning!) For the quizzes, you will get a study guide with objectives, and you basically want to make a study guide by answering those objectives. There were non-cumulative prelims taken in the evening as well. Overall, it was very self-disciplined, and you need to direct your study. I would recommend this class if you enjoy studying by taking initiative on your study routine and understanding rather than listening to the professor.

BIOMG 3320.comment: My semester was Marcus Smolka's last semester teaching this course so keep that in mind for this and previous reviews. The only work was the two prelims and a cumulative final. As long as you study for these well you should do fine. The material can be a lot to memorize and understand, but there are resources (office hours, practice exams, extra videos undergrad TAs put out, etc.).
Wonderful class, I recommend for anyone interested in biochemistry. Light load, helpful TAs. Lecture notes are always posted and have all the information needed to do well on prelims.

This class provides an excellent introduction to molecular biology and genetics and offers a very good balance between concepts and details. Although the lecture slides can get fairly involved, the exams places a heavy emphasis on understanding the major cellular processes and analyzing data from biochemistry experiments. There is no outside work other than reviewing lecture material and actually going to class. The professors were excellent at communicating the information and were in general very approachable after lecture or during office hours.
Spring 2019. Just go to lecture and listen. Mostly just details and memorization.
Intense in terms of detail, but really easy exams. You learn a lot if you're willing to work a bit.

BIOMI 1100.comment: I loved this class and would definitely recommend. There is a lot of memorization for the prelims, but all is covered in the lecture notes.

BIOMI 2900.comment: I thought it was fun! Challenging but the professors are understanding!

I took this class in fall 2023 with Doerr and Hefferon. Tobi is a fantastic teacher and person and Kathleen is nice and a decent lecturer as well, although she can be a bit dry at times. The class isn't too difficult but exams definitely require a lot of studying. Discussion sections are super helpful (especially if Tobi teaches your's), so I definitely recommend enrolling in that. Good class overall with great professors.
I love this class and this class made me realize I want to concentrate in microbio for my major!
I love this class and this class made me want to concentrate in microbio for my major !

Professor Buckley is a great lecturer who often gets lost in the sauce when talking about something he is interested in. The class is graded on a straight curve with opportunities for extra credit, so stress is relatively low stress. The applications of microbiology to industry or medicine were interesting.

BIOMI 2911.comment: Professors are great - super fun class and the material is very doable
Rania is a legend. Lab is fantastic and interesting. Very fair and intuitive. Occasional assignments take you off guard. Just prepare ahead of time for labs.

BIOMS 3160.comment: The professor is a great guy who knows his stuff but he does not seem very interested in teaching overall. The course content is similar to that in BIOMG 1350 - just much more in depth and in applied contexts. We were graded on exams and quizzes only, which he usually curved by adding points until it reached a mid-80s average grade.

BIOMS 4140.comment: This lecture course was okay, covers topics in drug kinetics & dynamics and drugs of various organ systems and disease conditions. Exams are all multiple choice and it is easy to lose points so read questions carefully and study all the notes. Do all the homework as it will help your grade.

BIONB 1220.comment: I liked the topics and the professor was very nice. The only downside was that there was a lot of work, but I think this is dependent on professor.
I really enjoyed the topics of the course. The assignments were pretty fair and Caleb gave good feedback. He graded pretty generously and is clearly passionate about the topic.

This was my second FWS, and I only chose it to learn more about neurobiology. The readings were very interesting and the papers were not as long as other FWSs (5 pages each). The professor was also very helpful and gave great feedback before an essay was due.

I took animal communications and it was very interesting! So of the journal articles were hard to comprehend and some were repetitive, but most were very interesting. Not too many writing assignments and he gave very good feedback.

BIONB 2220.comment: I took this course as a CS major with no extensive experience in biology and I took it for 3 credits so there was no work minus weekly MC quizzes and exams. The material was definitely very technical, but going to study groups helped me tremendously. The TAs would review the entire week's lectures and help answer questions about the weekly quizzes. There were also 5-7 different lecturers so it was fun seeing how each one decided to format their lectures/clicker qs/pre-lecture videos.

BIONB 2220.professor: Christiane Linster, Ronald Harris-Warrick, Shelby Dietz
BIONB 2220.comment: Took 4 credit option, Spring 19. Go to lecture and weekly study groups! Overall not a bad class, very interesting material.

This course is more challenging that it seems. Taken in spring 2018, the first prelim was filled with the most challenging material and therefore had the lowest mean. However, the course gets gradually easier just based on the subject matter, in that topics covered later are more interesting and generally easier to grasp. Specific professors are better than others; the best being Ron Harris-Warrick, Jesse Goldberg, and Melissa Warden. Watch the pre-lecture videos and complete pre-lecture assignments so that you are prepared for class, otherwise lecture will be confusing. iClicker questions are not graded for correctness, but just completion, so it pays to go to class even if you may not be particularly prepared. Lecture audio is recorded, which is a great way to fix up notes and study for exams. Weekly quizzes can be quite challenging, but going to study groups can help with these. Going to study groups also helps to remain up-to-date on information covered, as falling behind can be hard to come back from. I was enrolled in the 4-credit course that included a weekly discussion, which was sometimes annoying but worth the work, because prelims and the final exam are worth less percent of the final grade.

BIONB 3690.comment: AWESOME class. So many mind boggling fun facts and cool content

BIONB 3690.professor: Andre Kessler, Anurag Agrawal, Jennifer Thaler, Robert Raguso
BIONB 3690.comment: This course is super engaging and has very interesting content. I highly recommend it to anyone interested in the natural sciences and ecological systems, especially if you want to go into research in the future. One of the best things about this class is how much there still is to learn so it's a great one for really starting to ask research questions.  I will say, with so many lecturers switching off, it was a little disorganized (lecturers didn't always know what was/wasn't covered before them) and the exams were often a bit vague and difficult to prepare for. The TAs are always very helpful though if you take the time to ask. Almost all of your grade is only based on two exams and one paper, so just be a little careful with that as well. Overall though a light workload but high information content class

BIONB 4140.comment: This lecture course was okay, covers topics in drug kinetics & dynamics and drugs of various organ systems and disease conditions. Exams are all multiple choice and it is easy to lose points so read questions carefully and study all the notes. Do all the homework as it will help your grade.

BIONB 4910.comment: Bruce is really nice and very understanding. The labs are extremely engaging and the topics are super interesting! There are a lot of lab reports, about once every other week but they are done with your group (2 or 3 people)

BME 3110.comment: Really enjoyed the class. First HW is hard but after that everything is much easier

BME 3210.comment: Awesome professor, great class if trying to gain knowledge on analytical techniques, opportunity to get certified on the equipment as well through Cornell

BME 4910.comment: Bruce is really nice and very understanding. The labs are extremely engaging and the topics are super interesting! There are a lot of lab reports, about once every other week but they are done with your group (2 or 3 people)

BSOC 2061.comment: I really enjoyed this class. The professor made the class very entertaining. I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to fulfill a diversity credit.

BSOC 2201.comment: Richard Stedman is honestly the best lecturer i've had so far (in CALS), really prepared for lectures, and makes class interesting. He doesn't have slides so taking notes is a must (or just look at other ppl's quizlets), he usually has a exam review sheet and all possible concepts tested will be on it. Fairly easy but the exams focus alot on details so hard to get high points.

I really loved this class! You could do the readings if you want/ are interested, but will do well in the class even if you only have time to attend lecture. Stedman is super passionate and a great lecturer. Highly recommend.

I loved this class! Richard Stedman is a great professor and genuinely enjoys the curriculum he teaches. Prelims are pretty easy and you can probably do well if you just take good lecture notes, but the readings really help to enrich your learning experience, and are good practice if you're not used to reading a lot for classes, so if you're really interested and have the time, I'd recommend doing them.

BSOC 2350.comment: A lot of readings, can definitely be a bunch of work most times, but the professor is very kind and class is interesting. There are 4 essays throughout the semester that are ~4 pages long, but grading is not too bad. Overall, I enjoyed this class. Learned a lot about medical themes, disability, doctors - was not a premed major but this class is also apparently helpful for premeds to better understand a doctor and sick person's perspectives

BSOC 2468.comment: The whole class was focused on her project in Tanzania, so we barely learned much else. There was no through line between readings, weird grading policies, and the essays had nothing to do with what we were learning in class. Lectures were mostly just prof going on and on and getting so theoretical that it just wasn't engaging. Grade depends completely on ur TA. Our final project was a weird structure and expectations were extremely unclear. Class has a lot of potential and some of the readings were very interesting but it's butchered it in my opinion.

I took this class with professor Langwick. The material is super interesting and I would definitely recommend it to future doctors to learn more about how the role of medicine impacts society and culture. It is a good introduction to medical anthropology. However, this class is a lot of work. There were no prelims but all essays and readings every week. Professor Langwick doesn't allow laptops and she makes you print out the reading for every class and it is around 10 pages. It was bad for the environment. Also there are pop quizzes for the readings. I took it spring 2020 so the second half was impacted by COVID and there was a lot less work.
Langwick was really nice but the class was annoying and had unnecessary busywork. I felt like I learned nothing. She has lenient grading policies and somehow got an A+.

I really like this class. Prof. Hodzic is really interesting and leads very open and insightful discussions in class. There were no prelims in the class which was nice but instead, there were two medium-length essays and one final research paper.  TAs are very helpful and there is plenty of time to do the papers so if you stay on top of it it's not very hard to manage. Readings can be a lot at times but skimming through them usually does the trick and you learn a lot in lecture about each reading.

BSOC 3011.comment: The readings are quite long (and boring at times). But the class itself is not very difficult, graded on 3 papers to complete and attendance/participation.

Prof Tamarkin actually cares about his students and makes sure not to overload the class with work. Most of the readings were really interesting but some could definitely get a bit dry at times. We had readings before every class and then 3 essay based exams.
Total snoozefest but not hard. Never did any of the readings, got consistently good grades regardless. The entire curriculum is very vague and uninteresting

BTRY 3020.comment: The professor was boring but overall I learned a lot of statistics from the class. I thought that the assignments and quizzes were helpful in learning the material.

Jermey is a boring lecturer but I just watched his recorded lectures. He doesn't give out any practice prelims so the only prep material you get are the lectures and quizzes. Overall, it was a dry class but I learned a lot of R and linear regression.

If you're coming from BTRY 3010, the format of the class is the exact same, except the labs are much harder.  Prelims and final are cumulative, open note but only allowed his notes + your own annotations. Weighting is very fair but still requires you to do pretty well across the board. Overall, a dry lecturer and the material isn't very interesting either. Didn't go to lectures and just watched videos instead. Don't take this class if it isn't for a requirement.

Extremely dry lectures, badly taught, not curved, low median, overall really disliked the class. The only good aspects were that the lectures are recorded and my TA was helpful. If you don't have to take the class, don't.

Extremely dry lectures, badly taught, made me hate the content, not curved, low median, overall disliked the class. The only good aspects were that the lectures are recorded and my TA was helpful. If you don't have to take it, don't.

BTRY 3080.comment: I really liked the material, but Bunea has some trouble with pacing the class. She goes over introductory probability for a long time and then once the harder material hits she goes pretty fast. She's great at explaining things in office hours (she's an awesome person!), but TA discussion sections were pointless, only about 6 of us went each week and did not gain much. Final exam was worth 45% of our grade and was not cumulative, so all of the material that she rushed through in the last 2 weeks makes a huge impact on your grade.

Took it with Florentina Bunea. Handwriting is really hard to read and the material is very drab. However, Bunea definitely cares about her students and the tests are pretty easy. Watch out for Prelim 2 though, it's the hardest material. The material was basically the same as ENGRD 2700 without hypothesis testing.
Content was easy to follow and prelims were straightforward

Probably the easiest stats class you can take at Cornell for the probability requirement. There were 3 prelims in class and like 4-5 homeworks from the textbook but you could easily do them the night of.
simple probability course, 6 homeworks overall and 3 in class prelims- first half of the class was common stats knowledge that was in AP Stats.

CAPS 1622.comment: prof was really nice. discussion sections were easy and  really helpful. every lecture was pretty interesting. reading was long sometimes but not terrible. made the final exam optional for our class which was really nice :)

Great class! The lectures are very interesting as the reading material, although it can be a lot at times. A lot of interesting topics that are relevant today are discussed and the workload is very light.

Definitely interesting history class. The readings can be extensive but as long as you do not wait until the last minute they are doable. The professor knows what she is talking about, which makes the course material more compelling. Overall a decent introduction to Japanese history.

CEE 1130.comment: I took this class with Greeshma Gadikota and Damian Heibling. Professor Gadikota taught the first half of the semester and Heibling taught the second. The weekly problem sets aren't too difficult especially if you go to office hours. Additionally, we had large group projects that weren't bad and our prelims had practice prelims that were super similar. We did transition online (spring 2020) and the professors were incredibly accommodating. I do have to say as some super into sustainability, it's more of the science behind it rather than "trendier" side of sustainability.

Weekly problem sets, pretty basic content and difficulty (refer to lecture slides). One of the easier ENGRIs, but meets three times a week at 10am (Spring 2020) so not the most appealing. Took with Greeshma Gadikota and Damian Heibling

Weekly problem sets and a group paper/report type of project every unit. Exams are quite simple and straightforward, and material is not  difficult. Group projects can be a pain but overall it is an easy and somewhat interesting ENGRI!

CEE 3090.comment: The Steel Bridge Team is highly engaging and helps the team members no matter inexperienced or experienced to get as much hands-on work as possible!

CEE 3200.comment: This class is a lot of work and a lot of MATLAB but it was  fun for me. I enjoyed actually applying the stuff we learned in class to real world problems that engineers will have to solve.

Professor Cowen has been really helpful in this class and has a good handle on the material.  The problem sets and exams were pretty fair. I can see how the material presented in this class would be helpful down  the line in future career/classes.

CEE 3230.comment: The last half of this course really picked up and got very difficult. The professor's and TA's office hours were not super helpful and the homeworks were a pain to complete (and they were not very helpful for learning).

CEE 3510.comment: This class is so disorganized it really gets in the way of learning. That being said Prof. Richardson is going to completely revamp the class and change the curriculum starting Fall 2019, that being said this semester was a complete disaster. From changing deadlines to incorrect answers on the answer keys. Generally the slides were disorganized, overcrowded, and clearly hadn't been updated in years. Hopefully Prof Richardson is able to fix this class in the future because right now its horrible.

This class was very helpful and interesting. There was a lot of information about wastewater and water treatment. The exams were fair and very similar to practice exams provided by the professor. Going to lecture is important. The assignments were also interesting and were done in groups.

CEE 3610.comment: The class is very interesting and professor is super nice in helping everyone to learn about the topic and concepts associated with it

Professor is very knowledgable and accessible.  The structure and flipped classroom aspect really helped with learning. I really enjoyed his class, and I think all the assignments and exams were very fair.

Dr. Vanek is very knowledgeable in transportation and he gives a great introduction to all parts of transportation engineering. His lectures may be a bit boring and he takes a lot of time during workshops to pause to let you do the work on your own. The homework is 7 homework psets that are similar to the workshop problems during lectures, and prelims and final are all take home.

Very enthusiastic and accommodating professor. Workload is pretty light. He recorded lectures to watch at home and does review/exercises during class, but to be honest I didn't watch most of the videos and did fine.

CEE 5900.comment: A joke class. Worst class I've ever taken at Cornell. Lots of busy work, outdated and absolutely useless material. Mandatory attendance at 8 am with iClickers. Daily journal-like quiz including weekends. Just took it for the 4 credits. A huge waste of time.
From a non graduate student, this class seems helpful because we get to work on an actual project with other students. However, the material seems like common sense. Workload is a lot of busy work.
I took this course in Spring semester. The course is absurd and not helpful in any sense, based on my industry experience.

CEE 6910.comment: A joke class. Worst class I've ever taken at Cornell. Lots of busy work, outdated and absolutely useless material. Mandatory attendance at 8 am with iClickers. Daily journal-like quiz including weekends. Just took it for the 4 credits. A huge waste of time.
From a non graduate student, this class seems helpful because we get to work on an actual project with other students. However, the material seems like common sense. Workload is a lot of busy work.
I took this course in Spring semester. The course is absurd and not helpful in any sense, based on my industry experience.

CHEM 1008.comment: You just have to complete the notes page every week and attend problem-solving but the questions are very helpful for building up my knowledge in Chem 2080. In order to pass the course, 8 of each is usually required. Really enjoyed the class and professor as he is patient in explaining concepts.

CHEM 1058.comment: Incredibly helpful with the parent course, CHEM 3580. Taken in Spring 2018, I genuinely could not have done as well as I did in 3580 without this course. Jane Walcott is the professor, and she genuinely cares so much about the success of her students.

CHEM 1570.comment: Despite what people may think of her in CHEM 2080 lab, Dr. Kinsland is a great lecturer, especially for this class. The name baby orgo is very fitting for this class, as there is not a lot of work, the content is not incredibly complicated (though you still need to memorize some reactions and other things), and the pressure in this class is not very high.

Dr. Kinsland is nice and a passionate professor. She was super helpful during office hours. Orgo is orgo, so naturally, it is hard, but if you utilize all of the resources available it's doable. Dr. Kinslands would sometimes go on tangents instead of elaborating on topics, which was the only thing that frustrated me.

Overall, I had a fine time in this class. I started out really enjoying it (even though chemistry is not really my subject), but after the first prelim was super lost and stayed that way for the most part until the end of the semester. Dr. Kinsland is great, and the lectures are relatively fun even though the material can be confusing. I feel lucky to have had her as a professor. Still, this class was really hard, and even though it's "baby" orgo, there's a lot of difficult material to digest. Definitely didn't feel baby all the time.
Professor Kinsland is an awesome professor who makes lectures engaging. Exams are worth a lot but they are fair. They are pretty similar to the practice problems and exams she provides.

Kinsland is an amazing lecturer and I really enjoyed her class. She presents the material very well, makes lots of connections, and puts a lot of effort into helping students. Make sure to do the practice exams!

CHEM 2070.comment: I hated this class. I had very minimal background in chemistry because my HS chem dept. was awful, and really just struggled in this class. Definitely take advantage of the support classes. Just know that if you aren't good at chemistry, this class will consume your life. At the same time, you will have classmates who are breezing through this course because they took AP Chem. Stay strong, pre-meds.
I loved CHEM 2070. Dr. Lee is tough, but he's a very caring professor. However, he does make you work for it. It's nice though, because in the end, you feel like you truly earned the grade you got.
This class was horrible.  Very hard and so much work with all of the pre-lecture, post-lecture, flipped class and peer led review sessions.
Very hard class. Averages were usually in 50s and curved to a B. Need to be on top of work as it piles on for tests.

2070 overall is just a grind but it was a decent time. The class is very hard if you have no chemistry experience but that just comes with the class. Prepare to spend a lot of time outside of class understanding concepts. Lancaster himself is a nice guy and is clearly passionate about what he does. Cracks some fun jokes in lecture but is a grind

CHEM 2080.comment: Professor Hines is often condescending. She makes the group quizzes incredibly difficult. Labs can be graded arbitrarily. Don't take if you want a class with not much outside work as there are lots of things which must be completed outside of class.

Hines is great at explaining simple concepts in lecture. The problem with this class is that lecture is only the foundation for what you're expected to know. Labs and group quizzes can sometimes only feel loosely connected to topics that you talk about in class. Who you're paired with for group quizzes can make or break the class, so don't be afraid to speak up if you're with people who aren't pulling their weight. Prelims are fairly straightforward and usually resemble the practice posted. Expect to put in a lot of time outside of class.

Robert DiStasio is a decent lecturer and explains concepts pretty well. Unfortunately, his exams are very difficult and little prep work is offered. The exam questions are often pretty different from the discussion set problems, and definitely unlike the HW problems. One great thing is that the lectures are all recorded and posted on canvas within a day or two, which is very helpful.

Labs are probably the worst part of this class. They are generally very long, and very repetitive. Lab TAs seem a bit out of tune with each other, often giving different advice and different answers to the same questions. 

Discussions aren't all that helpful, just a TA going over discussion set problems that are already posted on canvas with answer keys. 

The best part about this class is that the final isn't cumulative, it's a third prelim. Professor DiStasio offers "mini prelims" during this time slot as well, which are smaller versions of the first two prelims (of your choice) that you can try to get a better grade with. 

Compared to 2070, I'd say the workload is slightly less, and the class overall is slightly less intense, but the difficulty is about the same.

Professor DiStasio teaches the content well,  and I like how he records all his lectures. However, he's a bit behind schedule a lot of the time, and this makes the labs a bit difficult to grasp (we do an experiment on a concept we barely learned about). We don't get many practice problems for the prelims either.
For the lab portion, it is pretty difficult at first because a clear procedure is not given. Also, the TAs would sometimes have different answers for lab questions/procedures, so you need to ask multiple TAs for help.

Quite possibly one of the worst classes I've taken here. I believe with Professor DiStasio it was much better than before, as he is quite good at explaining concepts and seems like a nice person overall, but there was barely any practice offered in preparation for the much more difficult exams. The worst part about the class is the labs, as the TAs seem like they do not communicate with each other, and my TA would recommend one procedure but another TA at OH would tell me I approached it completely wrong.

CHEM 2090.comment: Marohn is a nice guy who's really passionate about chemistry but he's not a great professor. I learned more from the homework problems than I did from any of his lectures. He had technical difficulties every day, so lectures always started late. I know COVID is making things difficult, but every day? Come on, man. I can only think of one lecture that he started and ended on time. Also, since he started lectures late and he has a tendency to ramble, it wasn't uncommon for lectures to last 30 minutes past the official end of class. Also, I stated above that the homework was the most helpful for me but my lord it was awful. There was way too much work assigned and the due dates were all over the place. He even assigned 56 new practice problems just four days before the start of Finals. Not cool :(

Prof. Chen's handwriting and notes were always scattered and he never posted them online, so essentially lectures were required. He never stopped once during lecture to ask for questions and the lectures felt very dry. This class was mainly just busy work for me.

I took this class as a 2nd semester senior after putting it off for 4 years. I did not take any Chem prior and was scared of this class destroying me, but ended up with an A+.

I had a heavy semester, and this class took up the bulk of my time. I did not attend lectures although they were enjoyable simply due to lack of time. Learning Analytics makes up 5% of the final grade so that is a tradeoff.

The problem sets take a long time because you have to teach yourself how to do everything. There are basically no office hours, no Ed. Redoing the problem sets and working through the released exam questions was enough to get the highest score on both prelims. If you learn how to do the questions, you can get ~100%, it's just a matter of how much time you have to study. 

My biggest complaint is that the professor often released practice exams/solutions very late, and they were filled with errors. I was able to catch some of the errors, but I probably missed many more. Hard to learn when you aren't given correct solutions. Also, organization was poor. Sometimes homeworks were canceled or extensions were given AFTER the deadline had passed. 

The labs were honestly fun! You get to work with a partner and it rarely if ever takes the whole 3 hours.

I recommended the MIT principles of chemical science course as well as reading the textbook. The material and kinds of questions are honestly fun, the workload is just constant if you want to keep up, and much of it had to be self taught. Overall, I'll miss CHEM 2090 a little bit.

Professor Musser wasn't an engaging professor and struggled to properly teach his students the material, which was already complex (as someone who didn't have any prior chemistry knowledge). After the first prelim's score distribution was... concerning, he changed the second prelim and final to multiple choice. Nevertheless, the score distributions didn't change and students stopped showing up to lectures. The content is still somewhat interesting, but I wouldn't recommend this class/professor (it's usually taken as a requirement either way).

I had Musser, lectures were fine. Lab grading is intentionally antagonistic. Got about an 88% every week with random deductions made on different parts. Labs are graded significantly after you do them, so you can't correct your lab for the next time. Even got deductions for not observing certain spectra peaks (how was I supposed to do that if they weren't there?). Course does not use Ed discussion which means you have to email to ask any questions at all. As a senior taking the course, this is a poor excuse of a Cornell class and much worse run than other large classes I've taken.

CHEM 2510.comment: I did not like how there was no unified grading schema for the lab reports. Although there was a rubric that was used, the interpretation of the criteria between TAs seemed to vary. The lecture notes did mention topics covered in the course, but the slides themselves overall did not have much words on them.

Either way this class is going to suck, but its a requirement for most people so you just have to deal with it. Lecture is a bit boring and seems pointless until you're studying for the prelims but they're recorded so you can go back and watch them. The prelims are challenging and hard to get a hold of because its testing you on lab concepts. The labs themselves are all kind of repetitive and the actual yields of your products don't matter like they did in gen chem labs because you can cite other students' data to use in your report. The reports are not as challenging as gen chem but they still suck. The key to this class is your TA. Clotide was the best TA and offered so much help and support!

Cynthia is a decent lecturer, she's clear and concise. However, halfway through the semester, she runs out of lecture material and goes beyond lab material which is kind of pointless but not a big deal. Labs are long, they normally take the full 3 hours. The lab reports can be pretty time-consuming as well. Grades (aside from exam grades) always took quite a long time to come out (sometimes a month+ for a lab report grade). The exams were fair but challenging. Shoutout to TA Jacob, he definitely made labs run much smoother than they could have.

Cynthia changed the course by eliminating a few labs and the second lab practical so that it felt more like a two credit course. Labs generally take 2-3 hours to complete, but there are several people who leave early. Both the professor and the TAs were very helpful when I went to office hours for help on the lab reports or problem sets. There were 4 problem sets throughout the semester and they took around 30-40 minutes to complete. Most of the questions could be answered by looking at the lecture notes or Chemistry Libretexts. I felt that performing experiments in Chem 2510 reinforced my understanding of organic chemistry (especially the more complicated reaction mechanisms) in a way that the lectures did not. I wish I had taken this course in conjunction with CHEM 3580.

CHEM 2900.comment: Lorey is an absolute sweetheart. I took this class when the pandemic first affected classes, and despite it being a lab class he managed the transition online really well, and structured it in a way that those who try could get high grades. Labs were easy to follow and lab reports were manageable. It was a nice refresher after the nightmare that was Orgo lab or boring Gen Chem labs.

CHEM 3030.comment: David Zax makes the course unnecessarily confusing through the use of excessively long handouts that contain absolutely no information of any value. The labs are largely meaningless and the vacuum lines do not work, so it is not even possible to synthesize some of the compounds in a pure state, especially deuterated compounds because everything is full of water vapor.  I would not recommend this miserable experience to anyone.

CHEM 3570.comment: This class was very challenging and required a lot of time outside of class to understand the material. I am not very chem-inclined so it took a lot of extra practice for me. HIGHLY recommend the LSC learning strategies center and the support class for extra help and material to practice with.
Fun and rigorous class definitely very intricate and interesting!

Professors were Coates and Lambert. Lectures were fast-paced and not in much depth. prelim difficulty was inconsistent because one prof made it too easy, one made it too difficult. Overall the course is not terrible but requires a lot of practice outside of class to get decent grades.

Let's start with Professor Coates. He taught the first half of the course. His lectures were decent, not too dry. The course content wasn't too difficult, and his prelims were fair and not too challenging. Then came the second half of the course with Professor Lambert. I'm honestly not sure if Lambert is just a terrible lecturer or the content at this point became extremely overwhelming, or both. Either way, once Lambert came in, the course became extremely difficult. His lectures felt a little unorganized, and his prelim was awful (48/100 average). He made up for it with an easier final, however. Both professors do seem to care about their students. I'd definitely recommend reading the textbook and taking notes while doing so, that is my one regret with this course. Taking lecture notes isn't enough to do well for most. Good luck soldiers.

CHEM 3580.comment: Ruttledge and Aye split the semester when I took this class.  I can tell Ruttledge cares and knows a lot about organic chemistry, but his lectures are incredibly disorganized and I found that trying to look at my notes after the fact was completely useless.  Aye was more organized with her lectures, but her accent is difficult to understand.  I would say both gave unnecessarily difficult exams and just stressed students out more than actually teaching them.

Fores and Abbasov were great teachers and offered extra credit opportunities which was nice for a core science class. Class was similar to 3570 in terms of workload and difficulty. Weekly achieve homework was the only outside work for the class. Highly suggest taking Brandon's winter prep course before 3580 because it covers all of the material for Prelim 1.

I took this class with Fors and Abbasov. As expected, incredibly difficult course. There is an unreasonable amount of memorization and understanding required, which is why most of the tests avg around a 60.  Final grade is curved so it all works out I suppose, but an extremely stressful and difficult course overall.
The lecture was essentially just copying notes down. Lecturer left no time for students to consume the material at all. Worse class, mediocre professor, TAs are great

I took this with Bruce Ganem who made the class very difficult. He did not provide a lot of resources or practice problems and the tests were unfair. We also had these weird Sapling quizzes that were unproctored and worth way more of our grade than they should have been.

CHEM 3590.comment: Was very organized in lecture. exams were fairly difficult however. Problem sets were not too long, although sometimes tedious.

CHEM 4100.comment: Would not recommend to anyone. Save yourself, he just took his graduate level material and changed the course number. He gets mad for students asking questions about month long material that he covers in 30 minutes. If you have to take it, graduate a year later and take it with another professor. Best of luck :)

CHIN 1102.comment: Very similar to CHIN 1101. Took this class half in person, then half online with covid. The covid portion was horrible; not that it was hard, but the main benefit of this class is being able to directly interact with peers and TAs. With zoom, only one person can talk at once and I feel like I didn't learn anything when we went online.
This is pretty much exactly the same as CHIN 1101, just a continuation. Lots of work, but the material is really helpful.

CHIN 1110.comment: Great class to take if you are a native chinese speaker, but the essays were a lot of work. The class itself was pretty chill though.

Very similar to CHIN 1110. New lesson every week, presentations from the class every Wed, quiz Friday. Rui Laoshi is a pretty fair teacher though. It's a decent amount of work with the 400 character journals every week so you just have to figure out a consistent schedule to do Chinese. You learn Chinese pretty well though.

Course probably different from before, but you use a textbook and go through the whole volume 2 of advanced beginners of Chinese. Quiz weekly on each chapter of the book, some dialogues, 2 exams, and a final project, and 2 oral presentations. Professor is very nice and easy to reach outside of class!

Took this Spring 2022. I speak another dialect and barely know Mandarin, but I was still placed in this class. I went in wanting to transfer out to  beginner's Chinese because I only understood about 50$ of what everyone was saying. There's a bit of variation in how fluent everyone in this class - some people were basically fluent and (in my opinion) should've been in the intermediate class, while others were more like me. Professor Liu is super nice and understanding and since it's such a small class, we all get to know each other pretty well. 

Workload - Meet 3x a week and we have a textbook that we follow, so every week we focus on a different lesson. Lots of memorization (about 50-70 terms to memorize by Friday - day of the quiz). You're expected to learn the vocab by yourself. Every week is basically like this: Mondays, submit recording of the lesson text before class and come to class ready to talk about the text. Wednesdays, 2-3 people doing their oral presentations & some grammar lessons. Fridays, quiz and go over textbook questions. Overall, if you put in the effort then you'll get at least a B+.

Pretty difficult if you are not a super fluent heritage speaker at home. A big jump from 1109. Weekly journal entries and a lot of quizzes and memorization. A really good way to improve on your Mandarin though, since you are being thrown into it. A lot of time required, but still pretty fun and worth it.

CHIN 2202.comment: CHIN 2202 isn't really different from CHIN 2201 so you should be used to the format/style of the class. Again, professor goes over material quickly but there are less quizzes and oral tests during the semester.

CHIN 2210.comment: As someone who speaks a dialect and does not actually speak mandarin at home, this class was a lot of work, but definitely pretty fun. I spent maybe 6 hours a week outside of classes reading and doing homework, but I know some others in my class who thought that the class was super easy and chill!  I received a lot of support and help when I failed to understand how to use more complex vocabulary, and my class size was really small (5 people). She invited both sections of the class to her place for barbecue after and I felt that she genuinely cared about her students and their well-being!

One of the most challenging classes I have taken and the workload was greater than all of my other classes combined. The professor means well and wants to see you improve, but may come off as strict. There are high expectations in terms of making your writing "more formal" and "at a higher level" with little guidance. You are graded on "improvement" as well so be sure to go to office hours if you want to receive a good grade.

CHIN 4428.comment:
There was a lot of expectations of you being able to understand the cultural norms. The topics were pretty advanced such as short stories, government, and economics.

There were weekly quizzes and exams very frequently. I struggled with writing and memorizing advanced characters.

CLASS 1531.comment: I took this class with Daniel B. Gallagher and it was pretty chill class. If you needed an extension he was more than willing to grant you one. It did get very awkward at times because no one would participate. Also, there was a week (that sadly was also prelim wee) which we had 3 different 6 page essays due with 2 day notices. they were slightly related with each other and graded on completion (like most of his essays). They were also just an exercise to get you to write more but it was incredibly stressful. Especially with such short notice. I do have to warn that if you don't like greek mythology and I mean REAL greek mythology NOT PERCY JACKSON, take this class. If not, it can be really draining. But, I ended up with an A despite writing some trash essays.

A little more work with Daniel Gallagher in terms of essays and quality of work that he expects. Great professor, used to be a papal latinist, and you could tell he has a strong grasp with the content. As long as he sees improvement, you should be able to do well.

I took this class with Jonathan Warner. Class was pretty boring but he was generous with grading. Lots of reading to do beforehand, but the writing assignments were straight forward and not too difficult.

CLASS 1699.comment: Not as interesting at the course description made it out to be. Professor is great, but I found myself losing focus a lot of the time because the lectures were boring, but maybe linguistics just isn't my thing. As for homework/exams, we only had 3 homeworks and 2 exams throughout the semester, so super light work.

CLASS 2689.comment: Overall, this class was a decent experience. The lectures were a bit dry and it was difficult to remember all of the information, but it was interesting to learn more about the historical figures that I had heard about in high school. The instructors were very fair. Would recommend to people interested in the subject.

COGST 2150.comment: The class is taught by a passionate professor but it is not good. As a psych major, this class covered more of a linguistic perspective which I did not enjoy. The TAs grading is pretty hard and usually, they could not help you with questions. I do not consider it an easy A
Really interesting class, especially if you put in effort to learn. Practically no work at all too, except studying for the prelims. Professor is very good too.

A great introduction to psycholinguistics with a great lecturer. Professor Christiansen makes each class easy to digest, and his presentation of each topic is intriguing and humorous at times. For my class, he did not assign homework and only had three prelims and a final essay, which were all writing-based. As long as you attend lecture and review the content of each lecture before the prelim, it is not hard to get a good grade. The prelims are not cumulative, and there is also an extra credit option. Definitely would recommend to anyone looking for a liberal studies class that is easy and interesting.
even though it wasn't my interest area exactly, the professor made this class' content accessible and fun to learn. I'd recommend this class to anyone!

COGST 3140.comment: This is potentially the weirdest class I've ever taken at Cornell. Professor Edelman wrote the textbook that you have to buy, then quoted himself in the lecture slides that he wrote as if he didn't write the textbook. This entire discipline seemed like something that he made up himself so he could teach a class about it and hear himself talk. Your entire grade in the class is 3 exams that are legit 5 multiple choice questions and 2 short answers. I got a 75 on one of the exams I studied hard for and a 98 on one of the exams where I legitimately made everything up. This class legit could be an easy A or an easy D it's unpredictable. Don't go to lecture because it is painfully boring to sit through and do the readings before the exam and hope for the best. But also just don't take this class.

I thought the premise of the course would be interesting, but I think the lectures tended to be quite lengthy and slides contained a lot of content. It's clear the Professor is knowledgeable, but it's a lot of information at once. We just had weekly mini-essays and annotations on Perusal that were not very hard.

Professor Edelman really changed up the structure of the class in response to virtual class and he seems to care about his students. A virtual semester consists of small weekly readings with annotations on Perusall and a weekly micro essay about the topic of the week with a max of 500 words. Topics are really interesting and light work kept me motivated, but I could see how a semester with prelims and finals could make the content seem tedious.

COGST 3420.comment: One of my favorite classes this semester! We get to learn about a lot of interesting topics and watch cool videos in class. Only workload is for prelims. I definitely would recommend this class to others.
This is a great course! Interesting material, not too much work. Plus it counts as an engineering tech elective.

Great class led by a great professor (David Field). Lectures are really interesting, full of in-class demos and videos. There's two prelims and one final -- and for all of these, he'll give you a question bank out of which questions will be picked. There's a few (around 5-6) easy in-class quizzes at random points, so it's good to attend class though not crucial. You can get by without going to class, but I'd highly recommend going to class because it's very interesting!

A very interesting class full of demos, videos and examples for pretty much every topic we cover! The professor is super nice, very knowledgeable and has tons of interesting, relevant facts to share. There is not much workload like no assignments just the exams and sometimes in-class quizzes. The content is not difficult to understand. Highly recommend this course!

Loved this class!  Very interesting material (explaining cool optical illusions), friendly professor, and only work is the 2 prelims and the final.  I took it during covid so exams were online which likely made them easier, but even without that I think it would be a pretty low effort and fun class.

COGST 4240.comment: Took with Mats Rooth in Spring 2018. Mats is a nice guy, but a bad lecturer. Lectures are hard to follow and he likes to ramble, and will occasionally lose his train of thought. However, the slides are also hard to understand, and there are no lecture notes (nor does he really follow the textbook), so you have to go to lecture. The class is quite disorganized, and homework/prelim grades took forever to be released. The class also seems to be focused much more on teaching how to use specific software tools to create/analyze linguistic models, rather than the theory behind how such software tools work (which is what I was more interested in). On the plus side though, he is rather lenient in giving final grades, so I still ended up with a B+ even though I kinda gave up on the class 2/3 through.

I took this with Mats Rooths during covid. Every lecture it felt like the professor was winging it as he went. He was always late to class (5-10 mins). Homework felt all over the place. Final project was also sort of ambiguous. No exams just projects. Grading was not too bad though. The class is very disorganized. This class is very linguistics focused too and you use software mostly to do linguistics stuff EX: foma. The hard part is coming up with grammar etc...

I took the class with Professor Marten van Schijndel (not the one listed above). More than half the psets (which were actually coding projects except for a few written questions) took more than 20 hours, although the short ones took a range of 1 to 5 hours. There were 7 psets total.  This is a predominantly CS class although it's cross-listed in LING and COGST. The lectures were interesting, but the projects (psets) were extremely frustrating, and the professor and the TA gave out obscure answers when asking for help.  I'm also not sure how much I learned from the projects. I ended up with a good grade, which is based on the projects and some participation, but wouldn't have taken it if I had to choose again.  Definitely know a friend you can discuss with or get to know someone if you take the class.

COGST 4740.comment: This class is highly disorganized, and it doesn't seem like the professor has a major hand on the course logistics. The projects are difficult not because of the content but because of the ambiguity in the description and the grading schema. The lectures are based off the textbook and are somehow made more confusing. You're better off reading the textbook than going to lecture. The grades and projects are never released on time, yet they still expect the students to somehow meet the deadline.

I came into the class with high expectations for NLP but this class really disappointed me by the way it's taught and kind of killed some of my interest of the subject. The lectures didn't prepare me for the projects at all. We went through algorithms in class but nothing about the implementation conventions. If you are not familiar with PyTorch and all those NLP packages, it will be a huge pain to search the documentation and often I didn't even know where to start because no one tells me what to look at. Thus, the projects are super time-consuming. I spent much more time on this class than on 3410 which is known for its heavy workload. Also, idk if it's bc the class is in the morning, the lecture is super dry and dead, the professor and the PhD lecturer really lack some enthusiasm in teaching and thus made the material much less engaging than it should have been.

I hated this class. The lectures are extremely boring and never talk about the actual code. And they expect you to code an entire neural network. My friends and I were lost the entire time, I've never been so confused in a class.

I took this class because I want to learn about NLP, but was thoroughly disappointed on the course structure, or more accurately speaking, the lack of structure. CS 4740 was one of the classes that fit my schedule for Fall 2020 where I took this class online. Lectures were decent, but could be better, there was a technical microphone issue where the professor's audio was practically inaudible and students were not able to hear clearly. Project guidelines were long, open-ended, overly wordy, and required students to write tedious code that were not directly related to class material.

I really regret taking this class over my other options. Prof. Cardie's lectures are almost entirely based on Jurafsky's textbook. The examples and figures in her slides are straight from that textbook, and thus you can skip most of the lectures if you just do the reading. Honestly, I think reading the textbook is the more efficient way to learn the materials since her lectures are poorly organized. She spends a lot of time explaining linguistics concepts but not enough time on math and algorithms. This is very troublesome if you have a big project team (3-4 people), because you will be expected to implement logistic regression, MEMM, etc. She does not teach these algorithms that are necessary to finish your project but happily wastes time talking about IBM Watson, which is just an interesting side thing. In sum, her lectures are not informative; the projects have interesting topics but you have to do a lot of self-studying to do them properly and thus they may end up taking too much time. Deep learning is the future of NLP. You will be better off skipping this class and instead take the free Stanford online course Deep Learning for NLP.

COML 1104.comment: This class provided me with life-long tools to analyze films but would I do it again? I'm not 10% sure. There are some benefits of taking this class over others, which mainly comes from having to watch films over reading books. The thing is, the class can also suck the joy out of watching films because it becomes a chore. There's a required film to watch once a week for roughly 11 weeks, with a 250 word review/response to the movie required once a week. This doesn't seem like much, and I acknowledge that you're probably thinking that I've never experienced a hard course in my life, but it takes a toll after a while. This is on top of the essays that are due every two weeks (total of 5 essays). I was already up to my ears in engineering courses and I had to manage to squeeze in time between writing lengthy lab reports and finishing up problem sets to sit down and analyze a film that was more than likely uninteresting and in a language I didn't speak or understand. No issue with other films in other languages EXCEPT for the fact that you're trying to read the subtitles while analyzing the scenes for things to write about and the two hour film suddenly turned into four hours. Outside of this, the essays are graded pretty fairly/easily, but it's hard to know what the grad students are looking for.
