Loved the class! Really inspirational. Made me rethink any platform I use and program I develop. Phenomenal professor and insightful papers.
Professor Levy is amazing and really tries her best to include students in discussions. You learn a lot of relevant material in this class, and there aren't too many assignments.

This is an awesome class. Professor Levy is so nice and treats students like equals. The entire lectures are really just conversations between her and the class. For a 4000 level course, there is very little work--readings for each course and three short essays. The content is super relevant and the class is a great place to learn.

INFO 4300.comment: Topic is interesting, however class moves pretty slowly due to an overly high emphasis on in-class participation, and practical demos, which are often hard to follow and not too helpful, with a lot of unnecessary and basic questions asked and waiting involved for class participation. Would have preferred less time spent on demos and more time on the theory/concepts behind IR design. Professor also doesn't post any notes to try to force you to come to class. Workload is very light.
I thought it was very good workload and educated me about teams and working with technology.
Interesting class but lectures were a little boring and attendance is mandatory. Project and assignments also had a pretty heavy workload.

Loved this class. First half of the course is working on assignments and learning different search topics (cosine similarity, etc), and the second half is working on your final project. Not too much work, but if you put in a lot of effort on your final projects it's super rewarding. Highly recommend.

This class is super interesting and introduced the basics of NLP. The first two assignments were not super hard but take a suuuuuper long time. a lot of people dropped after A2. the midterm was not too difficult and the final project was very rewarding.

INFO 4310.comment: This class is a lot more work on CS 3300 as homeworks are a lot more up to you. There are write ups for each homework assignment to talk about the story behind your visualization.

More of a discussion based class, compared to the pre-req INFO 3300. There were three HWs, which were more like the projects from INFO 3300, and a final project. I had a good time with it, but your group members definitely play a role in your experience. If you've never coded in javascript before, I wouldn't take this class. Take INFO 3300 first.

INFO 4320.comment: This class is super super hard for me… the class structure is a little bit disorganized but the projects are fun..? I had to stay in the CIS lounge and pulled so many all-nighters to get this done. But I heard the class with Cheng is easier.

fun class! get basic understanding of hardware (Arduino) there's a lot of work like weekly assignments and design exercises and final project but overall a very interesting and practical class to take!
Very fun class, but it's a lot of work. There are weekly assignments, three larger design projects, and a semester-long group project. It also teaches a lot of skills useful to the IS concentration.

The class was really fun! You get to learn Arduino, laser-cutting, CAD, and 3d-printing throughout the semester, culminating in a final project of your own design. However the workload grows dramatically in the second half of the semester as you balance the final project and other assignments, and without previous experience or a really great group, it can be very difficult to complete.

This class was interesting and you learn a lot. There is a heavy workload though. Weekly assignments although you are set up to complete them in class. There is a team project competent so choose your team wisely!

INFO 4340.comment: This is a decent class. There are a few coding/vue assignments and a lot of design assignments, but the design assignments may be fairly redundant if you have knowledge of the design process and have worked on UX projects before. The professor is very passionate but that can come off as intimidating sometimes. There's a group project where your teammates are randomly assigned. Workload is inconsistent, some weeks (coding assignments) have  a lot of work, while other weeks have fairly little.

This course definitely has a few coding-heavy assignments that I struggled a bit in but OH is definitely a lifesaver in this class. The group project (50-60% of your grade) experience is very dependent on your group members but is fairly management, though a bit quick-paced.

In the beginning this class had pretty tight programming deadlines, but then it made way for more design-related assignments. I enjoyed the hands-on interactivity. However, I wish there was more time for the final project.

INFO 4400.comment: This class has been redesigned to have a heavier focus on user research. Class lectures are definitely the best part of this class. They are pretty engaging and include a lot of fun interactive activities. The group project is also fair, and the professor is allowing students to choose their own teammates. However, homework assignments are still sometimes fairly tedious and annoying.

A really interesting class if you're really into design theory and HCI and have exhausted every other HCI class lol. I feel like other classes like HCI Studio with Francois teach the same thing over and over again but this class really goes into abstract design methods (feminist design, ethnographic studies, undesign, etc.) that you may not use in industry but are still super interesting to learn about. I'd stay away if this is your first design class though because most of the work is readings and designing a project that may or may not exactly be an app/website. Gilly is one of the most organized professors I've ever met and she's super knowledgable!
This class is a fun challenge. You mainly spend time working on one large design project but also have weekly reading responses and mini design assignments.
Took it Spring 2019. Overall workload is acceptable, readings are hard to understand sometimes. But class structure is really interesting (especially workshops), Gilly is also a great professor!

INFO 4450.comment: This class is fairly relaxed. It has no exams and mainly consists of a group research project with pretty easy milestones. However, attendance is mandatory, and there is a discussion post requirement.

In-class group activities and lectures are usually pretty interesting and I think your experience in the class would be highly dependent on who your group members are, who you can choose. Overall workload is really not bad at all.
Semester long project so you need to pick your group members well. Attendance is required.

The class is an easy A. Professor Fussell was very accommodating during COVID times. However, I found some of the class activities to be useless; time could have been allocated towards more utile tasks.

Interesting class discussing various aspects of online communications, including message affordances, conversational structures and coherence, grounding, workspace awareness, etc. It is very sweet in offering night session class to accommodate Asia time zones. There are 1 to 2 break-out room discussions every lecture. Discussion posts regarding reading materials. A research project carried out throughout the semester in groups of 6-8.

INFO 4940.comment: I thought this class had so much potential, but I was really disappointed in Professor Leshed. I found her incredibly standoff-ish and confrontational when students asked questions. She doesn't encourage learning and never answers questions in an understanding and sympathetic way.  As well, I have found the value of the subject area drowned out by the excessive work that is assigned. The class is a single, extended group project, but each section of the project is incredibly time intensive and there is a lot of subjectivity in the grading.
This is THE design class to take at Cornell. It's a lotto work, and sometimes there's too little time for group projects, but the time crunch is similar to design in the industry.

I really like this class! The workload is quite hearty with all the individual and group assignments. BUT, Gilly is a really passionate instructor and I learned a lot from the class regarding HCI and design process. I ended up putting the group project in my portfolio. I would encourage all design students to take it!

the course is very design process heavy, so if you're not into that then maybe this class isn't for you. 

overall, the course is pretty chill. there's a group project you work on throughout the whole semester so the workload isn't bad at all.
I took the LLMs class with David Mimno which was very enjoyable! The class takes more of an "exploratory" approach and doesn't have much work outside of class and no exams. Strongly Recommend!

INFO 5450.comment: This class is fairly relaxed. It has no exams and mainly consists of a group research project with pretty easy milestones. However, attendance is mandatory, and there is a discussion post requirement.

In-class group activities and lectures are usually pretty interesting and I think your experience in the class would be highly dependent on who your group members are, who you can choose. Overall workload is really not bad at all.
Semester long project so you need to pick your group members well. Attendance is required.

The class is an easy A. Professor Fussell was very accommodating during COVID times. However, I found some of the class activities to be useless; time could have been allocated towards more utile tasks.

Interesting class discussing various aspects of online communications, including message affordances, conversational structures and coherence, grounding, workspace awareness, etc. It is very sweet in offering night session class to accommodate Asia time zones. There are 1 to 2 break-out room discussions every lecture. Discussion posts regarding reading materials. A research project carried out throughout the semester in groups of 6-8.

INFO 5900.comment: A course that you cannot avoid as an MPS student:( If you get a good project and great teammates, I think it would be a nice experience. But it's very unlikely and it will be quite painful:((((

INFO 5900 -  The MPS project allows you to work for a real client for one semester. The good thing about this is that you get an experience similar to the work in the industry. The workload depends on your client's need. The assignment is easy but the project workload could be time costing.

INFO 6120.comment: I took the class in Spring 2018 when it was taught by a visiting researcher and PHD students. The class structure was very interesting and different than other INFO / CS classes I had taken. I found the course material to be SUPER interesting and the projects required creativity and ideation, which you don't find in a lot of classes. I would highly suggest if you are passionate about ubiquitous computing!

Took it Spring 2017, taught by Hane Aung. Probably one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Cornell. Weekly readings and responses, coding projects every 2-3 weeks, and a final 2 person project (presentation, poster session, paper). Material was really interesting, a lot about smart cities/homes, wearables, etc. Class seemed a little disorganized, but highly recommend. Prof and TA's were super helpful and always had time to help us.

INFO 6220.comment: In person this class is very easy and interesting, would recommend if you need a simple tech elective.
Professor Cheyre was fantastic and very helpful with COVID-19. I really enjoy how the class was transitioned to a-synchronous and was accommodating to different work styles.
Not structured at all. Professor don't teach class and TAs are teaching it. Do not recommend.

INFO 6450.comment: This class is fairly relaxed. It has no exams and mainly consists of a group research project with pretty easy milestones. However, attendance is mandatory, and there is a discussion post requirement.

In-class group activities and lectures are usually pretty interesting and I think your experience in the class would be highly dependent on who your group members are, who you can choose. Overall workload is really not bad at all.
Semester long project so you need to pick your group members well. Attendance is required.

The class is an easy A. Professor Fussell was very accommodating during COVID times. However, I found some of the class activities to be useless; time could have been allocated towards more utile tasks.

Interesting class discussing various aspects of online communications, including message affordances, conversational structures and coherence, grounding, workspace awareness, etc. It is very sweet in offering night session class to accommodate Asia time zones. There are 1 to 2 break-out room discussions every lecture. Discussion posts regarding reading materials. A research project carried out throughout the semester in groups of 6-8.

INFO 6940.comment:
For human ai interaction design research

Prof is pretty chill and weekly workload isn’t too bad (read a few research papers and make a discussion post before every class). The final paper was very painful to write though at most people do the one where its 15 pages and >30 sources to cite.

the course is very design process heavy, so if you're not into that then maybe this class isn't for you. 

overall, the course is pretty chill. there's a group project you work on throughout the whole semester so the workload isn't bad at all.
I took the LLMs class with David Mimno which was very enjoyable! The class takes more of an "exploratory" approach and doesn't have much work outside of class and no exams. Strongly Recommend!

Took building inclusive computing organizations. This is a very chill class with fairly little work. Topics are interesting but sometimes repetitive. This class includes two group presentations. We also had speakers from companies come in to talk to us about their DEI programs (but they were basically more of a recruitment pitch.

Took the DTSI class with Prof Csikszentmihalyi. He’s very knowledgeable, experienced, thoughtful,  reasonable, and most importantly, quirky in the best way possible. Work isn’t too bad; 3 short essays and a final group project. The class really pushed me to think ethically.

ITAL 2204.comment: Professor Campbell is the best, I strongly recommend taking this course with him. He is super sweet and just loves to hear everyone's opinions. He is also a really good lecturer and has really interesting things to say about the films in class. The course content is super digestible and doable and you'll have a lot of fun if you just do the homework which is pretty light. Treasure the class while you're in it, you'll definitely miss it when you leave.

JAPAN 1102.comment: The course was hard but the teachers were nice

A little more difficult than J1101, but with that foundation you are able to learn so much more and express many more ideas in this course. Terashima Sensei is very nice and explains material well during lecture, and is accessible for office hours outside of class. Sections are engaging and same style as J1101 and practice the content that was learned before. Final project is an essay and presentation.

JAPAN 2202.comment: Great course, and Larson Sensei is very helpful and encouraging. The course goes through the next 6 or so chapters of Tobira, and Larson Sensei pushes you to use grammar and parts that you learn from the text. Will really improve your Japanese if you put in the effort to learn. Homeworks are moderate, some have recordings in the worksheets you do, but definitely recommend continuing to improve your Japanese.

Daily attendance and lots of homework are rough, but the teachers genuinely love the material and make it as accessible as they can. Overall, the course does a great job of not only teaching language, but various cultural and historical lessons, and I would recommend taking it if you have the time in your schedule.

Larson-sensei is one of the kindest people I know! She is very willing to work with you and truly wants to see people succeed in Japanese. Whenever I have any issues, I can go to her and she will respond kindly and in a timely manner. She is the reason why I love taking Japanese! I highly encourage you to take it with her if you can!

KOREA 1102.comment:
I really enjoyed learning Korean, but gosh the homework for this class was so tedious. There is constantly so much work to do for this class and it didn't even feel like I was learning or making good use of my time completing the homework assignments. The almost weekly quizzes were also super annoying and very stressful tbh as the voice recordings were meant to be taken in one shot. This was worsened by the fact that I had the 9am section slot (and section is every single day), but even though I had good attendance in my first semester of this class (KOREA 1101), it was so hard to be consistent taking KOREA 1102 — I think I skipped 13 times throughout the semester as when you hit 14 you get bumped down a third of a letter grade.

Loved the 선생님s running section though. They were super friendly + funny and it felt like they genuinely cared about us as students.

KOREA 1110.comment: Professor Kim is mad chill and really nice, and pretty funny. I really liked him as a professor. Lecture was pretty much just going over the slides, and quizzes were based on readings, homework, and content on the slides. Pretty easy class if you just do a decent amount of studying.

LATA 2170.comment: The professor was great but as someone who is not a native speaker of Spanish, I found this class to be very challenging. I took this class after completing SPAN 2095 and I would recommend taking other higher-level classes before taking this one. Since the readings are from the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the old Spanish used is different from modern-day Spanish and is much more difficult to understand. The class also included a lot of class discussions which was difficult for me since many of the other students were native speakers.

LATIN 1205.comment: Professor Gallagher was extremely experienced and engaging, and organized the class very neatly. The work centered around canvas quizzes that were really translating and interpreting exercises due before most classes related to the ongoing concepts introduced in class. Overall, the class was very well organized and the textbook was very effective, and the content more engaging than just the Latin.

LAW 2650.comment:
This is one of my favorite classes I took at Cornell, but objectively one of the hardest. They do cold calling, rotate professors, and some of the work is very challenging, but a rewarding experience for those interested in the field of law.

Assigned seats and cold calling make it a little more tense in the class, but become friendly with the people near you!
Prof Hans and Prof Rachlinski are the best professors I've had at Cornell. The workload is not small - be prepared to do some readings!

One of the most interesting classes Ive taken at Cornell. It is essential that you thoroughly do all reading homework because they cold call students in class. This can be stressful at first but is honestly not a huge deal. I honestly never felt bored, and as long as you show up to every class (attendance is huge) and take good notes you'll do well

Loved this class! Hans and Rachlinski banter like an old married couple (can be awkward at times), but the class content is incredibly interesting. Make sure to do the readings as their prelims demand VERY precise answers, but the TAs are understanding and cold calls are not that scary! Would try to take if possible!

this class is pretty good, but there is quite a decent amount of work to be done. the readings are pretty lengthy & I'd REALLY recommend taking notes for all the readings (which adds hours of work on top of everything). It's also a pretty difficult class, as in the exams are REALLY tricky & it'll be pretty hard to get an A in this class. But this class is really interesting & the professors are really great lecturers. Both of them know how to make the class lively. The cold-calling is intimidating at first, but once you see some people say a couple of dumb answers, the pressure is taken off.

LAW 4131.comment: I enjoyed the class and I think Professor Chutkow does a good job in laying a solid foundation when studying law. The experience would have been a lot better if it was synchronous and in-person.

Prof Chutkow is super interesting and entertaining in lecture. I have learned so much. The assignments are very doable and related to class content. Readings are a reasonable amount and gone over in class.

Professor Chutkow has a sense of humor and she relates well with students. Class is not too bad; sometimes the legal reasoning can get a little convoluted (especially in terms of tort law) so make sure you follow with the readings and lectures. Grade primarily is based on two hypothetical problem sets, in which you are presented with a set of facts and must apply legal reasoning/facts from cases in the readings to your own set of facts. Would suggest you go to office hours for assistance as these are graded pretty harshly. Overall, the class is not impossible but make sure you get help if you need it.

Took this class Spring 2019 and absolutely loved it. Learned a lot about a number of different types of legal issues and cases to explain them. Professor Chutkow is a phenomenal teacher who consistently engaged all the students in lecture despite being a large class. Homework consisted of short readings throughout the class, along with 2 "Problem Sets" instead of prelims, which were essays you had to write explaining how a given court case should be decided based on lecture material.

This class provides an excellent and comprehensive survey of the American legal system, covering 1st Amendment issues, court procedure, civil, criminal, regulatory and administrative law, public benefits, and the Supreme Court. In addition, Prof. Chutkow is honestly the best professor I've had at Cornell -- she's always able to present the material in an engaging and relevant way and makes lecture 100% worth going to. There are two case analysis homework assignments, occasional section meetings that substitute for lectures, and multiple-choice exams. Definitely one of the most rewarding classes I've taken.

LAW 5090.comment: Great teaching style, passionate lecturer. Exam is difficult but workload is manageable (prof. travis dyer)

LEAD 3100.comment: This is a great class that is fun and very informative. I would be careful taking this class if you're looking for an easy A, the professor has no problem giving you a 2/10 on assignments. There are a few group assignments as well that only one group can get a 100 on, the other groups get 80, 60, 40, and 20, and count for a good portion of your final grade. There isn't really a way to get an A in this class unless you happen to be in the 100 and 80 groups every time.

Class is fairly easy. The biggest assignments are just short reflection papers every other week or so. I enjoyed the class and the content and feel like I'm coming away from the class with some real world applicable knowledge about teams, leadership, and myself.

LGBT 1940.major: Computer and information sciences,  Political science and government
LGBT 1940.comment: The class was great if you read the assigned readings and attended lectures (attendance was mandatory). Discussion sections were chill and it was just discussing the assigned readings. There were just a lot of assigned essay assignments and a lot of readings.

LGBT 2290.comment: The way she teaches queer history is very insightful and she does a good job of correcting herself when presented with new information. Her readings are diverse and hit almost every member of the LGBT community.

LGBT 2350.comment: A lot of readings, can definitely be a bunch of work most times, but the professor is very kind and class is interesting. There are 4 essays throughout the semester that are ~4 pages long, but grading is not too bad. Overall, I enjoyed this class. Learned a lot about medical themes, disability, doctors - was not a premed major but this class is also apparently helpful for premeds to better understand a doctor and sick person's perspectives

LING 1100.comment: The professor and her class material are great. I would take this class again! There is going to be reading assignments and essays every week, but these are easy and interesting assignments. She expects you to write in a concise manner and read the material in class. Each class is like a book club.

Took Language Myths and Misconceptions with Evelyn Fettes – was a pretty interesting + chill class and got to learn about lots of cool language related topics. Essays could be based on your own language background and the final project was a creative project.

Professor Abusch uses a "traditional" approach to teaching. Her grading on short essays can be unpredictable, making it challenging to score high due to her meticulous attention to detail. Despite this, she tends to award favorable final grades. The class structure is straightforward, resembling a "book club" where everyone participates in reading. The regular weekly readings are essential as she occasionally conducts quizzes. Additionally, her readiness to call out students underscores the importance of staying engaged and not slacking off in her class.

The material in the class was very interesting and she had you write in very basic English. She didn't require much time outside class to work on homework since her essays were short but be prepared to read a lot in class.

Frances was an amazing instructor and really took the time to teach the basics of good proper writing to ensure all the students were on the same page. There were four major essays that had to be at least four pages. The assignments were low commitment and graded easily.

LING 1101.comment: not the easiest class but still pretty interesting, important to actually pay attention and understand the concepts, interactive class (in person), homework assignments and prelims are pretty straightforward

I don't recommend the course if you are just taking it as a distribution requirement. It's not heavy on coursework and I did really like the professor. The prelims are fairly easy and its not difficult to do well in the assignments. However, the final was nearly impossible (3 hours and 7 questions for an 1000 level class) and brought my grade down from an A to a B+. Which is a shame because there is no reason it should have been that difficult, especially if the students were doing well all semester
Fantastic introduction to the subject. Weekly p-sets are a piece of cake, but learned a lot through lecture.

Super great class and equally great professor! Ryan is very friendly and taught in an extremely engaging manner. LING 1101 is full of interesting content and is a great introduction to linguistics — pretty easy as well. We had weekly homework assignments which only took about an hour each and were graded pretty leniently. Our prelims were in class and a decent percentage of the marks came from vocab crossword puzzles. The final was definitely much tougher though. Many extra credit opportunities too! Would definitely recommend.

The class itself covers a wide variety of topics within linguistics. I think the material is a bit harder than you would expect, as it's uniquely presented and unfamiliar to the majority of the audience (as opposed to some topics in psychology that might make more intuitive sense). Homeworks are good practice, and prelims were fair and had more problem-solving. Final was much harder in my opinion and had a lot more synthesizing than memorizing. Professor is very into his craft and clearly cares.

LING 1109.comment: Not as interesting at the course description made it out to be. Professor is great, but I found myself losing focus a lot of the time because the lectures were boring, but maybe linguistics just isn't my thing. As for homework/exams, we only had 3 homeworks and 2 exams throughout the semester, so super light work.

LING 2212.comment: This class was a lot of reading, but was interesting. The labs we did were really fun, and were always exciting. The prelims were pretty fair too, and the final is a paper.

LING 2215.comment: The class is taught by a passionate professor but it is not good. As a psych major, this class covered more of a linguistic perspective which I did not enjoy. The TAs grading is pretty hard and usually, they could not help you with questions. I do not consider it an easy A
Really interesting class, especially if you put in effort to learn. Practically no work at all too, except studying for the prelims. Professor is very good too.

A great introduction to psycholinguistics with a great lecturer. Professor Christiansen makes each class easy to digest, and his presentation of each topic is intriguing and humorous at times. For my class, he did not assign homework and only had three prelims and a final essay, which were all writing-based. As long as you attend lecture and review the content of each lecture before the prelim, it is not hard to get a good grade. The prelims are not cumulative, and there is also an extra credit option. Definitely would recommend to anyone looking for a liberal studies class that is easy and interesting.
even though it wasn't my interest area exactly, the professor made this class' content accessible and fun to learn. I'd recommend this class to anyone!

LING 3302.comment: Took the class with Cohn in SP18, and the course was taught extremely well. The material covered a wide range of topics in phonetics phonology, and combined the concepts from each subfield. In addition, she taught us to question assumptions that we may have made about phonetics or phonology in intro ling to have a deeper understanding on the subfields. She's very accessible outside of class, willing to help if you can't make it to class or if you're stuck on the homework. Even if you think you're a syntax guy, I'd say this course is worth taking with Cohn.

LING 3314.comment: Took with Michael Weiss in Spring 2018. Content is very interesting, and Weiss is a pretty decent lecturer. However, the class was early in the morning, room was kinda dark, and his voice is very soothing so it was easy to fall asleep. Lecture slides are posted and are very helpful when doing homework and studying for exams. There is a lot of reading, and it's really easy to fall behind on the reading (although it is possible to get by without doing all of the reading). There were two prelims and a final. Prelim 2 and the final were take homes, which was nice. Weiss also gives lots of extra credit opportunities.

Took historical with Weiss in SP18 and it was a pretty good class. The lectures can be kind of long and have a lot of information, but he uploads the slides and you can review them later if you forget something. Homework was not that hard, and there weren't too many (we had 7 I think), but the exams can catch you off guard (although he offered some EC opportunities for us). Takehome exams might take longer than you'd expect, so start them early to avoid pulling unnecessary all-nighters.

LING 3321.comment: This is by far one of the coolest linguistics classes I've taken. Although it did require a lot of memorization of sound changes, the lectures followed the textbook very closely so studying wasn't too difficult. Professor Alkire is so nice and extremely knowledgeable about the subject - he had an answer to pretty much every random question brought up in class, and if he didn't, he went to the library for the answer and told us during the next class. Workload is pretty light but there is some rather dense reading. He said at the beginning that "As long as you show up to lecture and try your best you'll get a good grade." Material is super interesting if you like romance languages. I've never really been a phonetics/phonology person but this class may have changed that - our relative chronology problems are actually pretty fun. The final is a take-home exam and there's a couple of quizzes, in-class exercises, and short homeworks.

LING 4424.comment: Took with Mats Rooth in Spring 2018. Mats is a nice guy, but a bad lecturer. Lectures are hard to follow and he likes to ramble, and will occasionally lose his train of thought. However, the slides are also hard to understand, and there are no lecture notes (nor does he really follow the textbook), so you have to go to lecture. The class is quite disorganized, and homework/prelim grades took forever to be released. The class also seems to be focused much more on teaching how to use specific software tools to create/analyze linguistic models, rather than the theory behind how such software tools work (which is what I was more interested in). On the plus side though, he is rather lenient in giving final grades, so I still ended up with a B+ even though I kinda gave up on the class 2/3 through.

I took this with Mats Rooths during covid. Every lecture it felt like the professor was winging it as he went. He was always late to class (5-10 mins). Homework felt all over the place. Final project was also sort of ambiguous. No exams just projects. Grading was not too bad though. The class is very disorganized. This class is very linguistics focused too and you use software mostly to do linguistics stuff EX: foma. The hard part is coming up with grammar etc...

I took the class with Professor Marten van Schijndel (not the one listed above). More than half the psets (which were actually coding projects except for a few written questions) took more than 20 hours, although the short ones took a range of 1 to 5 hours. There were 7 psets total.  This is a predominantly CS class although it's cross-listed in LING and COGST. The lectures were interesting, but the projects (psets) were extremely frustrating, and the professor and the TA gave out obscure answers when asking for help.  I'm also not sure how much I learned from the projects. I ended up with a good grade, which is based on the projects and some participation, but wouldn't have taken it if I had to choose again.  Definitely know a friend you can discuss with or get to know someone if you take the class.

LING 4425.comment: The class was filled with interesting material, I took it with Abusch in Spring 2018 and we covered implicature, presupposition, focus/theme, and pictures (very briefly towards the end). We spent around 8 weeks on presupposition, so if you aren't prepared for that kind of detail the class might not be for you. The lectures mainly consisted of her writing on the blackboard or reading off handouts and she would explain/ask us questions, but the class size was small enough so it was almost run discussion-style. Readings and attendance are "mandatory" but I'm not sure how much it impacts your grade. We had 3 problem sets, one in class exam, and one take home final, so overall it wasn't too much work. Just understanding the conceptual parts of the course could be tricky and take time to work through.

LING 4474.comment: This class is highly disorganized, and it doesn't seem like the professor has a major hand on the course logistics. The projects are difficult not because of the content but because of the ambiguity in the description and the grading schema. The lectures are based off the textbook and are somehow made more confusing. You're better off reading the textbook than going to lecture. The grades and projects are never released on time, yet they still expect the students to somehow meet the deadline.

I came into the class with high expectations for NLP but this class really disappointed me by the way it's taught and kind of killed some of my interest of the subject. The lectures didn't prepare me for the projects at all. We went through algorithms in class but nothing about the implementation conventions. If you are not familiar with PyTorch and all those NLP packages, it will be a huge pain to search the documentation and often I didn't even know where to start because no one tells me what to look at. Thus, the projects are super time-consuming. I spent much more time on this class than on 3410 which is known for its heavy workload. Also, idk if it's bc the class is in the morning, the lecture is super dry and dead, the professor and the PhD lecturer really lack some enthusiasm in teaching and thus made the material much less engaging than it should have been.

I hated this class. The lectures are extremely boring and never talk about the actual code. And they expect you to code an entire neural network. My friends and I were lost the entire time, I've never been so confused in a class.

I took this class because I want to learn about NLP, but was thoroughly disappointed on the course structure, or more accurately speaking, the lack of structure. CS 4740 was one of the classes that fit my schedule for Fall 2020 where I took this class online. Lectures were decent, but could be better, there was a technical microphone issue where the professor's audio was practically inaudible and students were not able to hear clearly. Project guidelines were long, open-ended, overly wordy, and required students to write tedious code that were not directly related to class material.

I really regret taking this class over my other options. Prof. Cardie's lectures are almost entirely based on Jurafsky's textbook. The examples and figures in her slides are straight from that textbook, and thus you can skip most of the lectures if you just do the reading. Honestly, I think reading the textbook is the more efficient way to learn the materials since her lectures are poorly organized. She spends a lot of time explaining linguistics concepts but not enough time on math and algorithms. This is very troublesome if you have a big project team (3-4 people), because you will be expected to implement logistic regression, MEMM, etc. She does not teach these algorithms that are necessary to finish your project but happily wastes time talking about IBM Watson, which is just an interesting side thing. In sum, her lectures are not informative; the projects have interesting topics but you have to do a lot of self-studying to do them properly and thus they may end up taking too much time. Deep learning is the future of NLP. You will be better off skipping this class and instead take the free Stanford online course Deep Learning for NLP.

LING 6314.comment: Took with Michael Weiss in Spring 2018. Content is very interesting, and Weiss is a pretty decent lecturer. However, the class was early in the morning, room was kinda dark, and his voice is very soothing so it was easy to fall asleep. Lecture slides are posted and are very helpful when doing homework and studying for exams. There is a lot of reading, and it's really easy to fall behind on the reading (although it is possible to get by without doing all of the reading). There were two prelims and a final. Prelim 2 and the final were take homes, which was nice. Weiss also gives lots of extra credit opportunities.

Took historical with Weiss in SP18 and it was a pretty good class. The lectures can be kind of long and have a lot of information, but he uploads the slides and you can review them later if you forget something. Homework was not that hard, and there weren't too many (we had 7 I think), but the exams can catch you off guard (although he offered some EC opportunities for us). Takehome exams might take longer than you'd expect, so start them early to avoid pulling unnecessary all-nighters.

LING 6425.comment: The class was filled with interesting material, I took it with Abusch in Spring 2018 and we covered implicature, presupposition, focus/theme, and pictures (very briefly towards the end). We spent around 8 weeks on presupposition, so if you aren't prepared for that kind of detail the class might not be for you. The lectures mainly consisted of her writing on the blackboard or reading off handouts and she would explain/ask us questions, but the class size was small enough so it was almost run discussion-style. Readings and attendance are "mandatory" but I'm not sure how much it impacts your grade. We had 3 problem sets, one in class exam, and one take home final, so overall it wasn't too much work. Just understanding the conceptual parts of the course could be tricky and take time to work through.

LSP 1101.comment: awesome class. Not too much work and super useful for other classes in which you'll have to do research in. I took it with Tony and Tom and they were super easy to reach out to by email and answer any research related questions. Make sure you participate in class because they really like that, and choose a topic you're actually interested in so that way it's more interesting for you. Great 1 credit class

MAE 2020.comment: Dr. Royer was an excellent lecturer and the class was very fair. The exams followed from the homework, discussions, and lecture examples. The homework could be long and tedious but it prepared well for the exams. Office hours were a must.

I had Yeo over the fall 2021 semester. The psets were very long over the semester and difficult to the point where every week I needed to attend office hours. They were assigning us problems that we hadn't covered in class or discussion until a few days before the deadline. Yeo was a pretty good lecturer with great demonstrations. Prelims were alright if you went to the review sessions.

An important engineering course to understanding the basic physics of materials. Lectures are fine but the examples gone over in class are often much easier than hw problems- the textbook actually has a lot more useful example problems. If you can do and understand the hw by yourself, you will be fine on the exams. If you find them challenging, go to OH. It was a fairly difficult course, but that's engineering for you. There is a lot of hw too but they do prepare you for the exams. Overall, I think I learned the material well enough from this course.
The professor tends to go on tangents during lecture. It's great that she's so passionate about the material, but it's not great for my learning experience. The amount of work assigned is also awful.

Lectures were not very helpful, Prof. Moridi isn't the best at clearly explaining new concepts, but she does lots of good examples in class which is helpful. Recitation is very chill and can feel like a waste of time, but its still helpful to go so you can ask questions. Overall, this course has a great teaching staff and there were ample office hours. Tests were difficult, but manageable if you studied well(just redo the problem sets to study and you'll be fine). I recommend reading the textbook- it makes everything more clear as lectures weren't great.

MAE 2250.comment: I really enjoyed this class overall, but the class structure is not great. Because this is a meche specific class, the work is more "rewarding" in my opinion. The lectures and labs sometimes felt completely separate which is okay but it was pretty fun

I really enjoyed this class overall, but the class structure is not great. Because this is a mechanical specific class, the work is more "rewarding", like machining and CADing. The lectures and lab sometimes felt completely separate which is okay, but sitll very interesting.

MAE 3130.comment: Very dry lectures. Professor Robinson is a very funny guy though. Class is basically just learn how to do stuff for the PSets and then get tested on that.

Lectures sometimes goes fast through a lot of material, so reviewing them is important. The exams are really similar to the problem sets. Course material isn't too exciting but it's helpful to learn about how XRD works

MAE 3780.comment: I took Mechatronics Fall 2020 and I was very grateful  for the class was redesigned to fit the restrictions imposed by COVID. Originally the class was three parts lecture, discussion, and lab, however, labs were cut during my semester and instead were replaced by kits  that were sent home, for us to work with. The homework was lengthy, but the discussions were helpful with understanding material not covered in class.  COVID restricted us from having the final competition and instead we each had to create a design for something that would be useful in a home or office space.

I took this course with Benjamin Finio in Fall 2019. An excellent course - it covered a lot of circuitry and programming behind robotics and similar systems in a way that was very easy to understand. For context, I'm a CS major and the circuitry was easy for me to understand despite not working with circuits past high school physics. What really sets this course apart from the courses I've taken here is how hands-on it is; we were given kits of physical circuit parts to build and measure, which gave me a lot of circuit intuition as well as excitement in knowing what I am learning is very relevant to the "real world". The final competition is a very enjoyable time too, but it would be a good idea to come into this course knowing someone you'd like to work with.

MAE 3783.comment: I took Mechatronics Fall 2020 and I was very grateful  for the class was redesigned to fit the restrictions imposed by COVID. Originally the class was three parts lecture, discussion, and lab, however, labs were cut during my semester and instead were replaced by kits  that were sent home, for us to work with. The homework was lengthy, but the discussions were helpful with understanding material not covered in class.  COVID restricted us from having the final competition and instead we each had to create a design for something that would be useful in a home or office space.

I took this course with Benjamin Finio in Fall 2019. An excellent course - it covered a lot of circuitry and programming behind robotics and similar systems in a way that was very easy to understand. For context, I'm a CS major and the circuitry was easy for me to understand despite not working with circuits past high school physics. What really sets this course apart from the courses I've taken here is how hands-on it is; we were given kits of physical circuit parts to build and measure, which gave me a lot of circuit intuition as well as excitement in knowing what I am learning is very relevant to the "real world". The final competition is a very enjoyable time too, but it would be a good idea to come into this course knowing someone you'd like to work with.

MAE 4180.comment: Hadas explains the concepts very clearly. But, even if you understand the concepts, the homeworks can be long and hard.

MAE 5180.comment: Hadas explains the concepts very clearly. But, even if you understand the concepts, the homeworks can be long and hard.

MAE 6710.comment: Guy Hoffman is a genius and one of the best professor in Cornell (just watch his ted talk). The lectures are stimulating and inspiring. Homeworks are easy if you have experience with python and ROS.

MATH 1006.comment: The professor (Strogatz) was super engaging and his passion for the subject really did rub off on the rest of the students. Complex analysis is also overall a very beautiful subject and it was super rewarding to take

MATH 1012.comment: Once a week review classes, no HW. Brendan was amazing, GOAT. You spend class doing problems (you get a packet of them), ranging from easy to difficult. You'd get time to try them on your own, then Brendan would go over them, step by step. Problems in class also include solutions. I used the problems from this class to study for 1120 exams because they were so good at capturing all the content you needed to know. Brendan was really good at teaching and explaining, and he's also super nice/chill. Super helpful class if you're struggling with the material, or just need some extra brushing up. Brendan also held OH which were super helpful! Overall, really helpful class and Brendan was an amazing teacher.

MATH 1106.comment: First, please consider this class if you struggle with calculus and aren't math-inclined. This was so much better than taking Calc 1. This fulfilled my prevet requirement, and I got a good grade. The professor is helpful and super friendly. This is one of the best math classes I have taken in my academic career.
Had James Beck. Great Professor who wrote all the detailed notes on the board. The material is much easier than Calc 1.
Difficulty depends on the student. It was easy but dumb mistakes are very possible given no calculators this term.

*Professor is James Beck*
This class is super easy if you've ever taken calculus before but need to take a calc class for med school. It's super basic, algebra is easy, and the exams are super easy. Super fun professor!

MATH 1110.comment: I'm a TA for this class and here are some tips that I think will help: do all HW assignments and pre-class so that your highest grades will contribute to your final grade. go to the monday supplemental review classes if you are really struggling - especially the ones right before prelims because his practice problems are super helpful! When studying for prelims, really focus on the HW assignments and quiz problems - I think these are most reflective of the types of problems they may ask you

I had Marie B.Langlois, but she isn't listed as an option; I really liked her and found her office hours helpful. I found the course more proof-heavy than my high school calculus class (I took AB Calc and got a 5). Strongly recommend using AP credit to place out of this class if you can. Homework and prelims were sometimes challenging, but the curve got me an A+ since this course is really intended for people who haven't yet taken calculus.

I took this class having already taken Calculus 1 in high school and it helped me significantly. That being said, there was a lot of new information and the way they want you to answer questions, specifically on homeworks, can take time getting used to. The structure of the class was weird, small classes where people have different TAs teaching them. Dr. Ramkumar was a very friendly and knowledgeable TA. I think in general though it is taught poorly. For some reason they introduce an idea to you, and have you struggle to see if you can solve a problem (which you end up needing the new concept you are about to learn to solve). After a long time of this, you learn a new concept only to go through 1 or 2 practice problems before the class is over. This was extremely frustrating because it would feel like you barely learned anything in class. Additionally, homework assignments which were due at the end of the week were based on the previous weeks Lecture content, so not only would you barely learn the content, but you would also revisit it a week later without having practiced it in the meantime. Homeworks were also graded for accuracy which I found stupid. Only got an A- because of prior Calculus knowledge. You definitely need to use out of class resources to succeed.

I mean it's Calc 1. Sungwoo Jeong is boring but a solid teacher (unintentionally funny at moments). Homeworks are annoying and take forever, do them with friends and make sure to check with others, the tutoring office in Malott is a godsend (those dudes are smart). 

Study study study for prelims, the final really fucked me, so much harder than I thought it was going to be. Grading is vague, they won't tell you the curve ever or what score you even got on the final.

Lowkey, I don't know if I'm just bad at math or Ramkumar sucks at teaching. Go to Kelly Pohland's lectures if you can instead, she explains things in a concise and easy-to-understand manner that would probably have you performing better. Also, the homework psets are really useful for helping you learn the material, so actually try on those, go to the support class for extra problems, and don't be scared to ask questions during lectures I promise no one's judging you.

MATH 1120.comment:
Had Robert Connelly before switching to Mark Poor. Both are very poor professors (no pun intended). Robert found it very hard to stay on topic and took several classes to even get started on teaching content, while Mark was very soft spoken and it wasn't clear what was happening or what he was teaching.

Homework is weekly and graded on completion, but there are two drops.

You only need to attend one prelim as the highest score is taken which is quite nice, but the final was cumulative and worth 45%. Also, in terms of how much of each topic is covered, the practice final was really not reflective of the actual final which was quite annoying.
Lectures were very boring. Hated this class but had to take it as a prerequisite. Take the engineering version if you are on the fence.

No.

(Sweet professor, but this class is just no).

Took AP Calc BC which helped a lot with this class. Most content is covered in BC, except for a few concepts near the end of the course. HW due once a week - took a decent amount of time and some questions could be difficult. But there is ample support at the Math Learning Center, Math support (MATH 1012), and Tatkon center. Exams were fairly difficult. Cao wasn't that great at teaching in my opinion. Sometimes, too much time was spent doing long theoretical proofs that weren't necessary for understanding/doing well on HWs and the exams. Although, there were a few theory/proof based questions spread out through the exams in the course - maybe 1 or 2 per exam. The course is mostly applications-based/practical with some theory sprinkled in, but you can get by without understanding it if it's not your thing. Cao's teaching/notes during lecture weren't great, so I just used the notes of profs/TAs from other sections on canvas.

Really if you are not a STEM major, like me, AVOID THIS CLASS. This class the the single main source of suffering of my entire semester.  The class expects you to preview everything beforehand and when you don't have time to do it you SIMPLY WON'T UNDERSTAND A THING. Homework is EXTREMELY CHALLENGING. Tests are OK though but you can easily lose points. Sacrificed tons of sleep because of this class. Really would not recommend.

MATH 1340.comment: Overall a decent class, although I found I had to ask lots of questions during lectures and office hours to ensure that I understood the information because the way concepts were explained sometimes did not makes sense to me the first time around. The content is very interesting and applicable to the real word without involving super complex math. I would especially recommend this course to social science majors because aspects of it relate to gov/poli sci.

Content was a bit harder than expected but textbook explains it pretty well. Homework problem sets each week can be challenging but prof Hyde does have lots of office hours. Can be difficult to get concepts explained from him though he does try, but as far as math goes, it's neat stuff to learn about when you do understand it.

Professor is fun and class is enjoyable. content can be difficult and he struggles with explaining it so sometimes concepts go right over your heard and you just hope they're not on the prelim. Actual concepts are fun and interesting though

MATH 1910.comment: This course all begins with Calc AB concepts, and gets progressively harder. In my opinion, I found lectures to eventually not be too helpful since I found it easy to fall a bit behind and not know what they were talking about in lecture, as it seems mostly like review and the professor moved very fast, however, he is funny at times. Since the concepts usually weren't too difficult until the end, I would say the class isn't too hard to do well in as long as you complete and understand the homework. This quizzes were always an easy question from the homework, I usually finished within a minute or so. The first two exams were much easier than the final, though, so that was a bit of a shock. You also get 3 quiz drops and homework extensions if needed and requested on time. Overall, this was a good course and hopefully helpful for taking 1920 in the spring semester.
This was a great calc 1 class, and everything was explained really well! The final was pretty tough, but prelims were chill. If you've taken any calc class in the past, this shoudl be pretty easy.
Good class but really hard if you don’t have a good calc 1 foundation.

First month is pretty much all review of Calc AB, class gets progressively harder. Peter was an alright lecturer, funny at times but not the best at explaining complex topics so I would definitely preview the textbook before going to class. Go to your TAs office hours when you are stuck on hw problems. I thought the prelims were fair.

Professor Bernard is an awesome lecturer- he's making Calculus II as interesting as possible. The prelims are more difficult than the homework questions, so they'll definitely require a lot of studying.

MATH 1920.comment: Homeworks were tough; I was in Math Support every week no doubt just to complete the weekly homework sets. Prelims are alright if you know the content.  I foresee this being helpful in future (I hope).
not fun. it's the weeder class if there ever was one. When you take it, do your readings beforehand, otherwise you'll be screwed.

Even after having taken multivariable calculus the year before in high school, this course was still quite a challenge. Lecture experiences totally depend on the prefessor and are very non-mandatory. Discussions are mostly mandatory, and also depend on the TA. Personally, I definitely enjoyed my discussions a lot more. Having said that, your experience will depend on your personal enjoyment of math and visualizing 3D environments.

This class is the harder math classes for engineers at Cornell. It is heavily curved and your grade is going to depend a lot on how the other students do. With that said, it is required so there really is nothing you can do about it but just work hard and do your homework and ask questions if you don't understand. The professors and TAs are generally really nice about giving help.

Lectures were informative but dragging, content was well covered and explained. Prelim 1 was way harder than I expected it to be, Prelim 2 and the Final went much better. Take the class more seriously than you think you need to.

MATH 2210.comment: I had Professor Alexander Townsend. He is really good at teaching with a great accent and is a loving father. He teaches the concepts on a basis for us to learn things correctly and does a swell job teaching them. But Linear Algebra is a tough course that is proof heavy. I think I would try to do the engineering track if you could do that instead if you aren't good at theoritical maths.

This class was proof-based than I was expecting, but Prof. Swartz was pretty good at walking us through how to do a proof. I wasn't always able to follow what he was talking about and it sometimes felt like he taught things that were slightly extraneous to the course instead of getting to the point right away. However, I felt relatively well-prepared by his lectures going into exams.

First of all, Ed Swartz is truly a great guy. 
However, I would recommend taking MATH 2940 (fulfills all the same prereqs) instead of this course unless you're a Math major or know for sure you like *proof-based* math.
This course can be hard to navigate as the content can be confusing and the textbook leaves much to be desired. Anecdotally, there were several dropouts. The support course is an excellent resource, although the practice problems are much easier than what is found on exams. 
The workload was not bad, 10 homework assignments and of course, study hard before prelims and final. It's a taste of what proof-based math is really like. Computational math like calculus I/II, in my opinion, is a different skillset. Take it only if you want a more rigorous challenge vs MATH 2940.

I really liked this course. The content was super interesting and Professor Swartz is pretty good and answers questions well in lectures. The support course that is offered alongside it is also super helpful.
Marcelo Aguiar was super organized and his lectures were always very helpful. This course convinced me to major in math.

MATH 2220.comment: Prof is great and class is challenging but rewarding!
Kinda hard. Doable homework. Short prelims. Can't get A without enough efforts

The homeworks are very difficult and I often was working up to the last minute for them. Lectures are ok, I got confused often but that might just be on me. Class was also understaffed. Material is interesting and professor is passionate about it, but again, it was very difficult -- probably the most difficult class I've taken so far. Professor does give extensions for homeworks, which is cool.

I actually really enjoyed this class. The professor was great, and she taught the material very well -- so much so that I hardly needed to open the textbook at all this semester. The problem sets are very long (a bit too much in my opinion) and were due Monday morning. The first part of the class was definitely the hardest (the test average was by far the lowest), but it progressively gets better. Obviously, this isn't finger-painting, so if you don't put the time in learning the material, you will not do well. Good class but time consuming.

Professor Mann is amazing. Lectures are clear and line up with the material in the textbook well. Psets are due Monday of every week and can be on the longer side. The difficulty of exams and hws are fair.

MATH 2240.comment: Insanely difficult. It's not abnormal to walk into a 3 hour prelim with five questions and walk out having only answered two. A must take if you plan on continuing with more math.

MATH 2930.comment: I liked this class a lot. The lectures are very proof-based so I recommend you just read the textbook instead. My best resource was the recitations- they're a good consolidation of the material (ultimately depends on the TA, though). Homework was straightforward. Watch out for the exams!! I remember Prelim 1 being really easy and then Prelim 2 and the Final were extremely hard. All in all, I enjoyed the class and found it pretty interesting.

Took with Professor Ritz in fall 24 and did not enjoy the class. Course concepts are very interesting but lectures spend too much time on proofs and not enough time on examples. Grading scheme for LOs is horrible and extremely opaque; the difference between a 1 and 2 is not well defined and seems subject to the grader, your discussion TA, so there is little consistency across the board. In order to do well in this class you NEED to do well on the quizzes and I recommend front loading 
your 3s to the best of your ability as PDEs get difficult and the final exam gives basically no partial credit so it’s vital to come in with as many LOs complete as possible.

The class is poorly designed. Without the bizarre, and frankly catastrophic, grading system the class would be decent. Ritz is a solid lecturer, the workload is light, and the TAs were helpful in my experience. You just have to pray that they haven't made the rubric absurdly strict for a given learning outcome and that you can squeak out a revision.
All the resources were very organized. Make use of the quizzes and do not pile the work at the last second!

Took with Freund in Spring 2024. Grading system with LOs takes a bit of getting used to, but I feel it is fair overall with how Freund implemented it. They are transparent and reasonable with what counts as a 1 vs 2 vs 3. 

The content itself gets harder at the end, so make sure you feel comfortable with the earlier stuff BEFORE you the class gets to fourier series and PDEs. 

Homeworks are tough but graded on completion, and the quizzes every 3 weeks are usually alright.

MATH 2940.comment: I took this class with Professor Lewis in Spring 2019. Lectures often were very proof-oriented, and although I could follow them easily (as someone who took CS 2800), that proof skill was often not tested on homeworks or exams. In fact, much of the workload felt like little more than number-crunching - easy, but annoying. I had high hopes for this class - talking to other, more math-oriented people, I often hear things like how beautiful linear algebra is. This class disappointed me, as I feel like I got very little of that abstractness that I value math for in the first place. On the bright side, the class itself is pretty easy - just read the textbook and you'll be fine.

Professor Laurent Coste is like a very nice uncle.  Although I was fine with his lectures, I know that many of my friends thought that his lectures were boring.  The first two prelims were generally considered pretty easy by a good portion of the class.  However, the final was a knockout punch that came out of nowhere.  Overall, the class is a pretty traditional math class which is pretty easy in the beginning, but watch your back on the final.

This class gave me quite a bit more trouble than I expected. Prof. Freund is kind and funny, and I always enjoyed his lectures, but I definitely had to re-learn content using the textbook. HW is weekly and graded on completion; it’s not very difficult but it takes a few hours. HW policy is extremely generous. Exams and quizzes are fair but still relatively difficult. I never really felt like the lectures or homework helped me study for exams beyond core concepts; practice exams were my best friend, and I essentially went blind into quizzes. My main problem with the course is that grades lacked transparency — no medians/means were released for any assignments or exams and I had virtually no clue how the class would be curved throughout the year, which was very disorienting.

Probably the most entertaining math class I've taken at Cornell! Prof. Townsend uses many examples in class and keeps everyone engaged. He gives many application-type questions too, which is useful for higher-level CS classes like ML and CV.
Really good class! Mainly focus on application, so no math proofs! Professor Townsend is really good and TAs are always willing to help.

MATH 3040.comment: Good Class, workload was manageable although sometimes the problems were challenging. Office hours were helpful
Why can't I give this class a six...this class is a spiritual experience that enlightens you to the beauty and power of mathematics.

Implemented with "backwards classroom" where students teach each other. A LOT of homework but similar to CS 2800. good class to take, if already familiar with concepts, otherwise easy to be drowned in the midst of people who take the class after already taking more advanced ones. Really good for improving proof skills (hence the exclamatory title), would highly recommend before analysis. No other math or CS course that I know of will teach how to build a proof from ground up.

MATH 3110.comment: I had Professor Speh, who is low-key very funny, as long as you pay attention. Really introduced me to the more theoretical side of math. Would recommend if you want to learn to write proofs.

This is a decently challenging, very proof-heavy math class. The professor is nice, although he talks pretty fast and it is very easy to fall behind if you miss lecture. He does all of his lecturing using a black board, and doesn't record notes/lectures, so being in class is definitely important, although the textbook covers basically the same topic in a wordier way. There are weekly PSETs consisting of 8 proofs and they are pretty challenging. Some background in proofs is definitely needed to be successful in this class. Overall, the content is pretty interesting if you are interested in the stranger properties of numbers.

Class is slightly annoying (as you would expect of a proof based class), the TA's take off many points for not specifying many details, but it really is impactful in the sense that it makes you think about math, proofs, and functions in a completely different way.

This is a very good class. Lectures are good though the professor does assume that students understand things when they probably dont so you have to ask questions. Exams were takehome (covid). the course gets difficult very fast though and the end materials is quite crazy. I remember spinning like 15+ hrs on the final takehome. The tests are decently hard but not too bad compared to the final. Make use of OH alot. Helps alot. This class also helps you write proofs.

I had Professor West. He's a nice dude but lectures were pretty boring and out of the textbook...so you didn't really have to go. Also, the two prelims were pretty easy overall although the final was like WTF...so much shit about improper integrals.

MATH 3320.comment: Fall 2019, with Prof. Nicolas Templier. If it's Prof. Templier, then I would recommend for the relatively low difficulty and workload. He taught the concepts very well, imo, though he tended to omit hard topics. You may find the class not challenging with him, but he is very easy-going and nice. With that said, please do not get discontent with his French accent at first, which isn't an issue at all but a charm as time goes.
good course, wish I studied more

Interesting content, Zywina is a great lecturer. The psets are pretty fair, difficult but there's enough time to do it. Unfortunately I did not allocate enough time for them so my grade was mid, but if you do then you should get an A-/A. I found the polynomial roots confusing but everything else was understandable if you followed the lecture and did the psets.

Taken Fall 2020 with Prof. Templier. Lectures were well-structured and he was enthusiastic about the content. Homework was reasonable and exams reflected the homework well. The course has been very helpful in more upper-level math courses, and I felt the material was taught so clearly that I've retained most of it to be able to apply it to my other math courses.
It's a quite easy class with Prof. Nicolas Templier.

MATH 3360.comment: Class is pretty easy and chill if you have taken some higher level math course before (or CS 2800). Prelim 1 was hella hard and the median was a 62 but prelim 2 and final had pretty high medians (around 90)
Nice course. Easy homework. Lengthy prelims. Can get an A with some efforts.

I really liked the topics that this class covered - they set up a good foundation for reading up on higher level math topics, and you also get to learn about interesting applications like linear codes and cryptography. The workload is pretty standard for a math class, weekly homeworks, 2 prelims and a final. I think the curve is a little harsh, because the medians tend to be pretty high. Professor Aguiar can be a little boring in lecture sometimes, but his notes are really good and well organised, and will tell you everything you need to know to do the homeworks and the exams. Although it was kind of sad that he still had homeworks due during the week of prelims :(
Great class with pretty engaging content and a good lectures. It's not too hard, although sometimes it can be tough to keep track of all the propositions and such that are needed to answer questions.

The problem sets, prelims, and lecture material were not really connected.  We never got back the third prelim and the last homework was returned during the final.  The professor seemed a bit disorganized and was sometimes hard to follow during lectures.  Overall, the material was interesting, but the way it was taught and tested could have been better.

MATH 4030.comment: I took history of math with Nerode Spring 2018. A lot of lectures consist of him reading the text (that he wrote and uploads to blackboard) or original materials, and explaining them. The material starts from Euclid (don't buy the textbook, it's just Euclid's Elements which is available online, and we basically didn't use it) and explains the development of mainly geometry and algebra up until Galois theory. The problem sets also aren't too difficult but can be long and tedious (there's around 9-10). A third of your grade is based on the presentation, where you choose a topic and give a 20+ min lecture to the class on basically anything related to the history of math. Attendance was mandatory when there were student presentations. Overall fairly interesting and a pretty chill class, but I guess it's not for everyone.

MATH 4130.comment: Took it with Knutson in fall 2020 (I know it selected Muscalu, but CUreviews won't let me publish without choosing a prof and Knutson wasn't on the list). The content was alright (really just a review of calc 1 and 2 with more proofs). I will say, Knutson is not an analyst and it shows, as this was also his first time teaching the course. Also, if you took 2230/2240, you will have already covered most of this material. Problem sets weren't too bad and we only had a final. Grading transparency is non-existent, as it took up until the last day of classes to know the homework and grade policy.

Took with Goncharuk in SP17. Problem sets could be long and hard (we had a double sized problem set the week before spring break due after break because of all the time we had) but were usually reasonable and very satisfying to complete. Overall I found it very engaging and would recommend to anyone with strong interest in math.

Took it with Daniel Rubin, Fall '16. One of the best math lecturers I've had, but I found the problem sets to be long and challenging. Most people in class had trouble fully finishing midterm. His grading policy was that if your final was good, it would determine whole grade; if not but midterm was good, they would both be considered; if both tests went badly then hw considered.

MATH 4140.comment: Took Spring 2019. Workload is very lopsided. Homework is easy and takes a couple hours (even quicker by getting answers from TA in OH). Midterm and final were impossible however. Hardest tests/assignment I've done at Cornell. Took 40+ hours. Course material isn't very interesting since its just a redux of analyis 1 in multiple dimensions. Wish we'd done more with lebesgue integration.

MATH 4180.comment: Prof Hubbard, Spring 2017. Hubbard is very good at encouraging people to ask questions in class, & in OH. I don't like analysis, but he made it a bit better, and also at end of semester went over applications to other areas of math (e.g. number theory, algebraic geo). But I still don't like analysis & found problem sets quite difficult. Comparable to 4130 w/ Rubin. Sometimes errors on HW, and covered things we hadn't learned yet.

MATH 4260.comment: Hard but super informative course. You learn a lot!

The course requires quite a lot of commitment, with the hours comparable to 3110, but more theory-oriented. However, it is packed with useful techniques (performance optimization, large-scale data processing, and more), so it sure is worth the investment. However, I'd strongly recommend entering the course after having a strong basis in mathematics, especially linear algebra.
While the workload is comparable to 3110/3410, Professor Damle is a fantastic teacher and I felt like I learned more than I have in most other classes.

Requires a fair bit of mathematical sophistication to really do well in, so be warned. There's a fair bit of work, and the median tends to be quite high due to the grad students that take this course, so be prepared for that. Prof. Damle's a pretty good lecturer that spends a fair bit of time building intuition for what algorithms do, so that's good.

This class covers a lot of material. Really it covers too much and you don't get enough depth in the topics but it's still a great course. Bindel was a really good lecture and he made amazing notes for every class. So even if you didn't go to class you still had all the info. There were a few short and pretty easy homework, however, the projects were brutal. Half the time it was trying to figure out how to manipulate some equation to get where you wanted and the other half was trying to optimize your code so it ran quick enough. Pretty much everyone ended up going to office hours where the TA would start going through all the equations but it would still take forever to actually complete these projects. Then the final was also crazy. It was a take home final and over half the class spent over 25 hours on it.

MATH 4280.comment: (Healey Sp20) Unfortunately the lectures were extremely boring to me and I couldn't really focus. Luckily I managed to do OK by reading the book, and studying past HW solutions for exams. But still did not enjoy the course and only took for the analysis requirement.

MATH 4310.comment: Professor Stillman is a good lecturer. Be prepared to attend every single lecture if  he teaches it again, because lecture notes will not be posted anywhere.

This prof was probably the best lecturer i have  ever had at Cornell much less the Math department. Very very organized lecture, easy to follow. The course content is not easy but the prof teaches it quite well. The exams are quite hard - especially the final. Homeworks are not that bad though. Exams were takehome + timed during covid. Context here is more indepth than the lower level linear algebra so dont worry about not learning new stuff.
Very hard class but the professor is very good! Lectures are very clear. Be prepared to work hard and attend office hours regularly.
Was definitely a hard class but the professor was very good! Lectures are very clear. Be prepared to work a lot on homework and attend office hours regularly.

MATH 4710.comment: Professor refused to post lecture notes or any preparation for exams except for references to the textbook. Lectures and material focused more on convoluted and involved proofs that didn't fit the description of the class or its prerequisites. Overall, it was unnecessarily difficult, especially because problem sets were not possible without reference to the textbook or online sources and similar problems appeared on the exams.

The professor was fine and explains things well if he knows the answers. I did not like the course organization. Problems came from the book, but the lectures were more like tangents, or brief and oversimplified summaries of book sections. Sometimes the lecture were ahead, but mostly behind, what we were supposed to have read in the book (to do the HW).
The content was well organized and notes were always shared. The course slowly scaled in difficulty as the semester went on. Homework was always on the longer side.

I'd recommend taking this with Professor Saloff-Coste, he's super nice and organised, and his zoom lectures were great too! The weekly homeworks aren't too long, some concepts might be challenging but I think this class is the nicest out of all the ones that fulfil the CS probability requirements.
Really nice professor and fun class! Professor is definitely always willing to help you out during office hours. For sophomores and juniors, I think this is a good first 4000-level class to take.

MEDVL 1101.comment: Took medieval gardens with Alice Wolff, was pretty interesting and had a couple visits to the botanic gardens. Workload was doable and she was a pretty understanding + easy grader. The essays we had were fun to write ie garden review, herbal manuscript, and our final paper was to design a garden for a fictional character or historical figure.

There were a lot of readings but they could always bring really interesting topics for class discussion. The professor was an easy grader and gives helpful feedback.
