We had peer reviews on our essays which was a little awkward. The final essay was a lot of work and required lots of research and time.

Took the class on women in medvl art and literature. Honestly, made me more in tune w gender studies and i dont regret taking the class especially as a stem major with a lot of prerequisites. Had an extra credit assignment consisting of writing a one page paper on the 2020 mulan reading. TA seemed tired often but was EXTREMELY understanding with covid situation (said to put mental health first)!!

I had Anna Waymack as a prof for young idiots and toxic elders. The readings were heavy and long at times, but she is a easy grader and very nice. She also brings food towards the end of the semester during presentations.
Asks the class too many questions they cannot answer

MEDVL 2170.comment: The professor was great but as someone who is not a native speaker of Spanish, I found this class to be very challenging. I took this class after completing SPAN 2095 and I would recommend taking other higher-level classes before taking this one. Since the readings are from the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the old Spanish used is different from modern-day Spanish and is much more difficult to understand. The class also included a lot of class discussions which was difficult for me since many of the other students were native speakers.

MSE 2060.comment: Very dry lectures. Professor Robinson is a very funny guy though. Class is basically just learn how to do stuff for the PSets and then get tested on that.

Lectures sometimes goes fast through a lot of material, so reviewing them is important. The exams are really similar to the problem sets. Course material isn't too exciting but it's helpful to learn about how XRD works

MSE 2620.comment: Taken in Spring 2020. The course organization was a little confusing. The beginning might be hard if you  don't have much background in waves. When we moved online, Prof. van Dover was really kind and accommodating  with deadlines.
go to office hours for psets!!!!!!

MUSIC 1100.comment: The assignments and quizzes are really easy. Professor is really nice and very easy with attendance and quizzes. There is a final exam but it was easier than the quizzes.

I took this class with James Spinazzola in Spring 2018. I would recommend taking this class if you already know how to play an instrument because it's fairly easy. You get assigned homework almost everyday though and it's all on handouts from class, so if you miss a lecture, you have to email him for the handouts. It was a bit unorganized, but overall, it was an easy A. Test were very straightforward.

Took with James Spinazzola in Spring 2017. This class is incredibly easy if you already play an instrument at a reasonably high level, but Spinazzola was not very organized and the class often seemed to be a bit messy. He was always somewhat behind schedule so the semester ended with parts of the syllabus not being covered.
Took it with Spinazzola. Really easy A if you play an instrument already.

MUSIC 1105.comment: The assignments and quizzes are really easy. Professor is really nice and very easy with attendance and quizzes. There is a final exam but it was easier than the quizzes.

I took this class with James Spinazzola in Spring 2018. I would recommend taking this class if you already know how to play an instrument because it's fairly easy. You get assigned homework almost everyday though and it's all on handouts from class, so if you miss a lecture, you have to email him for the handouts. It was a bit unorganized, but overall, it was an easy A. Test were very straightforward.

Took with James Spinazzola in Spring 2017. This class is incredibly easy if you already play an instrument at a reasonably high level, but Spinazzola was not very organized and the class often seemed to be a bit messy. He was always somewhat behind schedule so the semester ended with parts of the syllabus not being covered.
Took it with Spinazzola. Really easy A if you play an instrument already.

MUSIC 1312.comment: Fun class that I took during covid, so I didn't have to memorize as much haha. Frederick Nowell is such a helpful TA. he really grades  easily and understands the different level of writing and music each student has, he really helped me on the final essay.  The class is really interesting and I think overall easier than you would expect.

Sick class. Couldn't recommend this more--you listen to awesome music during each lecture and Peraino is so amazing. The tests are a lot of memorization but you'll walk away knowing so much music and the cultural backdrop of many songs.

MUSIC 1701.comment: Took the Music and Media section for my FWS freshman fall and enjoyed it. Readings were tough sometimes but we always discussed as a class and Jordan was chill even when we were like "I didn't understand much cause it was hard to read" cause then we'd just talk about what it meant. Workload was probably relatively low for an FWS, just written homeworks and a couple of essays where we got feedback which was really helpful. We had some cool topics and activities like going to the hip hop collection and having the opportunity to use the record players in the library, which I really enjoyed.

MUSIC 2102.comment: One of the best things about this class is how accommodating the instructor is - Prof. Shuster always responds to our concerns and often allows extensions when needed.  Workload can be heavy depending on the material covered in class.

MUSIC 3431.comment: Definitely a bit boring at times if you already have experience with sound design and production. Professor Cross is really knowledgable and super cute and caring. The class is what you make of it
Warren Cross is extremely knowledgable in the field and extremely accomodating during COVID really enjoyed the lectures and the projects were straightforward and not very time consuming
Very easy course, but Prof. Cross is rather disorganized (and covid didn't help). Assumes basically no prior knowledge going in, which is helpful.

MUSIC 3511.comment: Took course with Michael Sparhuber, in percussion studio. Mike is a great guy, energetic, wants you to learn. He's reasonably proficient/helpful in percussion; pushes you without pushing too much. Quality of 3511 will depend on who you take it with.

MUSIC 3602.comment: Frankly, a waste of time. If you can't get into Chorus or Glee, don't bother. The exception is if you have never ever ever sung before in which case this is a solid location to hone your skills for the first time

MUSIC 3603.comment: Glee club is awesome! This is more of a club than a class, but you can get credit for it so it's a great GPA booster. You get to meet great friends and sing amazing music with some of the most talented male voices at Cornell. What more could you want?!

MUSIC 3604.comment: Been taking it since I first got to Cornell. Does require an audition to get in, but is more like a voice-lesson. Class focuses not only on learning music but also improving singing through exercises in class, optional group lessons, and individual office hours. Mandatory performance at the end of each semester.

They take attendance sheets very carelessly. Though it's a precious experience for me to be a member of the chorale, the student who takes attendance sheets shows no respects to the one credit I am taking, and missed many of my attendance sheets, giving me a B at the end of the semester.

MUSIC 3610.comment: This is really great 1 credit class especially if you need a grade booster. It is just once a week commitment and you get to learn some really cool pieces on some really great instruments. You honestly have to have no previous experience and it is honestly a very stress relieving class. One you get in the zone when rehearsing pieces you forget about all your other worries.  I took it with Christopher Miller.

MUSIC 3621.comment: Conductor is meh now. Runs the orchestra like a youth symphony, and quality is definitely not great. But it's an easy A+ and community is pretty nice. Auditions are required every year.

I've taken it every semester Fall 2017 - Spring 2019. Fun people, fun repertoire; group goes on tour every year or two. There's been some turnover in the conductor position and competency has varied widely, but the conductors all seem to understand that we are stressed engineers/premeds, so they value effort over perfection. Audition required; graded on attendance (rehearsals and a few concerts) and effort, I think.

MUSIC 3634.comment: Took course with Michael Sparhuber. Mike is a great guy, wants you to learn (and wants you to get exposure to lots of weird percussion literature). Energetic. He's reasonably proficient/helpful in percussion. Pushes you without pushing too much. Accessible outside of class. For 3634, practice enough and show up, and get an A.

NBA 3000.comment: I loved the learning. I learned SO much about starting a business and feel that I now have the skills to start one if I want to. The class was engaging but one you can do side-work in if you want to as well. Ken was a great professor, super kind and gives great constructive criticism. Greg was great too, albeit super talkative, a bit difficult to understand, and sometimes strayed from the main points discussed in class. Overall great class with a usable final project that will help me throughout my personal life and career!

Not hard and very thorough overview of how to start a business! But classes are long and in the afternoon, mandatory attendance, and there's quite a bit of work (customer discovery interviews, slide decks, a final group paper/ presentation). Greg and Ken have a great sense of humor and are really nice. If you're cool with the above, would recommend the class.

The entirety of the course is fleshing out a startup business proposal and the final consists of presenting your pitch and a written business plan. Throughout the course, the workload is manageable, but the final is a lot of work and depends heavily on your team as well. I had a good experience but spent way more time working on this class's project than I expected.

The course mainly works you through how to create a business proposal and conduct customer interviews. They do not grade on the potential of your idea, but on you much you apply the business canvas to your proposal. Many user interviews need to be done but no exam.

This course is very interesting, as it lets you learn as you work on your project. The workload is very light  as it is just periodic check-ins and presentations. If you are looking to take a hands-on class where you can practice building up a business this is a great class!

NBA 5070.comment: Brad Treat and John Nesheim are great professors. A lot of the work is based out of the online lectures, though. It's not something you can cram in one day. Recommend watching the lectures when they're actually assigned, versus putting them all off to before the prelim.

NBA 5090.comment: Great teaching style, passionate lecturer. Exam is difficult but workload is manageable (prof. travis dyer)

NBA 5110.comment: I took this class with Prof. Nichols as a junior as an elective to fulfill my real estate minor. He was so chill and the best and the workload was super reasonable. Def would recommend taking with a friend because the HWs are in pairs and there is a group project. He canceled class sometimes to go to his kids soccer games. He is the best

NBA 5111.comment: Great course, very useful to learn about financial modelling

NBA 5150.comment:
Not a very heavy class - mostly discussion based with like 3 assignments. 

It’s a 5 weeks class but one class takes up to 8hrs.

It’s a pretty chilled out class - mostly discussed based!
It takes one whole day of your week but you get free Fridays for rest of the semester. 

The only negative is that teams are made by professor and you cannot change then.

Easy class and nice overview of leadership. Can feel a bit wishy-washy, so if you want to make the most of this class then try to apply the tactics that you're learning to your life instead of just passively taking in the material. The best part of this class is the 360 degree feedback; this is where you give around 10 emails of ppl you've worked with to the organizer of the class and they send an anonymous survey to  them asking for honest feeedback from you. You then get a really detailed report with quantitative and qualitative feedback about you. that alone made this class worth it.  You probably won't ever have another opportunity to get such detailed, honest, and helpful feedback from your peers again.

NBA 5380.comment: Interesting class with light workload. Homeworks are basically designing  business ideas and learn how to discover and select good ones. Final presentation about the best business idea per group.

NBA 5690.comment: Good introduction to management consulting with some key principles, but it definitely gets repetitive towards the end. I liked how Randy incorporated guest speakers despite it being a 7-week class, some juniors and some seniors to really get a sense of whether consulting is a career we may want to pursue. Little work for the first half of the class but ramps up towards the end, which also depends on whether you get a good group for the final case.
It introduces method regarding how to come to the consulting industry (eg. case study, structure building) and also what skills u need for consulting plus how to manage your career in consulting.

NBA 6029.comment: Took NBA 6029: Leading Agile Innovation with Sine. You just go to a hackathon that doesn't require you to code, attend a couple lectures, and write a paper. Do you learn anything about agile innovation? Well, I'll just say that the professor used a VHS tape to show us a video and had trouble doing that, and spent 10 minutes trying to find out how to access files on USB.

NBAY 5180.comment: Overall, the course was great! We gained valuable insights into the ideation process and the importance of deep interview research. The course was engaging and involved weekly group work, so choosing the right team is key!

NCC 4530.comment: Very light work. Half the class doesn't show up to lecture because it's optional, and the slides are self-explanatory. No prelims, just two quizzes with the first one being very trivial math.

NES 2661.comment: It was an interesting class! Maybe not the most useful information, but I really enjoy it!

NES 3519.comment: Professor Gocheleishvili is so passionate about the subject matter and he is a great teacher. He is super understanding and helpful, and he cares a lot about his students. I liked how he shared his own memories and experiences. There are three 2-page reflection papers about the readings and films, and then a final research paper (8-10 pages). Not much homework at all aside from occasional readings or films. Great class!
Best class ever taken at Cornell so far

Overall, not a very difficult class, but very tedious unless you're super passionate about the topics. There were about 3 large essays and 1 final research paper which constitutes the grade. Films and readings were tedious, but interesting. Would probably not take again but do not regret it either.
The more dry facts lectures can be rather dull. But the professor's comfortable and anecdotal style makes things interesting. Learned a great deal and also watched some good films.

NS 1220.comment: This class was super straight forward and easy to understand. The class has a lot of case studies which can help balance out your grades if you're not a good test taker. This class is also a good intro to nutrition for anyone who may need to take upper level nutrition classes later on!

NS 2600.comment: A lot of the reviews here are from Professor Moseley but Professor Thomas now teaches the class. She is kind and loves what she's teaching about. However, the class can get a bit boring and we always get out on time or late. There isn't too much homework and the concepts are pretty easy but they don't grade very leniently. More instruction could have been given for homeworks and projects as it was pretty unclear a lot of the time. Given how the class is structured, 98.00% needed for an A+ (no rounding) and extra credit is only worth 0.1% and takes a long time to complete. There is only few major assignments (1 midterm, 1 final project, a few writing assignments) so your grade is almost solely determined on a few things. Its a good class but def not as easy as it used to be.
This was a good class and it is not hard to get an A. Pop quizzes and assignments were simple if you did the readings and kept up with material. The class was informative and overall enjoyable.

This course introduced me to the Global Health minor which I ended up pursuing. Learning about HIV/AIDS, Maternal Mortality, and other topics within the realm of global health. Would recommend for everyone who is interested in Global Health!
Very interesting class, easy A if you put in minimal effort. Class can be dry occasionally.
Really good class, manageable workload and really cool content

NS 3150.comment: I took this course hybrid. The content is super engaging and interesting, and I think that the class is well structured to allow people to succeed. The grade for the course was based on two prelims and a short research paper on a topic. Going to the review sessions and really taking the time to think about and form answers to those questions prepares you really well, and following the guidelines for the research paper will have you set to do well.

Definitely very doable! If you took NS 1150, this is very similar- Dr. Levitsky repeats information presented.  Dan Berry provided pretty interesting information as well. Lectures were recorded, which was super helpful for reviewing content. Overall, I enjoyed the class a lot.
Not too bad, similar content to NS 1150 but half of it's new (the part taught by Dan Barry

NS 3310.comment: This class is super helpful for anyone studying nutrition and digestion or metabolism. The quizzes and exams were fairly difficult (there was a lot of info to memorize), but I was able to learn useful information. Good foundational class for further nutrition classes or research.

The professor is super engaging and very sweet! She goes at a great pace and answers questions with lots of clarity. It is a difficult class, but her lectures and quizzes prepare you super well for the prelims, and you learn a lot! The material is also very interesting, highly recommend!

An amazing trip through the digestive tract, taking a glimpse at the wonderful variety of nutrients absorbed along the way, growing an understanding of health related to digestion and absorption. Don't underestimate the course, it is a hefty amount of information, but all ties together. Exams make you think, but aren't cruel or tricky. Prepare, ask questions, and you will do well.

NS 3410.comment: This is definitely a heavy workload and lots of memorization. Lecture is almost every day with frequent quizzes. Professor really tries to interact with students and get them involved. You would get assigned TA who will be a great resource for you. I don't think this class is impossible but you might wanna limit other heavy work classes.

This class is required for HBHS students. Anatomy was such a fun class, Professor O'Brien is like the nicest professor I've ever had. While lecture is usually engaging and pretty interesting, it was sooo much work. Lecture is everyday and about 40-50ish slides are covered per class. As long as you keep on top of the material though, the class isn't too hard.

NS 3600.comment: Dr. Finkelstein is a very enthusiastic professor who cares about her students. One of the more difficult Global and Public Health Classes but also one of the more useful.

NTRES 1201.comment: Honestly pretty boring, I feel like they could have made this more engaging, though the debates were interesting. I feel like most people who took this class were just E&S students trying to get a clunker out of the way.

This course was pretty boring and poorly organized. Pete would always commandeer lectures and leave Xoco no time to talk. Grading was pretty easy though, and you could just keyword search readings for the reading quizzes.

NTRES 2201.comment: Richard Stedman is honestly the best lecturer i've had so far (in CALS), really prepared for lectures, and makes class interesting. He doesn't have slides so taking notes is a must (or just look at other ppl's quizlets), he usually has a exam review sheet and all possible concepts tested will be on it. Fairly easy but the exams focus alot on details so hard to get high points.

I really loved this class! You could do the readings if you want/ are interested, but will do well in the class even if you only have time to attend lecture. Stedman is super passionate and a great lecturer. Highly recommend.

I loved this class! Richard Stedman is a great professor and genuinely enjoys the curriculum he teaches. Prelims are pretty easy and you can probably do well if you just take good lecture notes, but the readings really help to enrich your learning experience, and are good practice if you're not used to reading a lot for classes, so if you're really interested and have the time, I'd recommend doing them.

NTRES 3240.comment: Maybe not worth your time depending on your future career. If you are looking to be in water resource management, this class is for you! Otherwise, eh. This class was recommended to me by someone who confused easy classes with good classes. Quite disorganized and not a lot of particularly novel information. If you are passionate about water and community outreach it would be good. Prof is super nice and your grade all comes from about 5 quizzes and participation and a couple big projects. "Optional" final in super easy class means absolutely no one took it.

NTRES 6240.comment: Maybe not worth your time depending on your future career. If you are looking to be in water resource management, this class is for you! Otherwise, eh. This class was recommended to me by someone who confused easy classes with good classes. Quite disorganized and not a lot of particularly novel information. If you are passionate about water and community outreach it would be good. Prof is super nice and your grade all comes from about 5 quizzes and participation and a couple big projects. "Optional" final in super easy class means absolutely no one took it.

ORIE 3120.comment: This class is not well organized, the recitations are useless, but the psets are relatively easy. Office hours are also infrequent and the prelim was riddled with errors. Lectures are also very boring. Took class with Frans and Udell

Frazier really does not know what he is doing. The way he teaches is so ineffective, unclear, lack of focus and structure. Lack of OH and effective feedback. The contents could be easy and fun, but Frazier made this course neither.
There's a new professor, Fraizer, who is making the class more difficult than before. Median is now a B+ and the class is no longer curved.
The course is OK. The weekly problem sets might be a bit long.

The class is disorganized and there is too much busy work. I lost interest in the class because we have to get the piazza questions right and don't get notified about our attendance scores until a TA tells us how the professor is grading us.

ORIE 3310.comment: Great class. Frans Schalekamp is a great prof and did a wonderful job of making the material interesting and making the lectures engaging. Labs were meh, though.
Class was fair, but the grading was tough. The class wasn't curved.
Class was very fair. Easy to do well if you try
Great class! Took it with Frans, who lectures better than most of the ORIE department. His office hours are also great. Learned a lot in this class.

ORIE 3510.comment: This class has a lot of interedting material that is super applicable to modeling in industry. However, the professor is sometimes really confusing during lectuer. Also the class structure is super stresful with one prelim worth 30% of your grade and a final worth 40%z

Not too bad of a course -- material is reasonable, although the course should really specify prereqs of linear algebra and Python. Prof Dai is hard to understand at first but the accent grows on you; he's also very accommodating.
This class was so difficult. Midterm and final were rough. The homework was the cherry on top, sometimes taking 10+ hrs.

ORIE 4600.comment: If you are into financial engineering and quant this course gives you a very basic understanding of the material. Taking the class alongside stochastics is really helpful. Callister exams are really straightforward with same difficulty level as the HW.

This class gives you a pretty decent overview of accounting and allows you to get a baseline understanding of both financial and managerial accounting. Callister exams are really straightforward and just like the homeworks. However overall the class is pretty boring.

ORIE 5126.comment: This class is also ORIE 4126 for undergrads and is AWESOME. Professor Gentsch has a lot of industry experience and he is a really good lecturer. We have psets every week which are hard but as long as you go to office hours you will be fine!!!!!

ORIE 5310.comment: Great class. Frans Schalekamp is a great prof and did a wonderful job of making the material interesting and making the lectures engaging. Labs were meh, though.
Class was fair, but the grading was tough. The class wasn't curved.
Class was very fair. Easy to do well if you try
Great class! Took it with Frans, who lectures better than most of the ORIE department. His office hours are also great. Learned a lot in this class.

ORIE 5510.comment: This class has a lot of interedting material that is super applicable to modeling in industry. However, the professor is sometimes really confusing during lectuer. Also the class structure is super stresful with one prelim worth 30% of your grade and a final worth 40%z

Not too bad of a course -- material is reasonable, although the course should really specify prereqs of linear algebra and Python. Prof Dai is hard to understand at first but the accent grows on you; he's also very accommodating.
This class was so difficult. Midterm and final were rough. The homework was the cherry on top, sometimes taking 10+ hrs.

ORIE 5550.comment: Okay class. Lecture videos are pre recorded and lecture times are meant for discussion but no one normally talks. Homeworks aren't too challenging. Not the most useful class and didn't learn a ton.

PE 1100.comment: I loved this class. I already knew how to swim just a bit, but I wasn't that confident in passing the swim test so I decided to take this class. I was nervous about it at first, but I ended up enjoying it. The instructor really takes time to teach you the basics, and corrects any mistakes that you make. Everyone in the class learns together, and you are able to take the swim test during one of the class days, while also getting a pe credit.

With Instructor Ramineh, you actually get to pass the class. She will step by step teach you how to swim and let us practice. If you struggle on something, she will correct you by teaching you the correct methods.

Instructor was very sweet and kind. Made the class fun and participated with us when able. Great class to use as a stress relief or break in-between harder classes or studying. Can take even if you already passed the swim test but are looking for a more relaxed or laid-back pace.

I had to learn to swim for the swim test and surprisingly Diane taught me well. It is pretty easy and you get to learn different strokes as well. You get 4 absences and I just saved all mine up until the end and skipped class the last 4 sessions. It can be cold after getting out of the pool and the pool is sadly not heated, but not as bad of an experience as I was expecting it to be.

PE 1104.comment: This is a great class if all you want to do is just swim. This is not a stroke instruction course, it is just straight swimming for the whole class period. I took this class immediately after Intro to Swim, and I have to say it was incredibly difficult but very rewarding. I can safely call myself a swimmer after this course.
Very understanding w covid situation and absences. Wish swim sessions were a little longer. Few absences allowed throughout semester, but fair amount.

PE 1130.comment:
Chill class, super cool, learned to scuba. It's like 3 4-hour sessions in the pool; you will get a bit cold, but not as cold as when you have to do the open-water dives in Seattle.
Unfortunately, I signed up for the class on St. Patrick's weekend and missed out on that. Please look at the class dates when signing up.

PE 1150.comment: Since this is a PE course it was S/U for me. I had a lot of fun with this class and I've never had previous ballroom dancing experience. I don't remember too much of it now, but it was a non-demanding PE course that let me do something I wouldn't have done outside.

Took this class with Timothy and Peggy Sayers. They were amazing instructors, and always made the class wholesome, fun, and challenging! It's definitely a class where you get as much as you put into it, some days I didn't pay as much attention and had a harder time keeping up with steps but they were really patient and always offered to show me the steps again!

Fall 2022 with Tim Sayers. The instructor and his wife teach together and are very knowledgeable and fun. Good intro to rumba, salsa, etc. Engaging class with low pressure (attendance based). We go through different types over the semester so to remember the dances you need to practice them on your own - but it really depends on how much you care about the class. Recommend for anyone interested in dancing.

I took this class with Iska Ziver in the Fall of 2018. When I first signed up for this class, I wanted to use my PEs to do something wildly different than what I was used to. I am glad to say that I was pleasantly surprised! I looked forward to this class every week as a stress-reliever. I especially enjoyed the TA (Kendall McAdams) and his humorous but informative demonstrations. My only complaints about this class are the relatively-fast pace (this is a survey class of ballroom dance after all) and the fact that this class only meets once a week.

PE 1162.comment: Fun PE that teaches you salsa from the basics.  Definitely helps to have some sort of dance background, but not necessary at all.  The class feels very judgment-free.  Mike's metaphors to explain dance moves are the best.

PE 1170.comment: My instructor was Lesley Greene. This class is fun in the beginning of the semester but, as one might imagine, it gets old fairly quickly. Beware of any dance class where you need to hold hands with a dance partner - lots of hand sweat. Also very frequent partner switching, so don't join the class expecting to get a lot of dancing time with a friend. You can only miss two classes, which makes for not a ton of leeway in attendance. All in all, classes are not the most exciting but the music is good and you do get to tell people you know swing dancing when you're done, so maybe it's worth it.

Swing Dance was a really fun PE. I have never done Swing Dance or had much dance experience before so I definitely learnt something new. We rotated partners throughout the session and learnt both West Coast and East Coast styles. The music is great and everyone is very kind - I looked forward to this class each week.

Swing Dance was a really fun PE. I have never done Swing Dance or had much dance experience before so I definitely learnt something new. We rotated partners throughout the session and learnt both West Coast and East Coast styles. The music is great and everyone is very kind - I looked forward to this class each week.

Swing Dance was a really fun PE. I have never done Swing Dance or had much dance experience before so I definitely learnt something new. We rotated partners throughout the session and learnt both West Coast and East Coast styles. The music is great and everyone is very kind - I looked forward to this class each week.

Swing Dance was a really fun PE. I have never done Swing Dance or had much dance experience before so I definitely learnt something new. We rotated partners throughout the session and learnt both West Coast and East Coast styles. The music is great and everyone is very kind - I looked forward to this class each week.

PE 1260.comment: Fun class taken Fall 18. Instructors are very professional and encouraging. Learned many fundamental kicks and strikes, like a nice combination of boxing and taekwondo. Reasonable amount of exercise every week.
Han Cho will kick your butt in a good way. Fun but also challenging. Wish he would change his music playlist sometimes. Class is very popular and large

PE 1261.comment: Best teacher! He is very lenient about attendance and coming in late and he really cares about your fitness and well-being. He is super friendly and makes an effort to be friendly with you! As for the class, we mostly do bodyweight exercises focused on balance and strength building. We use the track in Barton Hall and the stairs at Schoellkopf Field to do cardio. Sometimes what he asks is demanding, but you feel rewarded after! Definitely helped me with my fitness goals, too
The exercises did not rely on equipment, only the body. Some examples of exercises are running laps, pushups, planks, dips. Definitely don't come in hungry because you will feel very faint.

PE 1262.comment: Bert was amazing — super friendly and always encouraging regardless of your experience level. There were a range of different things we did during each class, with most of it being an emphasis on cardio and other typical gym workout routines, but there were also occasionally things like Zumba, walking in the Botanic Gardens, and meditation (we all just slept). Very chill and a great introduction to the gym.

Great fitness class! We do workouts in the gym and learn to use different equipment. Some days she will have circuits for us to do, sometimes we get to make our own. We also sometimes take walks outside if the weather is nice enough. We do meditation/sleeping and talk about nutrition but not very often. Bert is very caring and never judges you if you have a low level of fitness. You can also adjust the intensity level of the exercises to your own liking. Would 100% retake her fitness class if I could.

PE 1265.comment: This course is great if you want experience using gym equipment and learning new exercises, and is really what you make of the course. Perks include a gym pass and an optional fitbit for the semester. There is limited written work (setting goals) and assessments (beginning and end of semester to track personal growth). Classes can feel boring/simple but feel short and are a great way to set aside time to use the treadmill or do strength exercises for an hour in the middle of the day.

PE 1272.comment: Priscilla Timberlake is a jerk, her rigidity ruins the class as her attitude is negative, and she enforces a strict attendance policy w/o excused absences even when sick. Some of the walks are pretty, but often it seems she's just trying to fill 90 minutes as some walks we just walked straight back on North Campus through woods and got covered in mosquito bites. She is unfriendly and judgmental, would recommend taking this with friends or not at all.
Highly recommend walking tours with Priscilla, especially if you like walking/exploring outside. You go on fun walks near campus and you get to chat with the other people in your class
Helps you to learn your way around campus nature areas so that you can come back later! I am very glad I took this PE.

PE 1290.comment: Even if you don't do gymnastics, I'd recommend this PE to anyone! Jamie Jett was an awesome coach, who supported everyone of all skill levels- as long as you actively participated, showed up on-time, and tried your best. After warm-ups, stretches, and drills, the entire gym is usually opened to practice anything you wanna improve in. However, you might hear "Dance Monkey" one too many times...

I honestly am a very inflexible person so I was initially very intimidated by the thought of gymnastics but the professor was very supportive and you can go with your own pace in the class. Grade solely depended on attendance. We got to learn things like cartwheels and other floor routines as well as go on the parallel bars from time to time!

PE 1300.comment: Jon LaRock is my hero, and when your hero is teaching a bowling class, you take it. Here's how a typical day in Bowling goes: You'll walk into class. Jon will give you a nice smile, and he'll ask you how you're doing. You'll have no option but to say you're doing absolutely fantastic, because heck, you're in bowling class now. Once everyone files has filed into the bowling alley, Jon will spend about 5 minutes teaching a Team-USA certified bowling technique. Then, you're free to bowl at your own leisure for the rest of class! Gotta love it.

Every class was basically a free bowling hour twice a week. The instructor is nice but he barely taught much about bowling; he kinda just let us experiment. We also weren't allowed to do hw or even have our phones out, so we had to bowl even if we weren't feeling it. It also got kinda monotonous towards the end because it was just the same thing over and over and there were barely any games or challenges or even music to spice up the space/activity.

This is more like bowling free time than an actual class, which isn't a bad thing. The instructor gives a simple tip at the beginning of each class and then lets everyone bowl. If you show up, you are basically guaranteed to pass.
Really chill, you could just bowl however much you wanted every class. Fun and great for meeting new people!
John's a chill instructor, he lets you do work between bowls. Only the very basics of bowling are taught. This is a nice and relaxing distraction from the chaos of Cornell.

PE 1330.comment: Great class, you take a bus to Greek Peak and just ski there. They have instructors there so you take the class that fits your level there, and after class just ski for like 3 hours. Your class pass also turns into a season pass after the class is over.

The conditions on Greek Peak can really vary. One class we were skiing almost on powder and another there were literally patches of grass all over runs made of iced-over mud. The instructors are decent, but make sure you get into a class appropriate for your skill level. Lots of free time to ski on your own as well, overall a fun experience.

PE 1332.comment: I love that Cornell gives us the option to choose this! This (and other skiing/snowboarding classes) is great to take with friends, especially if you choose the Friday or Saturday ones (free bus to the mountain). There's a lot of time outside of the lesson and hang out. Greek Peak is small but good for beginners. The instructors vary based on who you get, honestly, but I really enjoyed one of mine. Like most things (especially with sports), you'll get more out of this class if you put in more effort.

PE 1340.comment: This was a great PE. Everyone was able to pick up three-ball juggling pretty quickly, and then they move on to various tricks (there are probably more kinds of tricks than you expect). You won't master everything they introduce, but you can continue working on the things you think are cool at the end of each class
I came in with no juggling experience and it was a great class.
We learned how to juggle clubs, balls, and rings. The class was also set at a very good pace. Made some really great friends in this class too.

PE 1350.comment: The class wasn't what I thought it would be. It's definitely more boxing than the hiit workouts I wanted. The instructor is very passionate and does the workout with you. As long as you're doing something related he doesn't really care.

The instructor was very passionate about the exercised he taught and made sure that everyone in the class was able to do them too. If you put in the work, the instructor won't care too much, but if you're visibly slacking, he might mark that as a missed class. He is very understanding if you need him to repeat a certain movement. If you enjoy some light boxing paired with a very intense cardio, you will get a lot out of this class.

PE 1375.comment: Han Cho is has a very unique sense of humor and great life advice and tips during class. Class is kind of tiring though with a lot of movement and repeating forms.

The instructor is extremely passionate and knowledgeable about TaeKwonDo. I think it would have been more fun to take it in a normal year but he did a good job of making sure that everyone is involved. I thought it was cool that he invited in students from the TaeKwonDo team to help out.

Han Cho is funny, approachable, and really passionate about TKD. A lot of the students take TKD for all four years and become really skilled at it. If you really enjoy TKD, you can also join the TKD sports team and go to competitions with other universities. Recommend trying this class out!

Fine. Pretty engaging; kinda weird. He had lots of weird lectures and "life lessons". I'm not very coordinated but he'd always lecture us "I don't care if you're good, I care if you try"; he wanted us to practice outside of class, which I did, on occasion. There's not much one-on-one interaction, due to the size of the class. You can tell that he and his top students are very passionate.
Han Cho is funny, and makes the class enjoyable. You will learn grappling/wrestling, boxing, a TKD form, sparring techniques, and beginner stances/blocks/kicks/punches.

PE 1376.comment: Class is nice and all, but we get just 2 absences and no makeups which is kinda not for me lol.

PE 1380.comment: I did not learn anything from this class. It felt like a waste of time.
It was a really interesting class. The instructor was also a really interesting person
Don't take this class, John Burger is a self-righteous white man who takes himself way too seriously

Pretty chill: what you'd expect . I got sleepy a lot since it was after lunch. The professor was really into it and wanted us to truly "feel" tai chi which was hard. You couldn't talk a lot in class but it was fun when he brought in the sticks for us to use. You have to be pretty coordenated/ remember the moves (not that you are graded on skill).

PE 1405.comment: Took it fall 2020. We would walk to different spots on campus, like the botanical gardens, or to the suspension bridge and then find a place to spread out as a group (masks on and distanced) and do some stretching and meditation. We had to talk with each other a lot while walking or at the locations which was really nice. She'd teach us about mindfulness and methods of taking care of ourselves through the stretching and meditations, and then we would journal for like 15 minutes. Then walk back to HNH. Very easy class, very worth it, I had a great time and it really got me out of my room and to explore new places on campus, while also taking care of myself, very great option during these times. We had planned to go online when the weather got cold but then the instructor Priscilla got us into HNH and we used the gym and dance studio which was really cool. Priscilla was also one of the coolest people I've ever met, highly recommend this class.

PE 1420.comment: Very peaceful and relaxing pe class. We learned different ways to meditate, and we used each meditation technique at the end of each class. This was a nice way to relax after a stressful day in my harder classes, and I would recommend this class for anyone who wants to fulfill their pe credit with a simple class.

Took Fall 2023. I really enjoyed this course! We learned different meditation techniques, and the teacher was super chill. If you're looking for a class to fulfill your PE requirement, I highly recommend this one!
Took Spring 2018. Very relaxing class. Learned about mindful meditation which was nice. Was a little boring at times. The instructor is so welcoming though :)

PE 1429.comment: Took this class with Jenni having literally never done yoga before and loved it. Fair warning it actually is a workout but some days are also more chill and you can relax and maybe even nap a little on those days. You are asked to read book chapters to discuss in class. Would highly recommend this class if you are at all interested in trying yoga.

PE 1430.comment: Lewis was a great instructor, I highly recommend taking it. Keep in mind when this class is and if it will work for you. You can only miss 4 classes over the semester! Also, this class will make you sweat (it is a P.E. credit) so keep that in mind.
Very relaxing, but attendance is very strict and you can only miss 4 classes a semester even though the class Is twice a week

Loved this class! So nice to have a built-in part of the day to relax and connect with your body and mind.  I also still felt like I got a bit of a workout, which I was happily surprised by. Would definitely recommend this one. Also Lewis is great!
Super great class, half of the sessions are "relaxation days" where you are able to just lay down and relax. Professor is lenient with attendance and allows you to make up missed classes.
Hawk is an amazing instructor. An overall every chill class that essentially brings back nap time from your elementary school days. You can only miss 2 classes though. Nameste!

PE 1440.comment: This was super fun! Honestly anyone could do this course whether they want something easy or challenging because you'll find both kinds of people there. As long as you show up and play you'll get credit. I loved it a lot so I'm considering taking Intermediate Badminton next semester.
Fun time at Helen Newman, helps you relax from other classes in a stress-free environment.
I like badminton. Got to play badminton.
Very lax class. Partners are switched up all the time, so you get to play with almost everyone in the class.

PE 1445.comment: Took this class since I've never officially learned tennis. I think we learned the basics and maybe in part due to that, we didn't "play" much with other individuals. Still had a good time though!

If you're interested in tennis, this is a good intro class to start. If you wanted to spend most of your time learning a lot of techniques and doing drills, however, this is not the class. Most days are spent doing some type of game. We start out the class doing "around the world" where you have to hit the ball to the other side of the net and then run over to the other side to do it again. The hard part isn't hitting, it's the running! Towards the end of the semester, you finally can refine your skills enough to have decent rallies and the games become more fun. The only downside of this class can be the instructor. He can sometimes be funny, but he can be one real nut job. He is not shy in expressing his views about COVID-19 and about the mask mandate. He will occasionally call everyone in the class over to let us know to never trust the media or Big Pharma. Regardless of what you think about his opinions it really doesn't have any place to be discussed in a tennis class and can sometimes be really annoying. If you try to question him on this, he will get very mad and start to debate you, he even has a printed-out script that he will read to kids about how the pandemic is not real. However, aside from the instructor, the class can be very fun, and you will get a workout running around.

PE 1446.comment: You go to the Risley Tennis Courts and do some drills, then play tennis. If you like tennis and you've played a bit, it's a fun class. Would not recommend for people who have never picked up a racket before.

PE 1465.comment: Had Daniel Evett as the professor/coach.  Super fun class, enjoyed a lot.  Cool guy too.
Old guy (professor) was weird, maybe just take bowling instead unless you really want to leave squash.

A good refresher for engineers spending most of their lives crammed in front of the monitor. You get to work out a lot during the one-hour period and get to meet a lot of non-engineering students/grads, and whacking those rackets is a good stress reliever.
The professor would bring in plants every day for us to hold and he even brought in a rabbit tail once. It was really weird but fun. I actually did learn to play squash- it's a good workout.

PE 1515.comment: Great class - learned how to fire a handgun safely, and our specific teacher (Herrera) was a total G

PE 1520.comment:
Pretty fun and relaxing PE class. The first few weeks are a lot of safety precautions and learning about the shot sequence. After that, it is pretty chill and classes are just shooting for the majority of the class. Basic class structure is just sign in, little review for 5 minutes, and then shoot for like 40-50 minutes. 

The main workload is just knowing what the whistle commands mean and what different parts of the bow are. 

The class gets full quickly during enrollment but lots of people tend to drop it so try to you could try to get in during that.
Very fun course. Beginner-accessible and just overall enjoyable.
Very fun & relaxing PE class! You get to learn about positions & techniques for how to shoot properly and participate in targeting with various ranges, targets, and cup towers, etc.

PE 1527.comment: Instructor is pretty cool and tells interesting history lessons. Having glasses isn't a problem if that's a worry. Cool sport what else is there to say.

Coach Matt puts the perfect blend of fun and actually learning a new sport in this fencing course! He is extremely careful about safety, so if you are slightly worried about fighting with swords, do not worry. He also talks (sometimes slightly too much...) about his own experiences, stories, and the history of fencing, which is very entertaining.

Getting stabbed honestly doesn't hurt much. The first few times you experiment with getting stabbed, you might feel slightly sore, but you'll be wearing protective padding with the tunics. And once you're actually in a match, the heat of the moment + adrenaline will make you completely forget the slight discomfort. 

This class is really fun and I hope they do an intermediate level class soon!
Loved this course. All you have to do is show up (like most PEs). The professor teaches basic foil fencing, and often added short history lessons which were fun.

PE 1545.comment: def a cool experience and i learned most of the basics of figure skating. you can take the class multiple times to really get good at the basics/the class itself is kinda split up by level so you'll get the instruction you need. you need to be on the ice the time class starts and you need to be in class for 15 hours which is 15 classes. overall a fun time though esp if you're interested in ice skating!

Great class! You can come in with a range of previously experience levels, and you get separated into groups early so you can learn best! The professor spends time teaching each group new skills each class, and the rest of the time you get to freely skate and practice.

Professor: Robyn Bentley
Really fun and really chill and I actually got good! Professor is so nice and really fun.

PE 1560.comment: Become Michael Jordan. CU's basketball coach was teaching this class, and I could tell he was disappointed in us. At least we showed up.

PE 1565.comment: Take this if you want to just play for 3 hours a week, and meet new people!

PE 1580.comment: Solid class, teacher is really nice, its basically a free hour in the gym. What's not to like?

PE 1608.comment: Hard if you aren't a decently conditioned runner going into this class. If you're a great runner, the sights and kinds of runs you go on are worth it.

PE 1610.comment: Fun class that lets you explore the area! The course fee is free to those who need PE credit, though you're probably going to have to spend money to rent some equpiment. The class only lasts a few weeks, so it's a good class if you want to get over your PE class quickly.

PE 1615.comment: Lots of fun, you really get to learn what you want to learn and you don't need to be incredibly buff to do well and have fun. Would recommend, although it costs a decent amount of $$

PE 1625.comment: One of the more useful PE classes you can take at Cornell. Very light class, there is a quiz at the end but you have the opportunity to correct your mistakes on it for a higher grade, and I got a 90% on the final quiz when I showed up to our Sunday classes hungover. The skills you learn here can save lives someday as well, and you walk away with a First Aid+CPR certification along with elementary wilderness survival skills.

Alice was a very clear and competent instructor and it is amazing how much we learned over the course of 16 hours (things like scene assessment, CPR and rescue breathing, how to use a defibrillator, how to make splints, a hypothermia wrap, etc.). Alice is VERY strict about punctuality. Two kids in the class were like 3 minutes late after lunch break and she made them wait outside for a bit and then let them back in but they weren't able to get the certification (still got PE credit), so keep that in mind. One of the most useful classes you can take at Cornell.

PE 1625.professor: Amy Woodin, Benjamin Blakeley, Kae-Lynn Wilson, Mark Holton
PE 1625.comment: A fun, informative gym class to take if you are outdoors-oriented and want to be prepared in a worst-case scenario.

PE 1630.comment: This class was absolutely awesome! The whole thing lasts one week. There's one class on a Monday where you go over some background and do some planning for the trip (which lasted for me under 2 hours despite what the schedule said). There's a class on Tuesday to go shopping for clothes and get whatever gear you need from COE (Cornell Outdoor Education), which is not mandatory if you already have everything you need. Finally, on Friday you get in a van and drive out to the Schenectady area to camp for the night, and continue camping there as you go in a cave on Saturday and a different one on Sunday. The caves were beautiful, and it was a blast crawling, climbing, and exploring them. My instructors, Sylvan and Kaitlyn, were extremely helpful, kind, and knowledgable, and made sure everyone was safe and secure at all times. I would highly recommend that anyone who is physically and financially able to take this course does. Just make sure you're in at least somewhat of good shape and can handle several hours at a time exploring a cave.

PE 1640.comment:
There should definitely be a lot more reviews, this is a great PE! It's super chill since the instructors are mostly all students, but they also teach you lessons and tips so you'll actually get better at rock climbing. Taking this class gives you a climbing pass at Lindseth, so you can also visit the climbing wall anytime you want outside of class for the entire semester.
Was S/U (ignore the A), it didn't give me the option to put that.

This is by far the best class I've ever taken at Cornell. It's student run and still so amazing. It's a great way to get into rock climbing or just climb more in a low-stakes environment. I'd recommend this class to anyone!

Super fun class and you actually learn really good techniques for rockclimbing. You also get a semester pass to go whenever you want for free! You muscles will definitely be sore the first couple times though

PE 1641.comment: This was a really fun introduction to rock climbing! The instructors taught many useful techniques. Highly recommend, only once a week!

PE 1642.comment: Its been really fun to have a set time to climb. Yes you can go by yourself but here you can learn specific techniques and get formal instruction to get belay certified!

I discovered a fear of heights that had somehow escaped me for 18 years during the second class, but the instructors are great. Very positive and welcoming environment, good introduction to techniques and lots of time to climb. Relaxed environment where everyone gets to learn at their own pace, fast or slow. You'll be belay certified by the end of class and can climb afterhours as well.

PE 1646.comment: Very fun class where you can go entirely at your own pace. I had only climbed a couple times before doing this, and it didn’t matter. You can do it at any skill level, they just want to help you improve (and are very good at doing so).
Compared to B-rock, this was a little more free-for-all, since everyone had different experience levels. I improved by quite a bit, but it felt more individual for me than I would've hoped.

PE 1657.comment: a silly class although it’s more of a ropes course than being a squirrel. COE instructors are always very nice. realized you can’t really translate anything into future use though because all of the gear required.

Awesome and fun class! only thing is that it takes a lot of time out of your schedule...recommend taking it in the  freshman fall! otherwise climbing trees in the snow won't be fun or safe...overnight sleep in tree was awesome! doesn't require much skill or strength as you might have expected

Very fun class and very open to beginners. It sounds really shallow, but there are really a lot of cool facets to tree climbing. You spend more time slinging ropes into massive trees and climbing them with ascenders and descenders. Other times you're working with two ropes and can spider-man up smaller trees. This is a really fun class and is a great way to get outdoors and get some exercise. Definitely don't overlook this one. You even have an opportunity to overnight sleep in some trees

PE 1663.comment: You spend only one actual day on the ropes course. Pretty cool, but not worth the hype.

PE 1664.comment: TAKE THIS PE!!!! This is the best most fulfilling PE you can take.  I went into the class as only a casual biker and left knowing not only technique but also trails at the local Shindagin Hollow State Forest

PE 1666.comment: Took this class Fall 2019. It's been two years since then but I still think about it regularly. Small class sizes, a few bike rides around the area to get used to riding, and an overnight trip (ours was to Taughannock). Very fulfilling and a great place to meet new people!

PE 1674.comment: Absolutely an amazing class! Please take this! As someone who has NEVER kayaked before I was perfectly fine. We had a couple of meetings before a big camping trip in which we just went to the Adirondacks! Imagine kayaking to a private island with a mini beach and camping there for the weekend. A complete blast!

PE 1675.comment: Chill, friendly instructors (the class is NOT taught by Myers, it is taught by Cornell students)! Easy to pick up even without any paddleboarding experience.

PE 1690.comment: One of the best COE courses I've taken at Cornell. SUPER fun and satisfying to get the hang of cross country skiing! Snowmobiles on the trail smell bad tho.

PHIL 1100.comment: I had Shaun Nichols who was new to Cornell the semester that I took it.  (This website has not been updated to give him as an option of professor for this class) His lectures are not very engaging and hard to pay attention to.  He does not give you any grades until two weeks past the drop deadline so you have no idea how you are doing until over two months in.  He does not give very much but when he does it is a lot and you have to go over his 200 slide powerpoints to understand how to do it.  If you miss lecture his slides are not very helpful.  Bright side is that his final is not cumulative.

Lectures were meh but the material was super cool. Great overview of Philosophy and really straight to the point. Assignments were useful and not busywork, and the prelim and final were very straightforward.

This class could have been a lot better than it was when I took it. I think the content was pretty interesting; if you're looking for a very general introduction to a broad variety of topics in philosophy, this class is for you. Unfortunately, Professor Korzukhin's lecture were quiet and hard to follow. The lecture slides were also not shared in order to encourage students to show up to class, but not having them as a resource when studying for exams definitely made the class a lot harder. The readings were not bad in difficulty so if you're looking for an introduction to philosophy, just reading about philosophy in your spare time might be a better option.

This class was overall a disaster. The professor's (Shaun Nichols) lecture slides are hard to follow when you're reviewing on your own, the professor also uploaded amendments to the slides for the final exam a DAY BEFORE the final exam- never in my career at Cornell have I seen such flippancy from a professor. The student doesn't get to know their grade until after the drop deadline which is also extremely considerate, and the student has to chase down TAs to get grades back (which the student receives about a month later). TA's quality is extremely variable so it depends on your luck there. The professor doesn't recognize that most of the students in this class are juniors and seniors taking this class for a distribution requirement- they picked this class because they thought it'd be interesting! Sadly, I'm turned off from philosophy

FA19- I had Shaun Nichols- Unfortunately, this course was not what I had expected. The professor gives no indication of your academic standing until way after the drop deadline, and the midterm was unreasonably hard for an intro class. Slides on topics are 200+ slides and the content sometimes isn't explained very clearly. Quality of TA's is highly variable- I wouldn't recommend this class/

PHIL 1110.comment: I had feminism, gender, and education. Professor Manne was an amazing professor, he really cares about his students. Class discussions and readings were for the most part really interesting (a couple dry ones) and we only had 4 essays (most other FWS have 5 slightly shorter essays).

(Ethics of Sex of Relationships with Adriene Takaoka) Probably not the easiest FWS out there but definitely manageable. Every class was a class discussion on the assigned reading, with some classes focusing on some aspects of philosophical writing (e.g. how to write an exposition). Imo attending office hours is pretty important if you want them to grade your paper favorably, it also gives you an idea of what they're looking for in an essay which is not always clear during class. Overall they're a pretty approachable professor when it comes to essay help/flexibility on deadlines. Feedback may seem harsh at first but the grading itself isn't so bad and there are opportunities for extra credit. This class was interesting and somewhat thought provoking, but involved a fair bit of reading with sometimes dense or confusing texts.

I had Adriene Takaoka for Ethics of Sex & Relationships and definitely really enjoyed this class. The readings are so so interesting and well selected. It is a discussion based section and gets boring midway through the 80 minute class (although I liked having it twice a week instead of 3 times like other FWS).

I very much wish Adreiene did more teaching, most classes just start with us sharing our thoughts and most people in the class aren't thattt well spoken/even read the reading. Given that the content is difficult at time it would be nice if they took you through it

They will give you an A+ if you do a good job, the bar for quality of writing is really not that high. You will get a B if you're not slightly locked in.

Overall super good class, totally take it if you wanna learn some interesting stuff about sex/romantic relationships/kinks
FA 22 Applied Ethics taught by Alex Esposito. Great course, loved the in class thoughtful discussions. Not hard to get a good great, and professor was very flexible.

Took w/ Alex Esposito, Applied Ethics. This class hard carried my semester. It was exciting to come to class every week ready to discuss a new philosophical topic, & have debates with the rest of the class. I have no background in Philosophy (STEM major), and thoroughly enjoyed this class, but do know that the essays (there are only really like 2? 3?) are based on philosophical readings that you need to understand. However, Alex goes through them with the class & kind of drills it into your head until you get it, so you don't need to know about Philosophy going in. Grading was extremely light & everyone got As for doing the work. One of the best classes I've ever taken & Alex himself is a deeply entertaining guy -- and a great lecturer. (Also rocks at both basketball & chess.)

PHIL 1111.comment: Class is not as interesting as I had hoped. Essays are fairly easy and straightforward though so I don't regret it. Also a short discussion question due at the beginning of each class, but not too hard at all. Information can be redundant but not a hard class to get through with a good grade.

PHIL 1112.comment: (SP '23 w/ Barbara Cohn - "Philosophy of Fun") The in-class conversations/"debates" were interesting and low-pressure, which is what made it awesome! However, the essays themselves were "forced" to be written in a specific and strange style, or you would lose points...

Class was ok. Prof was accommodating to extensions but reading assignments were pretty long. You need to put in a reasonable amount of work into the essays especially on the last two. If you put in effort you can get an A. Only recommend if you actually have interest in philosophy
Good class just significantly more work than other FWS.

I took Philosophy of Social Media with August Faller. The topics are very interesting and in-class discussions are also engaging. There are reading assignments before each class. They can be relevant articles (which are kind of long) or a chapter from writing workbooks (very helpful). There are also mini assignments but they are not hard at all. All work is graded on completion.

I had Ben Sales and it was a very engaging class. The prof loved to bring up interesting counterexamples and hinted at possible objections to arguments while letting students fill in the gaps through discussion. The readings are a bit long, but it's ok to not read it super in-depth but just to get a gist as the expectation is to discuss the material in class. Ben is an average grader, not too hard nor easy. I came out of the class with a deeper interest and understanding of self, identity, and free will.

PHIL 1440.comment: This is only offered in the spring and I highly recommend it! It was a lot more interesting than I thought it was going to be and the goal isn't to make you vegan or anything, but more aware of where your food comes from. There is not a lot of work, just reading assignments to do for each class. There are pop quizzes but you will be fine as long as you did the reading. No prelims, 2 papers.

PHIL 2220.comment: the best part of this course was my ta. genuinely couldn’t understand the professor sometimes. he was very knowledgeable, but i do not think that the lecture model works well for this class. papers are short and straightforward, with adequate time to prepare. weekly readings and discussion posts, that may be shared in section and discussed with classmates.

Took this class with Prof. Hubner in SP20. I came in doing the readings and participating in discussions, but eventually got busy enough to not have time to read anymore. The discussion sections are really thought-provoking in this class, and admittedly I didn't enjoy the class as much since I took the class for liberal studies credit (I am not a philosophy major). That being said, the class gave me some new perspectives on life, especially given the COVID-19 pandemic that happened at the time.

Didn't do the readings ever but discussions were really interesting. We were given a question bank for both the midterm and final and you wrote a free response answer to a couple of the questions so very easy.

I am a CS major and I took the class in Spring 2018 with Professor Pereboom. Although he is a very knowledgable and acclaimed professor, his lectures were a bit disorganized. It is not necessary to do all of the reading to do well in the class, there were so many readings that it was hard to keep up. For the exams, he gives a list of 10 questions to prepare the answers to and then asks 2-3 of them during the exam. So with adequate preparation and some understanding of the material you can do well in the class!
The class is required, and definitely useful, but the lectures are difficult to follow and take notes in.

PHIL 2415.comment: Honestly, the best professor I've had during my first semester at Cornell. The best introductory course to examine morality at an intersection of Phil, Psych, and Behavioral Econ. Professor Nichols makes lectures super interesting and leaves a lot of space for open discussion. The readings at first can be hard for non-Phil majors but as long as you get the basic idea, Professor Nichols breaks it down and makes sense of everything. Would highly recommend it!

PHIL 2455.comment: Markovits is a great lecturer, to the point where I didn't mind waking up at 9 to go to her lectures, and that's saying something. Lectures & discussion posts based on readings are required for attendance/participation, but discussion posts are easy to BS & lectures are pretty interesting. Final is an easy 100 -- she lets you answer whatever questions you like, and they all count for the same amount. Bulk of the work in this class is the written papers -- I think there were three of them. A clear argument is crucial, but in my experience the prof/TAs are more than willing to completely break it down for you if you put in the effort to meet w them. Overall an interesting, relevant, and not-difficult class.

Really nice intro phil course on bioethics. There are readings and discussion posts before lec, and attendance is marked for lec and section but all the material is interesting and engaging. They're all very relevant topics and lots of the material had me thinking and asking questions about things I hadn't really thought of before. If you've never written for a phil course writing papers might be a little difficult but if you work with your TA and the prof, they're really helpful. There's one final exam but it's easy, short answer questions. Overall, one of the more impactful liberal arts courses I've taken at cornell.

The content of the course is super interesting and engaging. Attendance is mandatory for lecture and discussions but, again, the material during lec is really interesting and I honestly enjoyed some of the discussions I've had with classmates during section. If you've never written for a philosophy course, writing papers might be hard but if you work with your TA and prof, you'll be ok. Overall, one of the more impactful liberal arts courses I've taken at Cornell.

Really good class about bioethics. If you don't really like writing papers and have time thinking about your arguments, it might be tough to write a high quality paper, but overall not too much work aside from reading posts and 3 papers.

This is the best class I've taken at Cornell. The content is so interesting and the workload is really manageable. Prof Markovits is knowledgeable and her lectures are definitely not boring. I highly recommend it to everyone.

PHIL 4720.comment: The class was filled with interesting material, I took it with Abusch in Spring 2018 and we covered implicature, presupposition, focus/theme, and pictures (very briefly towards the end). We spent around 8 weeks on presupposition, so if you aren't prepared for that kind of detail the class might not be for you. The lectures mainly consisted of her writing on the blackboard or reading off handouts and she would explain/ask us questions, but the class size was small enough so it was almost run discussion-style. Readings and attendance are "mandatory" but I'm not sure how much it impacts your grade. We had 3 problem sets, one in class exam, and one take home final, so overall it wasn't too much work. Just understanding the conceptual parts of the course could be tricky and take time to work through.

PHIL 6720.comment: The class was filled with interesting material, I took it with Abusch in Spring 2018 and we covered implicature, presupposition, focus/theme, and pictures (very briefly towards the end). We spent around 8 weeks on presupposition, so if you aren't prepared for that kind of detail the class might not be for you. The lectures mainly consisted of her writing on the blackboard or reading off handouts and she would explain/ask us questions, but the class size was small enough so it was almost run discussion-style. Readings and attendance are "mandatory" but I'm not sure how much it impacts your grade. We had 3 problem sets, one in class exam, and one take home final, so overall it wasn't too much work. Just understanding the conceptual parts of the course could be tricky and take time to work through.

PHYS 1012.comment: Fall 2018 was a flipped classroom style with a reading quiz before every lecture, problem set due every week, and a lab (no postlabs though). The entire lecture is pretty much clicker questions and examples, so if you don't do the reading you won't know what's going on. Jeevak Parpia was not the best lecturer but if you study the textbook material you will do fine.

PHYS 1102.comment: As an autotutorial class, PHYS 1102 is very challenging and should not be taken unless you have a very good grasp of the subject matter. Even then, the class remained hard to achieve a good grade, just based on not being able to miss very many points at all (you can calculate your grade as you go in the course). Do not take this class alongside other very challenging courses, as it takes a lot of time to complete. In spring 2018, they changed course policies to make it slightly less time-consuming, but learning the material on your own does take awhile. That being said, TA's (both undergraduate and graduate) are very helpful to ensure that you are focusing on what you should for exams and labs. Professor Taylor and Professor Giambatista are very nice and willing to meet with you to help you improve in the course.

Prof Taylor and his teaching team are great and very helpful. I really like auto-tutorial classes, because we get extensive help in the study center. Although the material is challenging, Prof Taylor is very nice and willing to help you learn. But be prepared to do a lot of work, and stay on top of your schedule!

PHYS 1110.comment: Just completely pointless. 1 credit course that has a weekly homework, 2 hour lab, and mandatory 1 hour lecture at the worst time slot imaginable (Friday afternoon). You will learn nothing about physics or experimentation. Grading is convoluted and harsh for what the course is. The only reason anyone should ever take is if it is mandatory.

The labs give you the chance to explore a variety of aspects of physics and are not too difficult. The professor actively tries to keep workload at a minimum while keeping the activities interesting. PollEv is used in lecture.

Just a complete waste of time. Grading was not standard across the TAs, and mine graded pretty harshly. There are weekly labs that take forever, and a lot of the equipment didn't work. There were two quizzes and a final. Attendance was required too. I've heard that they make this class easier every semester because it's so useless.

PHYS 1112.comment: Great class. Big time commitment due to mandatory lectures (clickers), discussions, and labs, but this was mostly helpful and we got a lot of practice. Problems were manageable and curve at the end of the class was generous. Fulbright was a good lecturer, Chris Wilson amazing TA.

This class is a massive time commitment, but if you don't mind the flipped lectures and have some basic physics experience from high school, you should be fine. There are some key concepts that the professor shows in lecture, so it might be worthwhile to pay attention. COOPs are fine, and the virtual labs are really a waste of time. Homework is pretty straightforward. There are a lot of exams, but if you know how to study you'll do fine.

Professor Krasicky is amazing, his lectures are extremely engaging and I think he explains concepts very well. The class is well organised so it makes sure that you're always on track. The homeworks were mostly only graded for completion and one question for comprehension so it wasn't super stressful. Office hours are incredibly helpful and reviewing the lecture notes and doing the homework are all you need to do to do well on the exams.
Professor Krasicky makes the lecture really fun with cool demos. The content is not hard if you read the textbook. The exam is fair if you are okay with hw and discussion questions.

I didn't like the flipped classroom and having to teach myself the material by reading the textbook. Sometimes I found myself confused in class because I didn't understand the textbook and in lecture we would go straight to iclicker questions. The course staff were really helpful and always available in lecture to help with the questions. I didn't like the coops in discussion and found the homework a bit challenging. The course staff was very accommodating when we switched to online Spring 2020 and made the second prelim and final open-book, take-home for three days.

PHYS 1116.comment: The median actually is pretty high, but the mean usually screws with the curve, as that's what it's based on. Mean is B/B+ for FA18, but median is A-.

Knowing very little physics, I decided to take this course (fall 2018) because I saw very poor ratings for the chap teaching 1112. Barely survived--went to all the office hours, homework parties, help sessions that I could make. That being said, Alexander was a great prof and so were the TAs. The problem sets are brutal and usually required 10+ hours per week for me, and with other people helping me. The material is difficult but really interesting. Take-home prelims & final. Rather low median (B) for an honors course, though.

Lectures often felt disjointed from the content being covered in the homework and textbook, mostly studied myself and on my own time, certain later topics like oscillators weren't explained well at all. Would not recommend to non-Physics majors, not worth the extra work and challenge. However, the concepts covered were interesting albeit challenging, weekly quizzes were stressful to study for especially after they were decoupled from the homework questions. Prelims felt challenging but felt properly curved. Homework really wasn't an excessive amount, just the individual questions require comprehensive thinking.

I took this course with Prof. Holmes. She didn't tend to do a great job with lectures (they seemed kind of last-minute thrown together), and she wasn't great at explaining material either, even in office hours. The textbook wasn't much help either. The TA was fantastic, and I learned a lot from the discussion sections. There was a problem set each week which took me 4-5 hours. It was extremely difficult, and it seemed like it was intended to compel you to go to the weekly "homework parties" (lengthy, optional class study sections held once a week with the professor, TA, and UTAs). I couldn't really ever do it without help. Additionally, there were weekly discussion section quizzes with a 15-minute time limit, which was kind of tough, but I don't think they affect the overall grade much.
