I took it with Maxson. The class itself is really interesting. There is only one pset a week, but it takes forever to do, and there is a quiz every week. Everyone is just trying to survive this class.

PHYS 1203.comment: Awesome class. Natasha is so passionate about teaching so it was really nice learning from her. Attendance is mandatory. Overall, not too much work and just a few easy assignments (like interviewing people. making decks, easy research). Very good option for fulfilling the CALS science requirements.

Probably the easiest class to fulfill the CALS physics requirement! Literally for your final assignment you can choose to do a book report (I'm talking like middle school style book report--I did mine on the book The Martian) or participate in the semi-related to science class play (either acting or behind scenes). Many opportunities for extra credit too.
Really great and easy class. If you've ever taken physics before, the class is really easy. Even if you haven't, you can still do well. I love Holmes she's very kind and accomodating.

PHYS 2208.comment: Very hard course for honest students due to take home exams.

Professor Case taught Spring 2018. The prelims were take home, but the final was in-person with 2 pages (front and back) of notes/formulas/whatever you wanted and it was brutal. Even though lecture is not mandatory, GO! Definitely always stay on top of this class because you can quickly fall behind because he covers so many topics!

PHYS 2213.comment: My experience with this class was awesome, and that has everything to do with my professor - Ryan Tapping. I think he is new to teaching, but he is truly amazing. Whatever the reviews say about this class from previous semesters (I took this class Fall of 2023) it completely flipped this semester. The overwhelming opinion from the students is that yes, the class is hard, you may not understand the physics, but you will love the professor and the way the class is run. Ryan truly listens to his students. He takes our feedback into account and explains why he is running the course the way he is. He has moved back deadlines for the whole class when students said that they have a stressful week with other prelims / courses. The exams were extremely fair, and the gradings scale is very forgiving. 50% of the grade is just showing up to lecture and turning in the homework. The cut-off for an A- was 85%. Going into the class, I was really nervous because everyone had horror stories and told me to take it at a different college for transfer credit. Ryan Tapping is actively making a difference and trying to change that! Take this class with him!

I had Professor Arias in FA2017. I really enjoyed the flipped classroom format where you watched a video on the topic before class and answered questions about the video and then in class you practice that topic. That forced me to be on top of the material. I would equate the level of difficulty to an AP class, as the math content is very low: a little bit of diff eq (LC circuits) and some surface integrals. Prof. Arias was very helpful during office hours (he would often straight up solve the HW problem) and there was an abundance of office hours w/ TAs.

Ryan Tapping was the absolute best! I took this class during his first semester teaching the course, and he explained everything so clearly. I had learned some E&M concepts back in high school in IB Physics, but none of the circuits or laws made any sense until I learned it here. He's also really nice, one of the only professors who listens to students' issues throughout the semester.
It was a flipped classroom style, so going to lecture was a bit unnecessary. The problem sets were incredibly hard, must go to office hours for them. The actual exams are not as bad, more fair.

I had NamJung this semester. The workload is super heavy. There are pre-lecture quiz, in-lecture quiz, discussion-quiz, and homework. This is the worst workload for a science class I have ever since. The lecture is not helpful at all, you won't learn anything from it. Watching video and asking TA in lab is a much better choice.

PHYS 2214.comment: The course was interesting, but an incredible amount of work. There are 2 lectures, 2 co-ops, lab, 2 reading quizzes, and a p-set each week. Prof. Ralph was very fair about grading (e.g. he accommodated the fact most of the class could not reach the last question of an in-class exam and changed the point distribution so that wouldn't negatively affect most of the class). He was a good lecturer and answered questions well + there are a lot of OHs.

liepe is an excellent professor who truly cares about his students and their success in his class. the prelims were very fair consisting of true-false and slight extensions of course material. the class takes up a lot of time between twice-a-week discussions, lectures, pre-lecture quizzes, in class quizzes, labs, and lengthy problem sets.

The amount of work for this class was genuinely absurd.  2 lectures, 1 quiz, 1pset, 2-3 coop assignments,  a lab, 2 pre-lectures (which normally took as much time as actual lectures), and 2 pre-lecture quizzes per week, generally totaling to about 10 hours of mindnumbing work per week. Most 4 credit courses I've had took up half as much time as this class takes.  Also, the course focuses on learning to plug and chug rather than conceptual understanding.

I personally enjoyed this class quite a bit. Prof. Liepe is more involved in his classes than any professor I've met. There's a lot of support, and it's pretty easy to collaborate and get answers during the study hours (where there are TAs present). The homework is a lot of derivation that is not at all relevant in exams (I guess they're just trying to make you understand) but coops and quizzes are helpful. The workload is quite a lot since they use the backwards approach where you learn the material on your own, take a quiz, then go to lecture where you review, then do lots of practice. Labs were alright

PHYS 2216.comment: Took this fall'20. The concepts in this class are hard, but that's because the whole subject is counter-intuitive. math is fairly easy though and its pass fail, so don't worry too much. We had group quizzes but individual finals.

PHYS 2217.comment: Took this class with Lois Pollack. She is a great professor, and really cares about her students and puts a lot of time into her teaching. The material was spaced out pretty well (although you do have to do the textbook readings or you will fall behind). Problem sets were not super time consuming. I didn't find the prelims to be that hard (although they were in class so we only had 50 minutes to complete them - it was a pretty nasty time crunch, and I never had time to check my work), but the average was very low (we were given points back and curved to a higher grade though).
Very challenging but also very fair psets and prelims. Xu is super underrated as a lecturer and his office hours are great

Definitely the hardest class I've taken here but it's an honors class so that was expected. The medians on the midterm and final were both around 50% and the class curves to a B+ so don't stress if you don't know everything. Problem sets are challenging, so definitely go to office hours, we had a great TA so those helped a lot. Overall I'm glad I took the course
Fun problem sets. Physics is the best. The medians are nice and low so you're not punished for challenging yourself.
Gennady was so bad. This class has no redeeming qualities. Definitely made me change majors.

PHYS 2218.comment: Took this class F2020. I love Ramshaw. Always ready for class and answers all questions. Lab is really neat (its a semester long experimental or research project with a group). Will say it is a bit rushed towards the end and the beginning of the class can be a bit boring, but overall loved this class! weekly homework that aren't too bad, 2 prelims and a non-cumulative final. Will say that the exams are a bit tough, but manageable.
Good course with an awful lab section. Brad is super chill. Bad handwriting though.

Spring 2019                             This course is supposed to be easier than 1116/2217. My semester had a rough time - probably just because of the professor. And there are no good waves textbook, except for a draft of one at http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/djmorin/book.html  (insert a tilde before djmorin).                              Our homework problems were all challenging, so we had no basic or "think-inside-the-box" questions, which made it really difficult to gauge how well I understood the material. Recitation (and its quizzes) was our only place to solidify understanding. Exams were reasonable. The last third of the course is thermo, which is a "new leaf" and the textbook and homework were great.                                        Labs are a joke as always (on the honors track at least). The project lab is kinda cool, especially if you like experimental physics - you're given two months to design and present any experiment, completely open-ended.                                         Median: A

Brad!!! He's an extremely good teacher for someone who's never taught before. his exams can screw you over though (personally don't like the way they were written) and the last few weeks/thermo felt a bit rushed. overall a great class, you probably won't get below a B- unless you do really badly

I had Professor Seamus Davis in SP18. He was funny, but if you aren't good at self learning, he provides no help as he doesn't hold office hours. On the plus side, he only gives one prelim and he gets rid of the lab component of the course. The take home final was very challenging and took me about 40 hours to complete.

PHYS 3310.comment: Very easy, and Prof. Franck is very nice. The labs have precise instructions you just need to follow; honestly a bit too easy, compared to the labs done in 1116 and the rest of the intro sequence.

PHYS 3316.comment: Took it with Tomas Arias.  Great professor, very enthusiastic.  Class used notes that he wrote up as well as Griffiths and  French&Taylor.  Very long and difficult problem sets but tests are fair coverage of the material.

Arias is a great lecturer, as usual. Pretty good class. Problem sets are nontrivial but not significantly worse than any other upper level physics course. Class could've benefited from a bit more coverage of the big picture, but overall was well taught. The textbooks are not needed - don't waste money on them. Arias covers everything you'll need in lecture.
Andre Leclair taught this class when I took it. He's a good professor, if a little dry at times. Make sure to do many practice problems and you'll do well, there's not much surprise on the tests.

Took this class when Prof. Nowack was teaching it. Great introduction to a vast field and Prof. Nowack was one of the best lecturers I've had. No matter which prof. teaches it, the textbook used is Griffith's QM. Well-written book, but results in 20-page+ Psets.

PHYS 3318.comment: Maxson is probably the best lecturer in the Cornell physics department.
It's mandatory, but try not to take it when Jane Wang teaches it. She has students teach most of the class and you end up not covering much material.

PHYS 3360.comment: Kirkland is really funny if you give him a chance. Very informative, if time consuming, class.
Tough class, lots of work. You develop a very good understanding of circuits as a non-ECE though.

An insane amount of work for just 4 credits. Somehow this lab class also has weekly PSets, a prelim, a final, AND a final project. Hoffstaetter blitzes through the material and has by far the worst class logistics and management I've ever had the misfortune to experience. Run for the hills. Take it in spring with Kirkland.

I wouldn't take this course again if I were held at gunpoint. Holy hell on a stick, every moment of this class was misery. The only organization came from the lab manual, the professor had no idea how to teach this stuff properly and it reflects in how clueless and silent the class was whenever asked a question. Canvas was rarely used, we never were given a grading scheme, the final sucked caterpillar balls, and good lord the lab work. Oh my god. This class is easily 6-8 credits worth of work. Do not touch this course with a 40 foot pole unless you absolutely have to.

Took this class in Spring 2019 with Professor Kirkland.  One of my favorite classes with super interesting and applicable material. Not too difficult if you're comfortable with pre-reqs (E/M, math). Definitely very time consuming (two three hour labs a week, and you definitely need all that time) but overall the payoff is worth it. Professor Kirkland is also really nice and funny and very helpful on labs and homeworks.

PHYS 4488.comment: Great class! Problem sets were sometimes difficult,  but interesting and they covered a wide variety of topics and fields which definitely inspired further research and reading. The flipped classroom element worked very well and allowed us to cover a considerable amount of material.

The flipped classroom structure is quite effective in extracting work from students. If one is willing to do the readings and homework ahead of time, there is an incredible amount to benefit. Unfortunately, the amount of actual teaching that takes place is somewhat minimal.

PHYS 6562.comment: Great class! Problem sets were sometimes difficult,  but interesting and they covered a wide variety of topics and fields which definitely inspired further research and reading. The flipped classroom element worked very well and allowed us to cover a considerable amount of material.

The flipped classroom structure is quite effective in extracting work from students. If one is willing to do the readings and homework ahead of time, there is an incredible amount to benefit. Unfortunately, the amount of actual teaching that takes place is somewhat minimal.

PLSCI 1115.comment: Pretty chill class. Met once a week when I took it and we just did labs and nothing that was particularly difficult. There's some work but it's not a lot.

PLSCI 2013.comment: Kathie Hodge is a lovely professor and makes lectures so enjoyable. If you take the PLSCI 2010 option, you are only responsible for studying for prelims and showing up to class. I learned so much from this course!

Really interesting content, exams were fair. labs + lectures are not too much work but there are 2 midterms, a final, group project and 1 essay. Professor is super engaging and would recommend taking this class!

PMA 1157.comment: She's a great teacher but her grading is extremely biased. There were no updates on grades throughout the semester and you only know your grade at the end. The class is not hard but if she does not like you, you will not get a good grade. Besides the grading, the class was simple and unique.

I really liked this class because we got to watch a lot of horror movies. The professor is really nice and is willing to help you with essays if you have difficulty and also allows you extensions if you ask in time. The workload consisted of readings and movies. The readings can be difficult sometimes, but it is best if you attempt to read it because she cold calls sometimes.

PMA 2220.comment: Absolutely fantastic course (and counts as a liberal studies). Nic was incredibly kind and really wanted everyone to learn and have fun while still teaching very useful technical skills. Even in the Covid era he still made class both fun and accessible regardless of where you were or how much space you had. If Nic is still the teacher when Covid-19 is over absolutely take this course.

PMA 2800.comment:
Very fun and no workload but there were occasional readings and presentations.

However, I was bad at acting, so I always stressed when I had to perform.
Carolyn is better than the other professors. More random exercises, less actual drama/acting stuff. Attendance is very very strict. Would recommend 10/10. Good job.

Excellent course! Carolyn is the best and cares so much for her students. She has lots of fun exercises for us that help us bond closer together, so that when we do somewhat awkward stuff in acting or stand up in front of the class to perform a scene, it feels a lot easier. Almost no work outside of class (kinda wish there was more as I felt we could've learned more) but it was a chill time.
One of my favorite classes at Cornell! I learned so much about how to express myself and get out of my comfort zone. A little more work than expected, but highly recommend to everyone!
I loved this class, reasonable workload and is super fun. Definitely take this class if you can!!

PMA 3550.comment: The title of the class is “Global Cinema and Media” now, but it was really enjoyable we watched a film every single class (2x a week 2.5 hrs/class) that covered films from the start and went to many different countries and languages. Only a few assignments and the professor is really understanding.

PMA 3570.comment: PMA 3570 is supposed to be Film and Video Production I. Professor Jeff is genuinely empathetic and understanding, which is a big plus considering the class spans seven hours a week. The course offers access to expensive equipment, presenting a fantastic opportunity for hands-on learning, though there's the responsibility of covering costs for any damages. If you have spare time and are interested in creating your own short film, I'd highly recommended this class. The actual filming only occurs in the last month, which can be a bit frustrating, but that's when most of the practical learning happens. Despite his teaching style being more lecture-based and not always effective, the unique experience of a film class makes it worth considering.

PMA 3680.comment: Definitely a bit boring at times if you already have experience with sound design and production. Professor Cross is really knowledgable and super cute and caring. The class is what you make of it
Warren Cross is extremely knowledgable in the field and extremely accomodating during COVID really enjoyed the lectures and the projects were straightforward and not very time consuming
Very easy course, but Prof. Cross is rather disorganized (and covid didn't help). Assumes basically no prior knowledge going in, which is helpful.

PMA 3805.comment: I took this class as a non-PMA major and loved it! It was fun to read plays, collaborate and workshop with other students, and in general just tap in to my creativity.  Prof. Stratford is a wonderful and kind professor who is super knowledgable and involved in the local theater scene.

I loved this class! Prof Stratford is great and leads super helpful discussions. In this class you'll learn how to write 10-minute plays (you'll write two plays) and read lots of examples for inspiration.  It's not technically part of the Creative Writing track (I think it's mostly PMA students who take it), but it's a great elective to take if you're a CW student anyway!

PSYCH 1101.comment: Pizarro's the coolest prof out there. He's a sneakerhead, and he's got stellar taste in music. Very light workload. Only open book weekly quizzes and a final that's de facto based on the quizzes. It is a lot of memorization, but it's overall an easy A, and if you put in a smidge of effort, you can even squeak out an A plus. First few quizzes will be tough as you get used to the format of the questions but 2 lowest quizzes get dropped. There is also five percent extra credit on top of everything for participating in psych department experiments. The content itself is super engaging and interesting.
There is a ton of memorization required. A lot of small details from the book. Even though it may sound easy, it really becomes difficult when you have 600 pages to memorize.
Teacher was very nice and course was easy and interesting
Easy and simple class. Professor teaches very well and likes to tell jokes in lecture. The only work is some readings (which I didn't do) and weekly quizzes. Also, make sure to do the extra credit.
Loved the professor, made learning very fun. Highly recommend for a distribution!

PSYCH 1130.comment: I took "Navigating the World through the Senses" and really enjoyed it. There were many opportunities for class discussions, and we wrote five essays overall (for most of them, we could choose the topic).

PSYCH 1140.comment: Course is very chill. The amount of assignments is okay but the grading is really easy. Vivian is a very understanding teacher and will give extensions if needed. The readings aren't too bad they are pretty straight forward and interesting. It is definitely more on a history side than the psychology side, but still pretty relevant to the world today.

Took this class with Karen Sasmita who had very clear plans of what this class was and spent the entire semester building one final research proposal. The inclass activities are very engaging and purposeful. Definitely recommend if you are looking into getting into research

Took it with Karen Sasmita- SEM 101 on event segmentation. Our assignments essentially all lead up to one final research proposal, so you just keep building on one topic throughout the whole semester. The workload doesn't seem very heavy because each graded assignment would be just one portion of your proposal (ex. introduction is due one week, methodology is due the 2 weeks later). During class, we discuss research papers that we have to read ahead of class. She seems to grade pretty generously  (has lots of homework graded on completion) and also very understanding if you ask for an extension.

This is not a rating for Kacie Armstorong but my professor is not up there. I took this class with Mary Elson. Elson is great, so helpful and always there to help! Shes super passionate about animals cognition and behavior and really wants to see us succeed! good class.

Super interesting class discussions. Grading a little harsh with a fair amount of work spread out (but around what you would expect for an fws). A lot of scientific writing so dont take this class if youre already in a lot of science classes and you get sick of doing scientificbpaoers and proposals.

PSYCH 2050.comment: Fall 2017 with Cutting. 2 prelims, 1 final, but you get to drop the worst exam. Exams are very detailed and mostly short response, so make sure you have the material memorized. Lectures were decent, pretty interesting at times, but they're mandatory because of in-class "essays" which were really just a couple sentences to answer a basic question from the previous lecture.

Professor gives incredible lectures full of interesting visuals and clearly loves the subject. You have to attend class and read the textbook or you will not know what you need and the prelims are very in depth. A basic understanding of the brain is not required but recommended and this should not be the first psychology class you take.

PSYCH 2090.comment: Jennifer Schwade (Spring 2018). If you attend class and take notes on her PowerPoints, you should do well on the exams. Her PowerPoints are very sparse and don't make sense, so you need those notes. You don't need to do the readings (unless you're confused and need further background information) because she explains what you need to know in class. She gives you a review sheet of all the questions you need to know for the exam and if you memorize that, you're all set for the exam. It's a low key class. I didn't enjoy it though because the class consist of only lectures with minimal discussion/input from students and the logic used for these infant/children studies just don't make sense to me.

Professor Goldstein is a very engaging lecturer and it's clear he's passionate about what he's teaching. The course covers a variety of topics, so it moves relatively quickly. While attendance is not recorded, he covers a lot of information that isn't on the slides, so I would highly recommend attending (and I enjoyed these lectures. There were weekly quizzes on readings (interesting reads, mostly about experiments). Prelims were somewhat lengthy, but he provides a list of topics prior and I don't remember any questions being big surprises (i.e. they were mentioned in the outline document).

Expected to learn more psych and fun facts about little kids but lecture discussed a lot of technical readings & experiments. I think I fell asleep in almost every lecture. Prelims were lowkey mad hard because there's so much information to learn, but I didn't study much so that's on me. Goldstein's study guides are extremely long but cover pretty much everything u need to know for the exam. If you're interested in psych but not interested in the science side of it I recommend taking another course.
2090 (Michael goldstein) is pretty dull. The name of the class is intriguing but be prepared to fall asleep because it gets boring. Decent amount of work and the prelims are hard.
Mike Goldstein is the most passionate and knowledgable professor I have ever met at Cornell. Great class ever, strongly recommend.

PSYCH 2150.comment: The class is taught by a passionate professor but it is not good. As a psych major, this class covered more of a linguistic perspective which I did not enjoy. The TAs grading is pretty hard and usually, they could not help you with questions. I do not consider it an easy A
Really interesting class, especially if you put in effort to learn. Practically no work at all too, except studying for the prelims. Professor is very good too.

A great introduction to psycholinguistics with a great lecturer. Professor Christiansen makes each class easy to digest, and his presentation of each topic is intriguing and humorous at times. For my class, he did not assign homework and only had three prelims and a final essay, which were all writing-based. As long as you attend lecture and review the content of each lecture before the prelim, it is not hard to get a good grade. The prelims are not cumulative, and there is also an extra credit option. Definitely would recommend to anyone looking for a liberal studies class that is easy and interesting.
even though it wasn't my interest area exactly, the professor made this class' content accessible and fun to learn. I'd recommend this class to anyone!

PSYCH 2650.comment:
This is one of my favorite classes I took at Cornell, but objectively one of the hardest. They do cold calling, rotate professors, and some of the work is very challenging, but a rewarding experience for those interested in the field of law.

Assigned seats and cold calling make it a little more tense in the class, but become friendly with the people near you!
Prof Hans and Prof Rachlinski are the best professors I've had at Cornell. The workload is not small - be prepared to do some readings!

One of the most interesting classes Ive taken at Cornell. It is essential that you thoroughly do all reading homework because they cold call students in class. This can be stressful at first but is honestly not a huge deal. I honestly never felt bored, and as long as you show up to every class (attendance is huge) and take good notes you'll do well

Loved this class! Hans and Rachlinski banter like an old married couple (can be awkward at times), but the class content is incredibly interesting. Make sure to do the readings as their prelims demand VERY precise answers, but the TAs are understanding and cold calls are not that scary! Would try to take if possible!

this class is pretty good, but there is quite a decent amount of work to be done. the readings are pretty lengthy & I'd REALLY recommend taking notes for all the readings (which adds hours of work on top of everything). It's also a pretty difficult class, as in the exams are REALLY tricky & it'll be pretty hard to get an A in this class. But this class is really interesting & the professors are really great lecturers. Both of them know how to make the class lively. The cold-calling is intimidating at first, but once you see some people say a couple of dumb answers, the pressure is taken off.

PSYCH 2800.comment: I thought the contents of the course were quite interesting! The workload is quite minimal--just exams and a final paper. While attendance is not required, it's helpful to attend as he sometimes only covers things while talking about slides in lectures that may not show up in the textbook. Similarly, some topics are only covered in the textbook. I enjoyed reading and taking the course regardless. Exams were sometimes quite specific, but generally they were manageable with some studying.

The class material is super interesting and honestly one of my favourite classes. The textbook reading is interesting and the lectures are too. Only thing I would watch for is that exam questions are oddly specific and draw from readings, textbook, and lecture.

This was the best non-major class I have taken at Cornell so far. To date, it is has been the only class that I have never skipped lecture for. Professor Gilovich is an outstanding lecturer and always keeps his lectures entertaining with pop culture references and details about interesting psychological experiments. The workload for this class isn't bad: two multiple choice exams, a quiz, and a final. The tests are pretty in depth though and consistently attending lecture and reading the textbook are crucial for doing well. Highly recommend this class to anyone who wants an interesting class to fulfill a distribution requirement.

The content is pretty interesting, but would not recommend this class for those with a heavy workload from other classes. The textbook readings seldom overlap with the lecture content, so a lot of time is spent self-studying the textbook material outside of class. However, you can do well if you have time to study the material properly.  Professor Gilovich is also a fun prof to learn with!

Really good class but the exams are HARD: questions are REALLY specific and tricky. They are badly formulated and might be tricky.  I found the material really interesting and the lectures engaging but I do not consider this class easy. 2 prelims, one research paper, one quiz, and a final.

PSYCH 2940.comment: There are a lot of interesting material and concepts taught in this class. It's still fairly new so they are still working out the kinks. While you get the opportunity to learn lots of material, I wish the lectures focused more on real-life applications. Overall, one gets a solid behavioral economics and psychology framework to understand decision making.

PSYCH 2940.professor: J. Russo, Robert Frank, Ted O'Donoghue, Tom Gilovich, William Schulze
PSYCH 2940.comment: This class has been one of my favorite classes at Cornell. The professors are all super knowledgable, and the content of this class is so applicable to everyday and future life. This is the type of class that has lessons you will take away forever. There are no homeworks except for some readings, 2 prelims and 1 final paper.

PSYCH 2940.professor: J. Russo, Robert Frank, Ted O'Donoghue, Tom Gilovich, William Schulze
PSYCH 2940.comment: Took this because I thought itd be an easy distribution req but I shouldve put more effort in. Was quite low workload just prelims and class participation but the exam questions were really obscure.

PSYCH 2940.professor: J. Russo, Robert Frank, Ted O'Donoghue, Tom Gilovich
PSYCH 2940.comment: The class is open notes. However, the questions in this class are so specific that it is very difficult to do well. Though, the curve is ok, as I think the average with curve was a B

PSYCH 2940.professor: J. Russo, Robert Frank, Ted O'Donoghue, Tom Gilovich, William Schulze
PSYCH 2940.comment: Interesting class with enjoyable material to learn and a really organized canvas page. HOWEVER, the grading system is really bad. You are graded on just two prelims, 25% each, and a final, 50% which I believe is a LOT. You just get 1% of extra credit from 5 SONA points... Exams are online and open notes but really hard and you do not get the answers back so you are not able of analyzing your mistakes and learn from them. I took the class as a freshman psych major and do not recommend doing this. As a whole, I liked the material but the grading system is bad.

PSYCH 3140.comment: This is potentially the weirdest class I've ever taken at Cornell. Professor Edelman wrote the textbook that you have to buy, then quoted himself in the lecture slides that he wrote as if he didn't write the textbook. This entire discipline seemed like something that he made up himself so he could teach a class about it and hear himself talk. Your entire grade in the class is 3 exams that are legit 5 multiple choice questions and 2 short answers. I got a 75 on one of the exams I studied hard for and a 98 on one of the exams where I legitimately made everything up. This class legit could be an easy A or an easy D it's unpredictable. Don't go to lecture because it is painfully boring to sit through and do the readings before the exam and hope for the best. But also just don't take this class.

I thought the premise of the course would be interesting, but I think the lectures tended to be quite lengthy and slides contained a lot of content. It's clear the Professor is knowledgeable, but it's a lot of information at once. We just had weekly mini-essays and annotations on Perusal that were not very hard.

Professor Edelman really changed up the structure of the class in response to virtual class and he seems to care about his students. A virtual semester consists of small weekly readings with annotations on Perusall and a weekly micro essay about the topic of the week with a max of 500 words. Topics are really interesting and light work kept me motivated, but I could see how a semester with prelims and finals could make the content seem tedious.

PSYCH 3150.comment: I took this course hybrid. The content is super engaging and interesting, and I think that the class is well structured to allow people to succeed. The grade for the course was based on two prelims and a short research paper on a topic. Going to the review sessions and really taking the time to think about and form answers to those questions prepares you really well, and following the guidelines for the research paper will have you set to do well.

Definitely very doable! If you took NS 1150, this is very similar- Dr. Levitsky repeats information presented.  Dan Berry provided pretty interesting information as well. Lectures were recorded, which was super helpful for reviewing content. Overall, I enjoyed the class a lot.
Not too bad, similar content to NS 1150 but half of it's new (the part taught by Dan Barry

PSYCH 3310.comment: I really enjoyed this class with Prof. Mendle. First of all,  Prof. Mendle is a really nice professor, and I thought her lectures were great. I haven't taken many PSYCH classes, but she reviewed concepts to help catch people up. I thought the class was overall really interesting, and the assignments were fun to complete. I definitely would recommend this class :)

PSYCH 3420.comment: One of my favorite classes this semester! We get to learn about a lot of interesting topics and watch cool videos in class. Only workload is for prelims. I definitely would recommend this class to others.
This is a great course! Interesting material, not too much work. Plus it counts as an engineering tech elective.

Great class led by a great professor (David Field). Lectures are really interesting, full of in-class demos and videos. There's two prelims and one final -- and for all of these, he'll give you a question bank out of which questions will be picked. There's a few (around 5-6) easy in-class quizzes at random points, so it's good to attend class though not crucial. You can get by without going to class, but I'd highly recommend going to class because it's very interesting!

A very interesting class full of demos, videos and examples for pretty much every topic we cover! The professor is super nice, very knowledgeable and has tons of interesting, relevant facts to share. There is not much workload like no assignments just the exams and sometimes in-class quizzes. The content is not difficult to understand. Highly recommend this course!

Loved this class!  Very interesting material (explaining cool optical illusions), friendly professor, and only work is the 2 prelims and the final.  I took it during covid so exams were online which likely made them easier, but even without that I think it would be a pretty low effort and fun class.

PSYCH 6140.comment: This is potentially the weirdest class I've ever taken at Cornell. Professor Edelman wrote the textbook that you have to buy, then quoted himself in the lecture slides that he wrote as if he didn't write the textbook. This entire discipline seemed like something that he made up himself so he could teach a class about it and hear himself talk. Your entire grade in the class is 3 exams that are legit 5 multiple choice questions and 2 short answers. I got a 75 on one of the exams I studied hard for and a 98 on one of the exams where I legitimately made everything up. This class legit could be an easy A or an easy D it's unpredictable. Don't go to lecture because it is painfully boring to sit through and do the readings before the exam and hope for the best. But also just don't take this class.

I thought the premise of the course would be interesting, but I think the lectures tended to be quite lengthy and slides contained a lot of content. It's clear the Professor is knowledgeable, but it's a lot of information at once. We just had weekly mini-essays and annotations on Perusal that were not very hard.

Professor Edelman really changed up the structure of the class in response to virtual class and he seems to care about his students. A virtual semester consists of small weekly readings with annotations on Perusall and a weekly micro essay about the topic of the week with a max of 500 words. Topics are really interesting and light work kept me motivated, but I could see how a semester with prelims and finals could make the content seem tedious.

PSYCH 7090.comment: Jennifer Schwade (Spring 2018). If you attend class and take notes on her PowerPoints, you should do well on the exams. Her PowerPoints are very sparse and don't make sense, so you need those notes. You don't need to do the readings (unless you're confused and need further background information) because she explains what you need to know in class. She gives you a review sheet of all the questions you need to know for the exam and if you memorize that, you're all set for the exam. It's a low key class. I didn't enjoy it though because the class consist of only lectures with minimal discussion/input from students and the logic used for these infant/children studies just don't make sense to me.

Professor Goldstein is a very engaging lecturer and it's clear he's passionate about what he's teaching. The course covers a variety of topics, so it moves relatively quickly. While attendance is not recorded, he covers a lot of information that isn't on the slides, so I would highly recommend attending (and I enjoyed these lectures. There were weekly quizzes on readings (interesting reads, mostly about experiments). Prelims were somewhat lengthy, but he provides a list of topics prior and I don't remember any questions being big surprises (i.e. they were mentioned in the outline document).

Expected to learn more psych and fun facts about little kids but lecture discussed a lot of technical readings & experiments. I think I fell asleep in almost every lecture. Prelims were lowkey mad hard because there's so much information to learn, but I didn't study much so that's on me. Goldstein's study guides are extremely long but cover pretty much everything u need to know for the exam. If you're interested in psych but not interested in the science side of it I recommend taking another course.
2090 (Michael goldstein) is pretty dull. The name of the class is intriguing but be prepared to fall asleep because it gets boring. Decent amount of work and the prelims are hard.
Mike Goldstein is the most passionate and knowledgable professor I have ever met at Cornell. Great class ever, strongly recommend.

RELST 2250.comment: The class has pretty interesting topics but the readings are often pretty grueling to go through just because of how dense they are. Overall not too much work and weekly responses are pretty quick to do!

Definitely worth taking if you are genuinely interesting in doctrines of Eastern thought. I have a lot of friends who took it just for college requirements who did not feel motivated at all from the material and ended up hating the class. If you have genuine interest, this class will feel very fulfilling and its easy-med workload will def be more than manageable

This class is a lot of reading and writing every week. The lectures were sometimes boring, but it did increase my interest in Asian religions. Professors and TAs are generally nice and understanding as well.
Super interesting class with not too much work. Midterm essay, final essay, and weekly responses. No textbook work and the assigned readings are pretty interesting and usually not too long.
Lectures could be boring, wish he would give us some sort of notes for each lecture because he talks so fast/scrambling to write down what he says.

ROMS 1102.comment: This class was a decent amount of work but not overload. I liked the structure of the course because it was easy to follow and maintained a good pace. One thing is that Julia is quite a harsh grader and tends to give pretty aggressive feedback. Overall it's a decent option but to be honest, sometimes her attitude during class makes it unenjoyable and a little intimidating.

Good course. Weekly readings aren't too hefty and weekly writing assignments are fairly doable. 5 total writing assignments. Professor is good at teaching rhetoric and storytelling, actual reading content can be difficult/boring but class is overall enjoyable.

ROMS 1108.comment: Prof Rodriguez is super sweet and understanding but she does not tell you anything about your grade until the very end of the semester. She has a "grading contract" that essentially guarantees you will get a B or above, as long as you show up, participate, and do the work. However, you will have no idea if you are getting a B+, A-, A, A+, etc. She doesn't give much feedback on work throughout the semester, most things are peer reviews. There are only 5 essays, for which the prompts are very open-ended, but she is also very open-ended when it comes to grading and will accept a wide range of things. Show up, do the readings, put effort into the essays and you will do really well in this class.

ROMS 1109.comment: Nick is really amazing. I enjoyed this class way more than I thought I would and learned a lot from him. Super engaging and genuinely cares about each of his students. I really hope he can tenured because he would be such a big asset to Cornell.
He is an amazing instructor with big interest in French generally. However, the workloads is a little bit heavy compared with other FWS, but the movies are really fun!

ROMS 1113.comment: I had professor Irene Eibstein-Alvisi, and as a comp sci engineering major I didn't expect to like my FWS class that much, yet this became my favorite class of the semester! I never really learned about Dante or his work before, and this class not only taught me about Inferno, but also the mindset of reading with intention that can be applied to much more than just this literature. Additionally, professor does spend a lot of one-on-one time with the students (if you are willing and actually schedule the meetings) to improve writing. Honestly, I think my idea of writing and ability has much improved over the semester, especially as she teaches a much better view than what high school teachers are able to explain. Overall, I would totally take this class again, I'd just recommend maybe some knowledge about christian religion as I had none, but it may be useful for the class. Even though I didn't start with the knowledge, I did learn over the course and was able to do fine. The only small downside, I'd say, is the workload of completing journals for each class and essay deadlines springing up, but it's not too bad compared to other courses, and the journals are technically only due by the end of the semester (but do them on time!)

IEA very clearly cares a lot about her class and her role as a teacher. She is there to help you improve in your writing and will NOT give an easy A for FWS. However, she will give a lot of feedback and help you get better. The class itself was interesting and IEA knew a lot about what she was saying. Overall, do not take this class expecting an easy A, but if you put in the work and clearly try to improve, she will give you a good grade and you'll learn a fair amount. Def more than what other FWS's are work-wise though.

I took this class with Vanessa Gubbins in Fall 2022. It was about dreams in literature specifically. I really enjoyed the course. She graded generously, gave good feedback, and was understanding if you needed an extension.

Took "On Love" with Itziar and it was a really interesting class. Most readings and films were fun to read/watch and we spent class analyzing different sections. Workload is what you would except from a typical FWS- 5 essays, 1st one is ungraded, then they inc in length from 2-3pgs to 8-10pgs I believe. She doesn't grade the essays so you only know your final grade after sem ends but should be relatively easy to get an A as long as you put in the work.

Took Dante's Inferno. Honestly was expecting to be bored constantly, but this class was genuinely interesting, especially when analyzing key symbolism or historical context within the cantos. Essay topics were also engaging, apart from the first one. Professor was funny and got us to engage in the class, and was very helpful with writing feedback on our essays. Would recommend.

ROMS 3210.comment: This is by far one of the coolest linguistics classes I've taken. Although it did require a lot of memorization of sound changes, the lectures followed the textbook very closely so studying wasn't too difficult. Professor Alkire is so nice and extremely knowledgeable about the subject - he had an answer to pretty much every random question brought up in class, and if he didn't, he went to the library for the answer and told us during the next class. Workload is pretty light but there is some rather dense reading. He said at the beginning that "As long as you show up to lecture and try your best you'll get a good grade." Material is super interesting if you like romance languages. I've never really been a phonetics/phonology person but this class may have changed that - our relative chronology problems are actually pretty fun. The final is a take-home exam and there's a couple of quizzes, in-class exercises, and short homeworks.

RUSSA 1122.professor: Raissa Krivitsky, Slava Paperno, Viktoria Tsimberov
RUSSA 1122.comment: Hard but professors are understanding. Extremely rewarding class
Meets 5 days a week, sometimes twice a day if you take the supplement. It is a lot of time commitment but it works and if you put in the work you will most likely get an A.

SOC 1101.comment: Love the class and professor so much!
The lecturer is so engaging and clearly passionate about the course. Also very fair and easy workload and testwise!! Definitely recommend.

The workload is reasonably balanced, including weekly readings that're closely tied to the prelim exams, ensuring that students are well-prepared. The lectures are engaging, often featuring stimulating discussions. A notable aspect of the course is Professor Sullivan's evident passion for the subject matter, which adds depth and interest to the learning experience.
Great class, I had Sullivan who was an engaging and fair professor.

Professor Bischoff is super nice and topics are interesting. Three in-class prelims, three 3 page papers, and then a longer final paper. Readings are tested fairly heavily but in lecture and discussion the readings are explained pretty thoroughly. I found discussion section super helpful

SOC 2100.comment: 400 word response per week, midterm and final. Interesting and fairly easy.

SOC 2190.comment: This is a really interesting course. Professor Nee is an expert in the field and I really like how he initially taught the course the foundations/history of the field then had us do a large-scale case study applying the concepts. Definitely not too hard--writing responses each week and a few longer essays.

SOC 2202.comment: Lecture was boring, but wasn't the most difficult course... Professor was weird and very long winded lectures the entire class.

SOC 2208.comment: Super interesting class, not as difficult/intimidating as it seemed in the beginning! Professor is humorous and makes lectures fun.

I absolutely adored this class! Professor Weeden was a great, engaging lecturer and I felt that I learned a lot of information (for the introductory level of sociology) and felt that many of the concepts were applicable to our everyday world. Professor Weeden explains topics very well during lecture. Exams were not difficult--you get a list of topics (I believe) and you'll be tested on those topics. Questions were not tricky questions and fairly straightforward.

The content is engaging and highly relevant to understanding what is happening around is on a day to day basis. There are a lot of readings, but they are generally pretty interesting. Professor Weeden has informative slides with plenty of qualitative and quantitative information, whether or not she goes over the readings varies from lecture to lecture. I suggest summarizing each reading as well as taking note of important data so you can refer back to them easily for the prelims and memos. Prepare to by analytical for these; it will not just depend on how well you can remember the material.
Dr. Alvarado is one of the most fair teachers I have ever had, as well as super relatable. Lectures can be dry sometimes but sometimes the content is extremely interesting.

SOC 2710.comment: I LOVED this class!!  Prof Sipple is so knowledgeable and clearly passionate about the material.  The lectures could be a little scattered, but if you're interested in education, this course provided so much food for thought.

I love this class!! Content is so interesting and Sipple really cares about the topic and the class. Would 100% recommend. There are weekly annotations which aren't hard just annoying busy work, but that is the bulk of the class. There are no prelims; just a midterm outline assignment, a final paper, and a final.

SOC 3060.comment: Great professor, engaging material, in class quiz once a week and final paper. All manageable if you attend and read.

SOC 3580.comment: This class is awesome!! HW is reading research papers (but most of the time they're genuinely really interesting) and every other week you write up a 2-page summary about the papers you read. There's a midterm and a final but questions are straightforward based on the readings and a question bank is provided ahead of time. Prof Young is so cool and fun, really recommend this class!

This class is awesome. Super light workload, but a chance to survey a bunch of genuinely really interesting current research in the social sciences. Young leads engaging lectures and class discussions.,

SOC 3710.comment: I took this course with Professor Hirschl. I liked his DSOC 1101 course so I thought that this would be a nice course to take! The grading was particularly hard but the material was very interesting to learn.

SOC 5710.comment: I LOVED this class!!  Prof Sipple is so knowledgeable and clearly passionate about the material.  The lectures could be a little scattered, but if you're interested in education, this course provided so much food for thought.

I love this class!! Content is so interesting and Sipple really cares about the topic and the class. Would 100% recommend. There are weekly annotations which aren't hard just annoying busy work, but that is the bulk of the class. There are no prelims; just a midterm outline assignment, a final paper, and a final.

SPAN 1230.comment: Professor cared a lot about students and was engaging. There is a lot of work, almost every night and at least 1 quiz each week. Tests were not bad. Grading was slightly based on how much she liked students. Participation helps a lot.

Lots of Spanish and lots of work. Very grammar heavy and not very interesting. A huge weight is placed on participation and the grading was a bit harsh. I guess my Spanish did improve in the end, but meeting 4 times a week was not very fun.

Not the best experience over zoom. Very harsh participation grades that didn't account for connectivity issues (couldn't hear/understand prof and other students a lot). A ton of disorganized busy work. Prof made a mistake calculating my final grade and refused to acknowledge it and didn't change my final grade

Not my favorite class especially over zoom. Participation grades are very harsh especially considering I could barely hear the professor or other students due to connectivity issues. There's a lot of disorganized busy work
I took the class with Paulo and it was a really good time. It was pretty hard for me, but I felt like my Spanish improved a lot over just a few months and they examinations were really fair

SPAN 2070.comment: I want to preface by saying that spanish is my weakness and I didn't really want to take about spanish class after high school but alas... CAS language requirement. The professor for this class is really nice but be prepared for a relatively difficult class and workload. There is homework due every class (class meets 3 times a week). The workload in this class was quite a lot for me personally. On top of constant hw to learn new grammar, we also had to watch videos in spanish and fill out hw based on comprehension. We would also have exams about every 2 weeks (mix of online prelims, orals, writings, etc). On top of that, we also had to do an exchange with a colombian student, which required a zoom meeting or email every week and a journal entry. The only nice thing about this class compared to SPAN 2090 is that you do a final presentation instead of an exam and both classes probably have a similar workload

The professor of this class was very understanding and kind. The bulk of the class was learning grammar, and attendance and homework were graded daily. The exams were straightforward if you understand the concepts taught in class/through the homeworks and textbook.

Daily homework assignments, but easy to complete. Course content includes both grammar and relevant medical vocab. Difficulty depends on your Spanish ability coming in, but tests were fair and not too hard. Participation/attendance counts. Bevia really cares about her students and is very flexible. Course includes a Zoom exchange with a Colombian college student which is super interesting but requires weekly reflection assignments.

SPAN 2090.comment: This class is similar to the workload and structure of hs AP Spanish. Prof is nice and helpful esp with office hours. Readings and films are based on intriguing cultural topics. Classes are groupwork and discussion focused and participation isn't required. Only downside would be that it is quite a lot of hw- 1-2hrs for every class. Exams are essentially all grammar- which I found harder than hs level.

High workload, content wasn't too tough coming from AP Spanish but came to dislike the homework (1.5-2.5 hrs of HW for every class). Tests based on grammar, 2 essays, and 2 oral presentations which are recorded on Zoom. Most of class time spent discussing the HW and working on grammar. Felt that my Spanish improved somewhat.

Harder than it should be for a mandatory class. Homework is made to take up to two hours and is due before every class. Tests are difficult but fair. Professor was nice but had to follow a strict curriculum. Definitely not a class I would take if I had a choice, but it is what it is.

This class has a larger focus on speaking during class, but most assessments are based on grammar that you practice orally in class and through written homework 3x a week. You can't expect to get through this class without talking because the class sizes are fairly small and the entire class is pretty much talking though. Kelly is super enthusiastic and cool and tried to make our class interesting even during a virtual semester.

It was her first year teaching but I thought she did a great job at making sure that everyone participated and improved their Spanish skills. It was definitely a lot of work if you wanted to keep up and do well in the class. I think the most challenging parts were definitely how comprehensive the testing was because we had vocabulary, grammar, orals, essays, etc.

SPAN 2095.comment: Great class! Profa. Maldonado-Mendez was very kind and engaging. We spent a lot of time in small group discussion. Weekly review of grammar concepts is independent, but you can bring questions to class if you want clarification on anything.

This class was so much work which consisted of readings, movies, and grammar exercises (although grammar was optional). While the workload was intense, I loved the class because Lawless was super engaging and we had a great discussion in every class.
[SP20] Prof.  Amigo-Silvestre is nice, but the workload is too much. I've heard great things about other professors though (Lawless)!

I have had guest lectures with Cecelia before, but I actually took this class last year with Tomas Bevia (his name wasn't on the dropdown menu). This class was fantastic and made me want to pursue the spanish major, largely based off of my experience with Tomas. He was an extremely engaging professor who showed his love for the course material by leading very insightful discussions, and there was always a wide variety of ways in which material was taught and in which we were assessed (quizzes, presentations, skits, etc). Overall great class and I highly recommend it!
Great class! Take this with Cecelia. She's an amazing spanish teacher. Very manageable workload and material is pretty interesting.

SPAN 2130.comment: The solid class that will help you improve your Spanish. However, it is relatively similar to other Spanish classes offered in Cornell and you will not be required to talk much more than you would in other small, discussion-based seminars. The professor is really fun but can also be strict at times. You read/watch a variety of interesting works and there is a slight focus on scriptwriting. Would recommend if you are interested in Spanish, yet do not take it because you think this will help your speaking enormously more than other classes.

SPAN 2170.comment: The professor was great but as someone who is not a native speaker of Spanish, I found this class to be very challenging. I took this class after completing SPAN 2095 and I would recommend taking other higher-level classes before taking this one. Since the readings are from the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the old Spanish used is different from modern-day Spanish and is much more difficult to understand. The class also included a lot of class discussions which was difficult for me since many of the other students were native speakers.

SPAN 2180.comment:
The course has small class size which makes it very interactive, you really get to know your peers and Professor. It is a LOT of reading and writing, like almost a ridiculous amount but the grading is fair. It is not difficult to do well in the class. She does cold call so do your readings or make sure you're good at bsing. The readings are fairly interesting and she is certainly a character. 

Keep in mind that I am a native speaker so my experience may be affected by this.
Love this class and Professor Lawless is a great conversation starter! My writing improved and my reading skill definitely improved. Participation matters!

This class requires some work but ends up being a very good time. You read very interesting texts and watch cool films that make the class work enjoyable. It actually felt like more speaking, and moderately formal speaking, was required in this class than the advanced speaking class. However, this will certainly help you improve. Small class sizes mean a chance to get to know the professor and classmates well enough that you will become very comfortable with them. Finally, the class really did its job and improved my writing in Spanish.

SPAN 2205.comment: Really enjoyable Spanish class that touches on several different topics. Definitely less work and less stressful than the advanced writing or advanced speaking classes. However, by this point, people taking the class should be interested in Latin America and its writing/art. Professor expects effort but if that is there, you will be fine. If you qualify for the class by official Cornell standards/past classes, your Spanish level should be fine. Definitely worth checking out!

STS 1123.comment: Had Donny Persaud as my professor.  Loved it, great class and great grading system.  Interesting readings and workload was not too bad.  Most of my class were engineering majors and I would say this is very applicable for the STEM field (and non-STEM).

Correction, professor: Vu Tien Dung Ha. Loved this FWS, we learned about the value of self in the context of technology and all the readings were super interesting. Super applicable if you're a STEM major, it's good to learn about the implications of the tech you're using and potentially building

The best FWS I took.  Class consists of only a few 3 page essays about topics that are fascinating to talk about regarding the creation and growth of online communities such as The Well and chat rooms.  Jeffrey Mathias makes the material interesting on many levels and classes are like discussions about the short readings.

STS 1126.comment: Readings and movie screenings every week. The class was disorganized and I did not really learn much by the end of the semester. She stopped grading essays after only the first one. However, she pretty much grades on completion, not quality.

Interesting and interdisciplinary topics covered in food science, technology, and other social topics. Instructions are well organized, course materials including films are fun. It was cool to visit the dairy bar and carry out an interview about students opinions on Cornell Dining.

STS 2011.comment: 400 word response per week, midterm and final. Interesting and fairly easy.

STS 2061.comment: I really enjoyed this class. The professor made the class very entertaining. I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to fulfill a diversity credit.

STS 2451.comment: Markovits is a great lecturer, to the point where I didn't mind waking up at 9 to go to her lectures, and that's saying something. Lectures & discussion posts based on readings are required for attendance/participation, but discussion posts are easy to BS & lectures are pretty interesting. Final is an easy 100 -- she lets you answer whatever questions you like, and they all count for the same amount. Bulk of the work in this class is the written papers -- I think there were three of them. A clear argument is crucial, but in my experience the prof/TAs are more than willing to completely break it down for you if you put in the effort to meet w them. Overall an interesting, relevant, and not-difficult class.

Really nice intro phil course on bioethics. There are readings and discussion posts before lec, and attendance is marked for lec and section but all the material is interesting and engaging. They're all very relevant topics and lots of the material had me thinking and asking questions about things I hadn't really thought of before. If you've never written for a phil course writing papers might be a little difficult but if you work with your TA and the prof, they're really helpful. There's one final exam but it's easy, short answer questions. Overall, one of the more impactful liberal arts courses I've taken at cornell.

The content of the course is super interesting and engaging. Attendance is mandatory for lecture and discussions but, again, the material during lec is really interesting and I honestly enjoyed some of the discussions I've had with classmates during section. If you've never written for a philosophy course, writing papers might be hard but if you work with your TA and prof, you'll be ok. Overall, one of the more impactful liberal arts courses I've taken at Cornell.

Really good class about bioethics. If you don't really like writing papers and have time thinking about your arguments, it might be tough to write a high quality paper, but overall not too much work aside from reading posts and 3 papers.

This is the best class I've taken at Cornell. The content is so interesting and the workload is really manageable. Prof Markovits is knowledgeable and her lectures are definitely not boring. I highly recommend it to everyone.

STS 2468.comment: The whole class was focused on her project in Tanzania, so we barely learned much else. There was no through line between readings, weird grading policies, and the essays had nothing to do with what we were learning in class. Lectures were mostly just prof going on and on and getting so theoretical that it just wasn't engaging. Grade depends completely on ur TA. Our final project was a weird structure and expectations were extremely unclear. Class has a lot of potential and some of the readings were very interesting but it's butchered it in my opinion.

I took this class with professor Langwick. The material is super interesting and I would definitely recommend it to future doctors to learn more about how the role of medicine impacts society and culture. It is a good introduction to medical anthropology. However, this class is a lot of work. There were no prelims but all essays and readings every week. Professor Langwick doesn't allow laptops and she makes you print out the reading for every class and it is around 10 pages. It was bad for the environment. Also there are pop quizzes for the readings. I took it spring 2020 so the second half was impacted by COVID and there was a lot less work.
Langwick was really nice but the class was annoying and had unnecessary busywork. I felt like I learned nothing. She has lenient grading policies and somehow got an A+.

I really like this class. Prof. Hodzic is really interesting and leads very open and insightful discussions in class. There were no prelims in the class which was nice but instead, there were two medium-length essays and one final research paper.  TAs are very helpful and there is plenty of time to do the papers so if you stay on top of it it's not very hard to manage. Readings can be a lot at times but skimming through them usually does the trick and you learn a lot in lecture about each reading.

STS 2812.comment: Really fun, interesting, chill class with light workload--just readings and a discussion post + reply each class. We had fun hands-on "labs" like inscribing cuneiform into clay tablets and Chinese calligraphy, they even mailed remote students the lab materials. Two prelims where we were given question banks that most of the exam was pulled from, and an option for a final paper or creative project (one option was to design your own writing system). The professors are super nice and accommodating, the material was really cool, strongly recommend this class to anyone interested in writing systems, linguistics, different cultures

STS 3011.comment: The readings are quite long (and boring at times). But the class itself is not very difficult, graded on 3 papers to complete and attendance/participation.

Prof Tamarkin actually cares about his students and makes sure not to overload the class with work. Most of the readings were really interesting but some could definitely get a bit dry at times. We had readings before every class and then 3 essay based exams.
Total snoozefest but not hard. Never did any of the readings, got consistently good grades regardless. The entire curriculum is very vague and uninteresting

STS 3911.comment: Professor was a great lecturer. Prelims were straightforward as long as you took basic notes on lectures and readings. Topics were very interesting. Very important to attend every lecture and have a friend in the class that can give you good notes if you are sick because the slides are not posted on Canvas.

STSCI 2100.comment: The material was presented inefficiently and in a confusing manner. Made the class way more complicated then it needed to be and only made it through with tutoring and additional "for dummies" how to books. Kids in this class are trying to fulfill a requirement and dont need the extra bs.

Easily my favorite ILR class. Karns is a really good teacher and makes the material super easy to understand. The tests are fair and you always get a cheat sheet, and none of the tests are cumulative.
easy, if you keep up with lectures. I recommend going
By far the easiest statistics course on campus!!!
Professor is a bit interesting...but the plus side is that you get to bring all your notes to the exams as "cheat sheets"! Makes the class manageable overall!

STSCI 2150.comment: One of my favorite classes at Cornell. Professor Smith really cares about her students! The class is fine if one puts in the work. Do not underestimate the amount of time it takes to complete the homework and lab assignments tho!
great class and super manageable. dr. smith is a queen
This class is super fun and I really enjoyed it.
pretty good course overall and has lots of ways to receive help through office hours. i recommend going to lab as they are helpful for completing the homework.

Interesting class. Loved the fact that we used real life data in the hw because it allows you to better grasp and understand the material. The workload is sort of light, but there is some memorizing, so you can easily be swept off your feet if you're not careful.

STSCI 3080.comment: I really liked the material, but Bunea has some trouble with pacing the class. She goes over introductory probability for a long time and then once the harder material hits she goes pretty fast. She's great at explaining things in office hours (she's an awesome person!), but TA discussion sections were pointless, only about 6 of us went each week and did not gain much. Final exam was worth 45% of our grade and was not cumulative, so all of the material that she rushed through in the last 2 weeks makes a huge impact on your grade.

Took it with Florentina Bunea. Handwriting is really hard to read and the material is very drab. However, Bunea definitely cares about her students and the tests are pretty easy. Watch out for Prelim 2 though, it's the hardest material. The material was basically the same as ENGRD 2700 without hypothesis testing.
Content was easy to follow and prelims were straightforward

Probably the easiest stats class you can take at Cornell for the probability requirement. There were 3 prelims in class and like 4-5 homeworks from the textbook but you could easily do them the night of.
simple probability course, 6 homeworks overall and 3 in class prelims- first half of the class was common stats knowledge that was in AP Stats.

STSCI 3110.comment: I hate this class with a passion. Made me hate statistics and made me want to drop my economics major. His lectures are dry and his squeaky voice makes my head hurt and want to fall asleep but I have to be there for attendance quizzes. He doesn't post his notes, so your only chance is to scribble everything he says to understand the concepts or take pictures. Homeworks are tedious and every week. All the questions are so long too with lots of computations. It isn't that difficult but its so monotonous and braindead my brain feels smooth and my IQ feels like it halved. His exams are awful too. There are like 1 million formulas but then he only tests you on like 4 of them. What a waste of my time to study. If you have to take it, take it S/U and save yourself the headache.

Packard is really boring and dry. PSETS take a long time to do as well. 

Exams are okay? - it might be better to take the other Econ stats class 3130. Did not find the class super helpful.

This class was very similar to AP Stat, with a unit on Continuous variables which needed some calculus review like integrals. 

There were 9 weekly problem sets, but had fake deadlines because all of them were due at the end of the semester so you have to keep yourself accountable.

Lectures are very boring, but attendance is not required. No practice exams are provided. The midterm and final were both online. Homeworks are kind of difficult and very long, but they are due by the end of the semester.
Weekly psets. Kinda random material though compared to other stat/probability classes?? Super easy at first and then got harder.

STSCI 3200.comment: The professor was boring but overall I learned a lot of statistics from the class. I thought that the assignments and quizzes were helpful in learning the material.

Jermey is a boring lecturer but I just watched his recorded lectures. He doesn't give out any practice prelims so the only prep material you get are the lectures and quizzes. Overall, it was a dry class but I learned a lot of R and linear regression.

If you're coming from BTRY 3010, the format of the class is the exact same, except the labs are much harder.  Prelims and final are cumulative, open note but only allowed his notes + your own annotations. Weighting is very fair but still requires you to do pretty well across the board. Overall, a dry lecturer and the material isn't very interesting either. Didn't go to lectures and just watched videos instead. Don't take this class if it isn't for a requirement.

Extremely dry lectures, badly taught, not curved, low median, overall really disliked the class. The only good aspects were that the lectures are recorded and my TA was helpful. If you don't have to take the class, don't.

Extremely dry lectures, badly taught, made me hate the content, not curved, low median, overall disliked the class. The only good aspects were that the lectures are recorded and my TA was helpful. If you don't have to take it, don't.

STSCI 3510.comment: This class has a lot of interedting material that is super applicable to modeling in industry. However, the professor is sometimes really confusing during lectuer. Also the class structure is super stresful with one prelim worth 30% of your grade and a final worth 40%z

Not too bad of a course -- material is reasonable, although the course should really specify prereqs of linear algebra and Python. Prof Dai is hard to understand at first but the accent grows on you; he's also very accommodating.
This class was so difficult. Midterm and final were rough. The homework was the cherry on top, sometimes taking 10+ hrs.

STSCI 4520.comment: Professor Giles is very enthusiastic about the course and obviously knows the topics very well. The coursework consists mainly of 5 bi-weekly problem sets, which take up a lot of time and effort, especially if coding is not one of your strengths. This class is required for the Stat/Btry majors, so try to take it with friends. The topics are also quite interesting as well.
Prof is a bit intimidating, course requires a lot of effort and time with projects but the final grade was very generous for me.

STSCI 4550.comment: Okay class. Lecture videos are pre recorded and lecture times are meant for discussion but no one normally talks. Homeworks aren't too challenging. Not the most useful class and didn't learn a ton.

STSCI 5080.comment: I really liked the material, but Bunea has some trouble with pacing the class. She goes over introductory probability for a long time and then once the harder material hits she goes pretty fast. She's great at explaining things in office hours (she's an awesome person!), but TA discussion sections were pointless, only about 6 of us went each week and did not gain much. Final exam was worth 45% of our grade and was not cumulative, so all of the material that she rushed through in the last 2 weeks makes a huge impact on your grade.

Took it with Florentina Bunea. Handwriting is really hard to read and the material is very drab. However, Bunea definitely cares about her students and the tests are pretty easy. Watch out for Prelim 2 though, it's the hardest material. The material was basically the same as ENGRD 2700 without hypothesis testing.
Content was easy to follow and prelims were straightforward

Probably the easiest stats class you can take at Cornell for the probability requirement. There were 3 prelims in class and like 4-5 homeworks from the textbook but you could easily do them the night of.
simple probability course, 6 homeworks overall and 3 in class prelims- first half of the class was common stats knowledge that was in AP Stats.

VIEN 1104.comment: Not very much work, and kind of interesting. It's more about growing grapes for wine then drinking wine, so if you want to learn more about tasting and such then you should probably take Hotelie wines. There is a tasting every class though.

The class itself is pretty boring, but it's one more credit than hotel wines and you can choose if you want to take it graded or pass/fail. I almost never went to class, didn't study for a single exam (I failed each one), but don't fret, I still ended with an A+ in the class. I don't if it's the same every semester, but we were able to get 44 points of extra credit to add to our cumulative grade, so that's why I rarely went to class and didn't study.

Overall a very interesting class. Couldn't take it in person with actual wine tasting, but professors recommended a bunch of wines we could taste to go along with the material, and students were encouraged to drink tea, coffee, or juices if they couldn't acquire wines. Class is more about the process of making wines and growing grapes, compared to the hotel wines class. COVID semester consisted of module quizzes and small activities. Optional papers could bring you to a 110%, so it is pretty easy to get an A/A+.

The class is very interesting and you learn about the types of wines, but a lot about vineyard management and the growing of the grapes. You learn that there is so much more than you thought to managing a vineyard, and that so many small subtle things go into making a perfect bottle. Weekly quizzes, and 3 wine review papers that require at least 1 journal. Super easy and not a lot of time required for this class. 10 extra credit points total, so you can get up to 110. Arnink is a very nice professor, and Russ is very nice and entertaining, and has a lot to share about his expertise in vineyard management. Do not take ECE 2300 after or you will fall asleep during it.

A great class to sit back, relax and drink a variety of wines. There are wines almost every lecture and it is quite fun to learn about the basic concepts of vitiulture. There are lots of extra credits so most of the students end up with an A.

VIEN 2360.comment: Great class to try liquors and spirits. Minimal workload. Vodka whiskey and other spirits tastings at 10AM

VISST 2000.comment: Hardest liberal studies class I've taken and my lowest grade. Lectures were interesting but there are a ton of readings, paragraph-response exams, discussion sections, meetings with TAs, and a 20-page paper.
Very easy class, all paper based. Lecture topics are interesting but the lectures themselves are boring. No prelims which is very convenient.

The class is super engaging - might be diff now it isn't moisey though - I really liked the content but beware there's a 20 page paper which is kind of difficult to pull together so it's not completely easy

Definitely not the lightest class that you could take to fulfill requirements (I'm a CS major), but super interesting class. It does a broad survey of a bunch of different topics from philosophy of perception/seeing and important visual and aesthetic developments. For me, it really opened up my mind to different topics, and I wish I took it earlier! I did take it during SP20 though, so the class was definitely made easier towards the second half of the semester.
This was a great class! Lots of readings, but it was all interesting and worthwhile because they want you to succeed.

VISST 2805.comment: I really enjoyed this class as it wasn't just a lecture style course, but one that incorporated seeing the art pieces associated with the weekly topics (in the museum, up close, and you can even touch most of them). The professors are both clearly very invested in what they're teaching! Each week had a separate theme (one was tea ceremonies) and I thoroughly enjoyed learning about all of the topics. There's very little work during the semester (just weekly readings) and 1-3 essays (including the final). I wasn't too sure on what they were looking for on the papers but going into office hours was very helpful to see how I could improve for the final.

VISST 3175.comment: The title of the class is “Global Cinema and Media” now, but it was really enjoyable we watched a film every single class (2x a week 2.5 hrs/class) that covered films from the start and went to many different countries and languages. Only a few assignments and the professor is really understanding.

VISST 3342.comment: One of my favorite classes this semester! We get to learn about a lot of interesting topics and watch cool videos in class. Only workload is for prelims. I definitely would recommend this class to others.
This is a great course! Interesting material, not too much work. Plus it counts as an engineering tech elective.

Great class led by a great professor (David Field). Lectures are really interesting, full of in-class demos and videos. There's two prelims and one final -- and for all of these, he'll give you a question bank out of which questions will be picked. There's a few (around 5-6) easy in-class quizzes at random points, so it's good to attend class though not crucial. You can get by without going to class, but I'd highly recommend going to class because it's very interesting!

A very interesting class full of demos, videos and examples for pretty much every topic we cover! The professor is super nice, very knowledgeable and has tons of interesting, relevant facts to share. There is not much workload like no assignments just the exams and sometimes in-class quizzes. The content is not difficult to understand. Highly recommend this course!

Loved this class!  Very interesting material (explaining cool optical illusions), friendly professor, and only work is the 2 prelims and the final.  I took it during covid so exams were online which likely made them easier, but even without that I think it would be a pretty low effort and fun class.

WRIT 1380.comment: FWS: Writing back to the news - I love Professor Kelly!!! This course is quite hard but very rewarding if you put into the work. You can read news article about New Yorker every week and discuss about social issues. I came to the class not liking news but left with a lot of quality writings and ideas. RECOMMEND!!!
